He drives all over the Aghsu region.  He also takes people from the Aghsu region to the capital of Baku. With all this driving, wear and tear on his vehicle has occurred and he needs to make repairs. Cahangir is asking for a loan to make these repairs so that he can transport people safely around the regions of the country.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle

loans.name: Qalib

texts.en: Qalib lives and works in the Novju village in the Aghsu region of Azerbaijan with his wife and four children. He is 55 years old. He started raising sheep and cattle over 20 years ago. With a few setbacks here and there, he has grown his business. Qalib requests a loan to purchase sheep and feed to further provide for and improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and feed

loans.name: Yavar

texts.en: Yavar M. lives in the Novju village in the region of Aghsu in Azerbaijan. She is married with four children. Her, along with her husband Arif, have raised sheep and other livestock for the past 25 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase more sheep and feed to provide for her growing business. (Yavar's husband, Arif, is shown pictured)

loans.use: to purchase sheep and feed

loans.name: Badam

texts.en: Badam lives in Novju village in the region of Aghsu in Azerbaijan. She is married with two children. Her, along with her husband Sakit, raise sheep and other livestock. They started raising sheep for wool over 15 years ago. After growing their business from only a few sheep to now over 50 heads, they want to continue improving their business by purchasing more sheep for the upcoming year. Badam is requesting a loan to purchase more feed for her livestock as well as to purchase more sheep. (Badam's husband, Sakit, is shown pictured)

loans.use: to purchase more sheep and feed

loans.name: Seadat

texts.en: Seadat was born and raised in Aghsu in Azerbaijan. She is married with one child. Seadat and her husband, Qudrat, own and operate a small food market in the city. They started the business nine years ago out of a small location. A few years later they started renting the location where they are currently. The business has been growing well and they want to further expand their store. Seadat is asking for a loan to increase their stock as well as to expand the variety of goods by providing items not previously provided at most stores in the region. (Seadat's husband, Qudrat, is shown pictured.)

loans.use: to expand the variety of goods offered

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is married with four children, all of whom are in primary school. He has not undertaken any training. In 2002 he started his business, which was initially buying and selling cattle. This did not make enough profit for him to sustain his family thus he started selling timber which he does currently. With the proposed loan through PEMCI, he hopes to buy a power saw, which he will use to split his own timber instead of hiring a saw. This will give him an edge over the competition and improve his profit margins. He will also be able to hire out the power saw to other millers, which would bring him some additional income. We believe he has the ability to repay the loan with no difficulty.

loans.use: Timber seller

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a single young man who has undergone training as a mechanic at the Siaya Polytechnic. He has been in business since 2002 after leaving college. Presently he runs a workshop in conjunction with other mechanics. Paul took the first loan of $150, which he repaid in a timely way. With the proposed loan, he intends to buy tools and spare parts to open his own workshop. Through his business he has been able to support his parents and siblings and also to be an inspiration to other younger people. In view of the high unemployment situation in the country, the youth are being encouraged to start their own businesses as Paul has done. Paul is worth supporting in the spirit of empowering the youth of this country as a way of fighting poverty.

loans.use: Buy spare parts and tools.

loans.name: Danson

texts.en:
Danson has four children--two whom are adults and two young ones. He has received training from the Kenya Dairy Board and Land’O’Lakes in the handling and processing of milk products. His business involves buying raw milk from farmers about 75 Km from Malaba town and transporting it to Malaba, where it is pasteurized and distributed to customers.

Currently he is able only to handle 500 litres of milk while his facility is able to process at least 1200 litres. This is his first loan with PEMCI and he intends to use the funds to increase his raw-milk handling capacity. Danson sells milk within Malaba town and as far as into neighboring Uganda. The demand for milk is high as this region does not produce milk.

His objective is to turn his facility into a mini-plant and to diversify into milk products such as yoghurt. He employs four other people in the dairy, in addition to his wife and himself. This project has the potential for growth and is worthy of the support of Kiva and its partners.

loans.use: Increase milk stock.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is married with five children, all of whom are in primary school. Michael runs a small shop and a video entertainment facility at the back of his shop where he shows movies, etc. This is his second loan with PEMCI but his first with Kiva. His first loan enabled him to stock his video library thus improving his business. With the proposed second loan of $225, he intends to register his business with DSTV, a cable TV provider in the region. This will enable him provide quality films and games to his customers, especially during soccer seasons. His wife is also a small-scale business lady. As this is the only video shop in his neighbourhood, his business has good potential for growth.

loans.use: Video show room

loans.name: Demeteria

texts.en: Demeteria is married with two children, both grown up and married. She started her business last year to support herself. She finished her first loan successfully. This is her second loan with PEMCI. Her first loan enabled her to increase her stock and even open up a cereal store at her home. She takes the cereals to the market during market days in addition to her fish business. With the second loan of $225 she wishes to increase her stock further and also buy tobacco from the local farmers in her community and sell it to the factory at a higher price since it’s the season of harvesting tobacco.

loans.use: Purchase cereals and tobacco to sell

loans.name: Crispinus

texts.en: Crispinus started his business in 1990 with capital from the sale of his farm produce. His business includes buying cattle from the nearest markets and selling them at a higher price to farmers or at slaughter houses. Through his business, he has been able to educate his twelve children up to secondary school levels. With the proposed loan of $300 he intends to increase his stock. With sufficient funds he is able to buy more animals, saving on time as these animals have to be transported long distances. He plans to increase the number of animals moved at a single time in future. Livestock trading is a lucrative business and worth supporting.

loans.use: Cattle trading

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en: Carolyne is married with five children. She is a form-two, secondary-school dropout because she lacked school fees. She started her business in 1992 in order to support her family. She is an active member of the local community self-help group. Through her business she has been able to support her children by paying their school fees. With the proposed loan she intends to uplift her stock and be able to save some of the profits to buy herself a piece of land. The amount involved is not large and she should be able to repay the loan without difficulties.

loans.use: Buy fish stocks

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en:
Guadalupe is 33 years old and is a hard working and tenacious woman. She is married and the mother of 2 girls (12 and 14) and hopes that her daughters will complete university. Her husband works in a meat packing company, however his salary does not cover all the family expenses. For this reason, Guadalupe was motivated to start her own business and started selling tacos in 1997. She started with very little capital in a rented space, but now, thanks to her reinvestment of income, she is able to rent a better space.

Now, Guadalupe needs a loan of $475 which she will use to buy shells, kitchen utensils and food items to make tacos. Guadalupe is confident that she will succeed in her business and is grateful for all the assistance received.

loans.use: Kitchen goods/Food production and sales

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina is 45 years old, she is married and has 3 children aged 24, 19 and 11. Her husband works laying flooring, however as there has not been stable income for the family, there have been hard times when unexpected expenses arise. Ernestina wants her children to attend university, and so, in order to pay for this expense and other family expenses, she started selling shoes, as recommended by a good friend. Sales have increased as she is a good sales person and is motivated by the income available to her family.

Ernestina's clients are increasing and she needs to cover the costs in order to have the needs of her clients met, in order to offer them a good service. For this reason, she needs a loan of $475 which she will use to buy merchandise, to have variety and to grow her business. You can help Ernestina and the life of her family by making a contribution.

loans.use: Merchandise purchases

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina and her husband have been selling nutritional products for two years. They have 4 children, but only the youngest, who is 17 years old, lives with them. Josefina's mother-in-law is sick, and in order to pay for the necessary medication, she and Juan Carlos, her husband, started this business and now they are distributors in several cities near Tampico, their home town.

Josefina needs a loan of $475 which will be used to buy more merchandise to sell to other municipalities nearby, as she has seen that there is high demand and she wants to expand the business. You can contribute to the growth of the business. Your help is appreciated.

loans.use: Merchandise purchases

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza is married with six children, although only the youngest, who is 15, lives at home, and the rest are already married. She and her husband make and sell block ice in Saltillo, Coahuila, where they are originally from. They started this business in order to provide for and educate their children. They started by making the blocks, and after eight years, they were able to buy a machine to make the ice flakes and expand the business. Her husband has an adapted motorcycle that is used for the sales of icecones in parks and outside schools.

Esperanze needs a loan of $600 which will be used to buy additional products to make the snow/ice. You can contribute to the growth of the business and improving her family's life.

loans.use: Consumer goods purchase

loans.name: Con

texts.en:
Con is 30. Cao’s husband, Vuong, is 33. They have a child who is going to nursery school; he is 5. Their activity is to make baskets from bamboo trees.

Their income is $11 per person/month. Cao and Cao's husband need a loan $75 from the Kiva programme so that they can continue and expand their activity. They will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To make baskets from bamboo

loans.name: Tuoi

texts.en:
Tuoi is 54 years old and her husband 59 years old. They have two daughters and a son. Their ages are 20, 18, 15. Only the youngest daughter continues at school. The women's activities are to sell groceries. Tuoi’s husband and son are farmers. They have land for growing rice, which is 5000 square meters.

Though they have the capacity, they don't have enough capital to increase the variety of goods for the grocery store and improve their rice productivity by using fertilizer. Their income is $7 per person/month. They want to receive a loan for $75 in order to enabL. their activities. They will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To increase a variety of goods for the grocery store; buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Noor Mohhamd

texts.en: Noor M. is 52 with a household of 8 in District 8 of Kabul City. His main business is general repairing but he prefers car repairing because he can make more income. He had few materials so he took a loan to buy car parts and hire one assistant to work better and repair their clients' cars. He has 3 sons who are working with them in the workshop. With this loan process he can cover his financial obligations.

loans.use: Buying car parts

loans.name: Mohmmad Parwiz

texts.en: M. Parwiz lives with his 3 children in District 8 of Kabul City. During the war he lost his wife in a bomb blast. He has a vehicle repairing shop with 6 years experience repairing tires, diesel pumps, engines, brakes and other parts of taxis and other cars. He faced lots of financial problems during the war. Now he is taking a loan to develop his business and cover his financial obligations.

loans.use: Buying Materials

loans.name: Cu

texts.en:
Mrs Cu and her husband have 8 children between 25 and 8. Her second child, Hung, is 22 years old. He became paralytic after falling from a tree.

They only have a little land, about 6,000 m2, to plant cashew nut trees but the land is very poor and they have no capital so they can’t gather the harvest.

Mrs Cu used to sell chickens and pepper at small market but the poultry contracted bird flu which ruined her business. Huong, her husband, only works on their cashew nut garden, and the income from this land is not enough for their family.

The four eldest children stopped going to school and have to work as a day laborers but they only enough money for their own living. Their average income is $9/person/month. Now, she asks to borrow a loan of $100 for her pepper selling and to buy fertilizer for their cashew nut trees.

loans.use: Sell chickens and pepper

loans.name: Hue

texts.en:
Miss Hue and her husband have 3 children. They are 13, 11 and 6. Dung, Hue’s husband, was stabbed his back in the argument with friend and he was paralyzed. The family sold their house to pay for his medical treatment.

Miss Hue doesn’t have any land or a house and she must support 3 children going to school. Selling fish is thus important for them to increase their very small income by about $2/person/month. Their average income is $8/person/month. Miss Hue has already repaid two loans. Now she wants to borrow a loan of $75 for her fish business.

loans.use: Selling fish

loans.name: Vy

texts.en: Miss Vy and her husband have 5 children between 13 and 1. They must support children going to school, and they must support their mother, who is old. The family doesn’t have any land, so they only earn money through their sales business. Hung, Miss Vy’s husband, buys coconuts from door to door and then sells them at the market. Vy also sells food for breakfast in the morning at the market. They borrowed a loan with no interest from the project, which has been important for them, as it increased their income by about $2.50/person/month. Average income is $12/person/month. Miss Vy has repaid a loan of $75, and now she asks to borrow a loan of $75 again.

loans.use: sells food for breakfast

loans.name: Zelaikha

texts.en: Zelaikha is 30 years old. She has an electronic flour mill. She gets grain and mills it. Her son is helping her do this by selling the milled flour to the market. She wants get a loan to buy flour and more fuel for generating electricity. She wants to expand her business and make more money and support her family economically.

loans.use: Electronic mill and fuel

loans.name: Lailoma

texts.en:
Lailoma is married. She has four children. She is borrowing this money for her son's shop. She herself manages the cash and takes part in cleaning, organizing, and packaging of the material. Her son  helps with the purchasing and selling.
She wants to get a loan to expand this business and make more money to support her family economically.

loans.use: Buying more food material

loans.name: Roqia

texts.en: Roqia is 25 years old. She is single. She has lots of customers. She is doing different types of embroidery. She wants to get a loan to buy an embroidery machine to make more nice designs according to customers' orders. She wants to expand her business and wishes to have a nice shop in the future.

loans.use: Buy embroidery machine, thread, cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I intend to expand and diversify my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the loan to expand my businesses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Aliitasi

texts.en: Aliitasi S. is a forty four year old woman and she has seven children.  Aliitasi is passionate about her taxi business and she and her husband are able to raise almost ST 200 per day (approximately USD 80).  Micro-loan facilities are critical to helping Aliitasi and her husband maintain this income stream and keep their seven children in school.  As this large family’s income is entirely dependent on a single auto, providing financing to Aliitasi will allow her to purchase spare tires, brake fluid and Samoan road licenses to keep the taxi business running.  Aliitasi happily reports that she finally has what she has always dreamed about – a thriving business.

loans.use: Auto repairs and road licenses

loans.name: Amataga

texts.en:
Amataga S. is a talented 32-year-old woman who makes flavored ices to sell in her village. She is married and has five children. Amataga believes in herself and her ability to expand her business. Her husband and children are very supportive of her efforts, and the entire family benefits from the income she generates (up to USD 40 a day). This income is critical to meeting the basic needs of her large family.

Amataga is applying for a loan to purchase supplies in bulk so that she can increase her inventory. She is confident that she can sell more product, because she is often unable to meet the current, high demand. Flavored ices are a favorite in the village, especially with the local primary schoolchildren.

loans.use: Purchase of plastic cups, purified water, sugar, cordials

loans.name: Aniva

texts.en: Aniva is fifty-four years of age and has six children.  Aniva believs that her small business really helps her raise her family’s standard of living.  She is also very confident of her abilities to run the business, especially since she has support from her family and friends, and they believe in her enterprise.  She started off with only one product – selling baked fish in her local village; but with previous SPBD loans, she explored adding a second product, baked chicken.  Since she started, she feels that her customer base has grown a lot and she feels there is more growth possible if she is able to expand her supply and product line.  Aniva admits to working very hard to make this business a success and is proud of her efforts.  She is confident that she is able to provide the best quality goods with the lowest prices in the village.  Aniva will use the loan funds to purchase larger supplies of fish and chicken as well as some basic baking supplies.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and baking supplies

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en: Amelia S. is from the village of Tafitoala.  She is thirty-six years of age with six children.  Amelia’s small business project is fishing, and her husband is helping her make the business a success.  Amelia sells some of her fish at the local market as well as in front of her village road so that passing traffic can easily see her catch.  On a good day, Amelia can earn ST 100 (approximately USD 40). The business is her family’s main source of income, and it ensures that her children can stay in school by enabling her to pay the school fees, buy uniforms and school supplies.  Amelia will use her loan to buy time-saving equipment such as fishing nets, spears and baskets to store fish in etc.  She is very thankful of the support and help of her family in helping grow the business, especially her husband for working really hard.

loans.use: Purchasing fishing nets, spears and baskets

loans.name: Eseese

texts.en: Eseese is 29-years old.  She has seven children and she lives in the small village of Sataoa.  She is very happy about her small fishing business that she runs with her husband.  Eseese’s husband does most of the fishing in the daytime when the tide is low.  Eseese is responsible for selling the fish; she sells fish in front of their house under the shade of a large tree.  Many people pass by, and on a good day, Eseese is able to bring in about ST 200 (USD 80).  This is the sole income source for her and her large family.  An initial loan from SPBD helped her purchase time-saving equipment which has improved their fishing yield, and she is anxious to secure more loan funds to invest further in her business.

loans.use: Purchase fishing nets, spears and baskets

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta L. is thirty–eight years of age and is from the village of Sataoa.  She has two children.  Her small business project is running a banana plantation.  There are many different types of bananas that grow well in Samoa and bananas are a staple of the local diet.  Eseta works from morning till evening to clear brush, weed and plant bananas.  Her husband also believes in the business and helps when he can.  Eseta takes her bananas to the local markets and sells them there.  The income from Eseta’s banana sales are crucial to providing for the basic needs of her family, and she is anxious to invest further in her business.  With a loan, she hopes to purchase natural fertilizers that can improve her crop yield as well as materials to build a fence around her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and fencing material

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta was born on April 20th, 1938 and has worked hard her whole life to raise her nine children and provide each of them with food, clothing and an education.  Eseta is a well-known businesswoman in her village.  She is able to provide for her family with the almost ST 150 (approximately USD 60) that she earns selling her famous pork buns at the local market as well as at a small shop at her family’s residence.  Many place orders ahead of time, so she is confident of the high demand for her product.  She will use a loan to purchase bulk supplies like flour and oil as well as to upgrade some of her supplies and equipment, like purchasing a new frying pan and plastic bags to seal her orders.   Eseta is confident that investing in her business is the right thing for her and her family’s future.

loans.use: Purchase supplies and equipment

loans.name: Ese

texts.en: Ese T. is from the village of Lotofaga Safata.  She is 43-years old and has four children; two of her children are married while the other two remain in school.  She is pictured here with her small children and her grandchildren.  Ese runs a small retail shop in her village.  She is very focused on growing her business and so is her entire family.  By working together, her family ensures that the shop is able to stay open long hours to satisfy her customers and improve her profits.  Ese reinvests as much of her business profit as possible; she is working hard to expand her product line to ensure that the local villagers have access to a wide variety of products.  She will use a loan to buy more merchandise for her shop as well as to buy wood, paint, and corrugated iron to renovate her shop, as a portion of the structure is damaged.

loans.use: Purchase inventory and supplies for renovation of store

loans.name: Fiaaluai

texts.en: Fiaaluai V. is from the village of Lotofaga Safata. She is 35-years old.  Fiaaluai runs a sewing business.  Fiaaluai is very vocal about being grateful for the sewing talent that she has and that she is able to leverage this talent to provide for her family.  By working hard, Fiaaluai is able to sew more than twenty clothing items a day to fulfill the orders that locals place.  Local villagers appreciate Fiaaluai’s talents as a tailor and come to her for clothing for special occasions like birthdays, weddings and church events.  Fiaaluai is confident that by continuing to work hard and invest in upgrading her sewing supplies and materials, she can ensure her customers remain happy with her product and keep returning for more.

loans.use: Purchase sewing machine needles, fabric and for upgrading sewing supplies

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Faafetai T. is from the village of Sataoa.  She is fifty–five years of age and has raised four children.  Her business project is running a cattle farm behind her house.  Right now, Faafetai has ten cattle and is seeking a loan to purchase additional cattle as well as some materials to repair her fences.  Faafetai can sell one cow for about ST 150 (approximately USD 60), and her sales usually come from a local villager buying a cow to slaughter them for a funeral, wedding or birthday.

loans.use: Buy cattle and fencing material

loans.name: Fine

texts.en: Fine G. is from the village of Vaiee.  She is 42-years old and has five children.  She runs a sewing business and makes clothes on order for the local villagers.  She works very long hours trying to fulfill all of her customers’ orders and her family is very supportive of her business efforts.  On a productive day, she can complete up to twenty items of clothing a day and bring in about ST 200 (approximately USD 80).  She is confident of the demand for her unique tailoring talents in the village that she lives in.  With a loan, Fine will make some needed repairs to her machine and purchase additional sewing supplies.  A loan to Fine ensures that she can continue to leverage her talent to provide for the educational expenses of her five children and continue to raise the living standard of her family.

loans.use: Purchase sewing supplies and make machine repairs

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: Folole is 64-years old and has raised five children.  Many of her children still rely on her for financial support so her income from the village store that she operates is necessary to provide for her needs as well as her family.  She quickly acknowledges that she is grateful to have her shop to support herself, her children and her grandchildren.  Her store services the locals in her small village and supplies them with a variety of goods:  snacks, juices, water, toilet tissue, soap, frozen foods, etc.  Her revenues can be up to ST 300 a day (approximately USD 120), but she has to work hard to translate this into a profit.  Folole is passionate about investing in expanding her product line as well as renovating some damaged parts of the store’s structure in order to attract more customers.   She will use a loan to refill her shelves, repaint the store and repair the roof.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for resale and paint,  wood, roofing material for repairs

loans.name: Fuamata

texts.en: Fuamata is 58-years old and has raised five children and one of her children still remains in school.  Fuamata has used taro to support her large family for some years.  Daily, she tends her half-acre taro plantation and is very thankful for the work as it has helped raise her family’s standard of living.  Fuamata hauls her taro product to the local markets to sell.  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and she has no trouble selling her crop.  Fuamata is applying for a loan to purchase some insecticides to increase her crop yield as well as some bush knives and gloves to make the work easier for her.

loans.use: Purchase insecticides, bush knives, gloves

loans.name: Fuaselela

texts.en: Fuaselela lives in the small Samoan village of Tafitoala.  She is a hard-working woman who believes in herself.  Through her hard work, she has raised six children and put them through school.  Fuaselela’s business is making and selling pork pies and pork buns for sale in her village.  Demand for Fuaselela’s goods is very high amongst the locals.  Her daughters help in the making of the pork pies and pork buns, and they sell them both from their residence and at a stand at the village school.  Fuaselela is committed to continuing to expand her business, and she is currently looking for a stall at the local flea market, which she thinks will be the best locale for generating demand.  By working very hard, Fuaselela and her daughters can make up to ST 100 (approximately USD 40) a day selling their pork pies and pork buns.  They all feel that this is a revenue stream worth investing in for the sake of their children.

loans.use: Buy flour, pork, baking equipment

loans.name: Leata

texts.en:
Leata is an enterprising young woman.  She is 22-years old and runs a small shop in her Samoan village.  She maintains a variety of products inside her shop and prides herself on her ability to meet the varied needs of her customers.  She is passionate about being able to provide the best quality at the lowest prices in town.  Leata readily admits to being very happy with her business enterprise and proud of the fact that she can contribute a meaningful amount to her family’s income.  

Leata is applying for a loan to both purchase additional merchandise/inventory for re-sale in her store as well as purchase some paint and other materials to keep her store in good condition.

loans.use: Buy merchandise/inventory and store renovation materials

loans.name: Lama

texts.en: Lama S. is 45 years old and has seven children to support.  She rents beach fales (small open huts on the beach) to tourists.  Back-packers or passers-by will use the fales to picnic or to spend the night.  The fales are located on a white sandy beach on Samoa’s coastline.  Lama can earn up to ST 300 (USD 120) per week.  She is very proud of the hospitality she can show the tourists and is grateful for their words of encouragement.  Currently she has ten fales, and she would use loan funds to begin building another as well as to make repairs on the existing structures.

loans.use: Build additional fales (huts)

loans.name: Lotufaamanatu

texts.en: Lotufaamanatu is 38 years old and has six children.  Four of the children are in school, and Lotufaamanatu’s income from the taro crop is critical to keeping current with the children’s school fees and supplies.  Lotufaamanatu and her husband work together to raise taro for sale at the local markets.  Her husband does most of the farming, while Lotufaamanatu is responsible for hauling the product to market and ensuring they receive good prices for their crop.  She is confident in her business skills and is thus applying for a small loan to help her purchase another small plot of land in order to expand the taro plantation.

loans.use: Purchase acre of land for planting taro

loans.name: Lolofa

texts.en: Lolofa K. is 44-years old and has four children who live with her in the small Samoan village of Vaiee.  Lolofa  is grateful for the weaving talent that she has.  She has used previous SPBD loans to leverage this talent to provide for her family.  With very hard work, she can weave up to 10 fine mats per day that will sell for a total of ST 250 (approximately USD 100).  Her mats are well known and villagers come to her and place advance orders for special occasions.  With a thriving business and a history of repaying past loans in full and on time, Lolofa now qualifies for a home improvement loan.  Providing funds to Lolofa will help her make some basic improvements to her family home’s roof and floor.  Lolofa’s home also doubles as her workshop, and so a loan to Lolofa will help ensure that she can keep her raw materials and finished mats safe, clean and dry.

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa lives in the small Samoan village of Fagalii–uta  with her seven children.  She is 52 years old, and she is the proud owner of a small village shop.  In her small store, she sells a variety of products to the local villagers such as, snacks, mutton, toilet tissue, water and much, much more.  While there are several competing shops in the village, Luisa has a loyal cadre of customers and is committed to expanding her product line and ensuring a consistent supply of goods so that she can ensure her customers are satisfied.  She feels confident that combining the right products with good service will ensure her success.  Luisa’s children help her run the shop, ensuring she can remain open long hours to service the villagers.  Luisa will use a loan to purchase merchandise for re-selling in her store as well as to make some small improvements to better the appearance of the store and make it more attractive and inviting to potential customers.

loans.use: Buy merchandise and materials for renovation

loans.name: Masaolagai

texts.en: Masaolagi is a hard-working Samoan woman.  She is 53 years old and has seven children.  She has put all seven through school, although many of them still rely on Masaolagi for financial support.  She is able to meet her family’s basic needs by making donuts and selling them to local shops to sell to their customers.  One of her daughters helps make the donuts each day, and her husband helps her buy bulk supplies and makes deliveries of the donuts to the local shops for re-sale.  The family can bring in up to ST 180 (approximately USD 70) on a good day.  Masaolagi is woman of much heart and perseverance, and her motto is that “struggle will lead to a happy end”, so she is confident that her efforts are worthwhile.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for making donuts

loans.name: Matapa

texts.en: Matapa is from the Samoan village of Lotofaga Safata.  She’s thirty-one years of age with three kids.  Her primary goal is business success, and she works hard daily to achieve it.  She and her family rely on their daily catch for income.  Her husband does most of the fishing, while Matapa’s main job is hauling their catch to the local market and ensuring she is getting good prices.  She can earn up to ST 150 (USD 60) a day.  Matapa is confident that investing in her and her husband’s fishing business is the best way for to ensure an education and a bright future for her three small children.

loans.use: :  fishing nets, spears, baskets, etc.

loans.name: Polima

texts.en: Polima is a talented woman with four lovely children.  She makes several products that she sells to the local villagers – a delicious coconut/tapioca drink, cakes, buns and donuts.  She admits that making enough of these products each day to satisfy her customer base is very hard work, but her family and friends are very supportive of her efforts to be a successful entrepreneur.  Polima sells her goods through local shops and just by walking around in her village with a basket of goods.  Polima’s business income is critical to supporting the needs of her family and she is committing to continuing to invest in the business.  A loan will give Polima the capital to purchase supplies in bulk (and thus at a better rate) and ensure a consistent supply of her delights for the local villagers.

loans.use: :  Buy bulk products to make drinks and baked goods

loans.name: Meiema

texts.en: Meiema is 46 years old and is a mother of four children.  Meiema’s entrepreneurial spirit led her to take out an initial loan from SPBD to start up a canteen at the village school selling buns, donuts, ice-cakes and banana chips.  With subsequent loans, Meiema was able to turn this small canteen into a proper, well-organized shop.  Her shop opened a couple months ago, and she reports strong sales thus far.  She is anxious to continue to invest her in business and is anxious to enlarge her shop further.  She happily reports that her dream of becoming a business owner has finally come true.  An investment in Meiema’s shop will help her reach her dreams of success.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara T. is a hard-working fifty-three year old womanwith seven children. Her husband and all the children work together to tend the taro plantation.  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and there is always demand for it at the local markets.  The family can bring in up to ST 100 per day (approximately USD 40) with their taro crop sales.  This is the main income source for this large family, and Sara feels that it is a sustainable income that they can grow with hard work.  She says that if the family concentrates on working hard, the money will come and will be enough to meet their needs.  She is applying for a loan to buy some basic gardening equipment like shovels, knives and gloves to help make their work more productive.

loans.use: :  Buy equipment:  shovels, knives, gloves

loans.name: Salu

texts.en: Salu is a 45-year old woman who lives by the seawith her husband and their seven children.  Her husband and all the children are working together to make Salu’s business a success.  The family has built small open huts called fales on the beach (in the style of traditional Samoan houses) and back-packers will rent these huts for picnics or to spend the night on the beach.  In one weekend, Salu had twenty people stay at the fales.  With this promising indication of demand, Salu and her family are anxious to invest further in their fales, building additional and renovating the current ones, in order to attract more tourists.   She is confident in her abilities to manage a growing enterprise and enthused at the prospect of being the owner of a thriving business.

loans.use: additional fales and upgrade current fales

loans.name: Nafeesa

texts.en:
Nafeesa D/O Besmillah, 33, lives in District 8 of Kabul City. She is married and has 7 family members. She has an embroidery business at home, and through this she assists her husband in solving financial problems. After her marriage she faced lots of financial problems because her husband was jobless for 3 months. At that time she wanted to start her business in a shop, but her husband didn't give her permission to start a business in a shop. Therefore she decided to start her business in her home.

With her first loan, she purchased abrics and produced some clothes and sold them in the market. Her business grew from the time she took her 2nd and 3rd loans. Now she is in her 4th loan cycle and wants to continue taking loans because she is happy that through loans, she was able to start a successful business.

loans.use: Buying cloth, thread, etc

loans.name: Wahida

texts.en:
Wahida, 22 is the daughter of Sardar M. and lives in District 8 of Kabul City. She is a high school graduate, but due to financial problems she wasn't able to attend University. She is single and is willing to help her family overcome financial problems. She shares a business with her father who has a chicken meat cart in one of the markets of Kabul City. Her father started the business with limited resources and little meat and it was hardly possible for him to keep his business going.

Then Wahida heard about the AFSG loan process and she decided to start taking loans for her father's business. She started with the first cycle through which she bought more meat for her father and their business improved by the time she took her 3rd cycle. She is now at her 4th cycle and is happy with the loan process.

loans.use: Buying Chicken Meat

loans.name: Selesitina

texts.en: Selesitina is married and has four children.  Selesitina’s husband is unemployed and her small business making banana chips is the sole source of income for their large family.  As the family breadwinner, Selesitina works long hours, but she reports that it is a good feeling to be able to provide for her children.  Her confidence is growing as her profits climb – she can earn up to ST 150 (approximately USD 60) a day by selling her banana chips through local village stores.  She will use the loan to purchase some basic equipment, like frying pans, as well as buy bulk supplies of the necessary ingredients.

loans.use: Buy bulk supplies of ingredients such as oil and frying pans

loans.name: Sililoa

texts.en: Sililoa lives in a tiny seaside village on the island of Samoa.  She is 45 years old and fishes with her husband.  The income from their daily catch is the sole source of income for their family.  Her husband does the bulk of the fishing in the early morning, and Sililoa’s responsibility is to haul their catch to the local market and negotiate good sale prices.  She is confident that investing in their fishing business is the right thing for the whole family and is applying for a loan to help them buy some new nets and basic equipment to improve their fishing yield.

loans.use: Buy fishing equipment, e.g. nets, knives

loans.name: Sitaua

texts.en: Sitaua is a hard-working woman of forty-nine years of age.  She has eight children that live with her in a small village in Samoa.  Sitaua strives very hard.  She is very grateful for the support of her husband and children in helping her reach her dreams.  She makes snacks to sell at a canteen that she operates on Fridays and Saturdays in the local village.  She sells flavored ices, cakes, buns and a variety of packaged snacks.  Sitaua feels confident that investing time and money in her business is the only way to really bring in the extra income necessary to raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase food containers and coolers

loans.name: Sinai

texts.en: Sinai lives in a small Samoan village, is married and has eight children.  She has a half-acre garden where she grows vegetables for sale to the local villagers.  The work is laborious, as Sinai grows many different kinds of vegetables, such as pumpkins, cabbages and carrots.  Sinai sets up a stand in front of her house to sell her vegetables.  Sinai’s family recognizes this small business as critical to their welfare and so all help out in tending the garden and selling the vegetables.  She has dreams of being able to purchase more land to expand her garden.

loans.use: Purchase seeds to grow and sell vegetables

loans.name: Sootino

texts.en: Sootino F. is a young, talented, 36-year old woman with three children.  She has a unique talent in baking Chinese cookies.  These are a very popular item with the local villagers, especially the schoolchildren.  She works long hours everyday to bake as many cookies as possible to satisfy the demand of her customers.  The demand is so high that even Sootino’s husband helps out in the baking and the deliveries to the local shops.  Both Sootino and her husband believe that investing in this business is the best way that they can raise their family’s standard of living.  Sootino is applying for a small loan to gain access to the capital necessary for purchasing ingredients in bulk (and thus at better prices) as well as to purchase some containers that she can use for delivering her Chinese cookies to the local stores.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and food containers

loans.name: Suati

texts.en: Suati L. is an enterprising young woman of thirty-three years of age.  She’s married with four children and lives in a small Somoan village.  Suati, her husband and their extended family have founded a small brick making business.  They are the only business of this kind in the area, and thus they feel that investing further in the business will mean handsome future profits.  Suati, for her part, is passionate about keeping her children in school and ensuring a future full of opportunities for them, and she feels like working hard in the family business is best way for her to reach that goal.

loans.use: :  Buy cement, wheelbarrow, spades

loans.name: Taase

texts.en: Taase is forty years old. She’s married and has five children.  Taase maintains a strong belief in her business as does all of her family.  They all believe that investing time and money in their taro plantation is the only way to raise their standard of living.  Taase will use her loan to buy more bush knives for clearing brush and digging taro; this will make the work quicker and more productive.  Taase hauls her family’s taro crop to the new market in town twice a week.  She claims that the high quality of her product is what keeps her regular customers coming back each week.

loans.use: :  Bush knives

loans.name: Talafaaiva

texts.en: Talafaaiva is 45-years old and lives in a small Samoan village.  She has seven children and runs a taro plantation in order to provide for the basic needs of her family.  The entire family helps Talafaaiva with her taro plantation.  Her husband and her children help with the brush clearing and weeding.  Talafaaiva hauls a taro crop to the local market every day to sell.  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and she has no trouble finding demand for her product.  Customers even come by her home asking to buy taro.  Her family is confident that growing the taro crop is the key to raising their standard of living, and so Talafaaiva is applying for a loan to purchase time-saving equipment to that they can expand their plantation.

loans.use: Buy equipment such as bush knives, gloves, shovels

loans.name: Talalelei

texts.en: Talalelei is 32 years old, is married and has four children.  She makes flavored ices to sell at the local primary school in her village.  With the help of previous loans, she has seen her business grow and is confident that she can continue to enlarge her customer base.  However, in order to keep making her product, Talalelei needs to purchase a new refrigerator / freezer.  She is applying for a loan to get access to the capital to make this large purchase.  Providing funds to Talalelei to make this purchase ensures that she can continue to work to provide her family with a steady, necessary income.  She is thankful for the micro-loans and says that her dream is to someday open a retail shop in her village.  With Talalelei’s past record of success, SPBD is sure she can achieve this goal.

loans.use: Buy new refrigerator/freezer

loans.name: Taua

texts.en: Taua is fifty-eight years old.  She has three children, and they are all married with families of their own.  The family’s taro plantation is their main source of income.  Only one person in this extended family has a job outside the small family farm.  Taua believes that it is investment in growing the taro plantation that will help her raise the standard of living for her children and grandchildren.  Three times a week, the family sells their taro crop at the local market.  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and there is always ample demand for their supply.  Taua is applying for a loan so that she can make some basic improvements to their plantation tools.  She wishes to purchase additional fencing, bush knives and gloves.

loans.use: :  Buy equipment:  fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Taualagi

texts.en: Taualagi S. is forty-two years old.  She is married and has five children.  She tends a vegetable farm with her husband and children.  Taualagi works daily from morning until evening to make her garden productive.  This is the main source of income for this large family, and Taualagi is anxious to invest further in the family business.  She equates a loan to their business as an investment in her children’s futures.  She is applying for a loan to purchase additional seeds to expand the variety of vegetables that she raises.  She thinks expanding her variety and supply will help her attract a set of customers.

loans.use: Buy seeds, gardening tools

loans.name: Tuimema

texts.en: Tuimema is 33 years old.  She has two children who are in primary school.  She runs a small shop in the Samoan village of Sataoa.  She knows everyone in the village, and her friendly smile and kind words keep customers returning to her store.  She is confident that she can continue to expand her shop and is enthused at the future prospect of being owner of a large, successful store.  Tuimema is applying for a loan to help expand her product line and ensure a consistent supply of goods to the local customers.

loans.use: :  Buy merchandise for resale in her shop

loans.name: Tuinanau

texts.en: Tuinanau is 47 years old and has raised six children.  All six of her children are married and have their own families.  Tuinanau is a very independent-minded woman and does not want to depend on her children and their families for financial support so she used an initial SPBD loan to start a business selling flavored ices (locally referred to as “ice cakes”) to the children at the local primary school.  Her business has strong sales, and she is applying for an additional loan in order to purchase supplies in bulk (and thus at better rates) and continue to make her product.  A loan to Tuinanau will help ensure that she can continue to run her business and remain financially independent.

loans.use: Buy purified water, sugar, cordials

loans.name: Vaituutuu

texts.en: Vaituutuu is woman of 59 years, but she says she still feels young.  She has raised eight children and all are now married and have their own families.  However, many of her children and grandchildren still rely on Vaituutuu for financial support and all take part in her popcorn making business.  She makes and packages her popcorn and sells it to shops and customers in the village.  Vaituutuu’s family used to struggle to bring in enough income to cover their basic needs, and with the previous loans having allowed her to launch this small business, Vaituutuu says she feels like a rich woman!  Providing her another loan will allow her to purchase popcorn, oil and packaging in bulk and thus at better rates.

loans.use: supplies:  popcorn, oil, packaging

loans.name: Vasiliy

texts.en:
Shortly after Ukraine gained it’s independence in 1991, Vasiliy took advantage of new economic freedoms and opened his first grocery store in the city of Kharkiv. Fifteen years later, his business is thriving. He has expanded by opening a second store, employs ten people and is in the process of remodeling a third store that will hopefully open soon. Eventually he would like to build a new building on his own land. Vasiliy is an energetic and hard-working business owner but also very kind and caring. He strives to maintain quality service in his stores and take care of his customers. For each of his employees he provides a retirement plan – a very good benefit for a private employer. Vasiliy and his wife have two sons and are active in their church. Their desire is for others to share the hope they have in Jesus Christ. Vasiliy has requested a loan for $1000 to add to his working capital. Increasing competition makes it all the more important for him to maintain a broad and fresh product selection. He’d like to use this money to expand the amount of goods he has available in his stores.

Після того, як Україна отримала незалежність в 1991 році, Василь вирішив скористатися перевагами нового економічного суспільства та відкрив свою першу крамницю в м. Харків. З тих пір пройшло вже 15 років, бізнес Василя до сих пір успішно розвивається. Він відкрив другу крамницю, взяв на роботу 10 працівників; зараз робить ремонт в третій крамниці, планує скоро її відкрити. В майбутньому планує побудувати окреме торгове приміщення на власній ділянці. Василь – дуже енергійний та працьовитий, але й добрий, дбайливий. Він завжди намагається якісно обслуговувати покупців та привітно ставитися до кожного клієнта. Продавці, які працюють на Василя, офіційно найняті на роботу, а, отже, їм нараховується пенсійний стаж. Василь – одружений, в нього двоє синів, вони активно служать в церкві. Вірою в Ісуса Христа прагнуть поділитися з усіма оточуючими. Василь просить про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб збільшити власний робочий капітал. Він розуміє, що конкуренція стає все жорсткішою, саме тому вибір свіжих продуктів має бути більшим та різноманітнішим. Василь хоче використати ці кошти для того, щоб поповнити асортимент харчових товарів в крамницях.

loans.use: Broaden product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anne Marie

texts.en: Anne Marie M. started her business in 1977. She began selling seven small boxes of soaps and used clothes. She joined Hope’s group (a Microfinance Institution in DRCongo) in 2004. Anne borrowed from Hope seven times, expanding and diversifying her business by adding wheat and corn flour and vegetable oil. Currently her business capital is $1,500. Now, she wants a loan of $1,000 to expand her business in order to meet customer demand and generate additional profits. Anne’s medium-term plan is to be able to consistently purchase a quantity of 100 sacks of wheat flour from the factory, which will give her a bonus of three sacks for her purchase. Anne was born in 1948, and she is married with nine children.

loans.use: To buy more goods to meet the customer demand and generate additional profits.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif is a resident of the town of Beylagan. He is 42 years old and has three children. In 2006 he started his own business and has built a shop where he sells food items. As this is the only source of income for his family he wants to develop the business. His market is quite new and he has little capital of his own to develop the business. He wants to organize his shop and buy a counter regrigerator where he could store dairy and meat products. He applied to Normicro Beylagan branch for the first time for his loan of $600.

loans.use: To buy a counter refrigerator

loans.name: Shukur

texts.en: Shukur is a local resident of the town of Beylagan. He is 50 years old, married and has three children. He rents a place in the local market where he sells shoes. He has been working in the market since 2004 and has established his business well. When he first started the business he borrowed 400$ from Normicro Beylagan branch to buy shoe varities to sell. Since then he has been one of the best clients of Normicro. Later on, he borrowed two more loans. As he continually buys new models of shoes, he now needs 1200$ now to increase the variety.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en: Rahima is a Displaced Person from the Armenian occupied Fizuli region of Azerbaijan. Now she lives in the town of Beylagan with her family. When they were relocated to Beylagan she decided to contribute to the family income. She rented a place in Beylagan market in 2000 and started to sell textile goods and curtains. Having little funds of her own, in 2004 she applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed $300 to buy new textile goods for her shop to develop the business. Later she borrowed two more loans. Now she needs another loan to buy a good counter table.

loans.use: To buy a new counter table

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Tofig

texts.en: Tofig is a local resident. He is 48 years old, married and has three childen. He has his own shop near the market place in the town of Beylagan. He sells household items of different kinds. He has been engaged in this business since 2000. He is one of the best clients of Normicro Beylagan branch. He borrowed his first loan in 2004 in the amount of $600 to buy inventory. Then, after paying back the loan, he borrowed two more loans in 2005 and 2006. Thanks to these loans he gradually increased the volume of sales. Now he has applied for his next loan also to increase his inventory.

loans.use: To increase the number of inventories

loans.name: Veronique

texts.en: Veronique learned how to make jam from a development organisation in Kinshasa. She developed that knowledge and turned it into a business. With the money she raised from the jam business, a total of $300, she expanded her business by adding livestock such as a goat, pig, and some ducks before joining Hope’s Group (a Microfinance Institution in DRCongo) in 2004. From the proceeds from her livestock business, she opened a pharmacy. With Hope’s loans she bought a corn mill. Veronique’s business is developing considerably, and with a loan of $600 she will meet the high customer demand and generate additional profits. She has confronted and overcome many challenges with her business. That’s why she named her business “Long Story.” Veronique, born in 1950, is married and a mother of 10 children.

loans.use: To purchase medicines and goods in bulk.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Natig

texts.en: Natig is a resident of the town of Beylagan. He is 34 years old, married and has three children. He has a shop on the way to the local market where he sells carpets. He has been engaged in this business since 2001. He sells carpets of Azeri production and sometimes imports carpets from Istanbul or Dubai. In 2004, when he was going abroad, he applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed $600 to buy more goods in Istanbul. Later, he borrowed two more loans and increased his stock of carpets. As he is planning a new trip to Istanbul he has applied for $1200 to buy new models of carpets.

loans.use: To buy new models of carpets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Theo

texts.en: Theo operates a two, corn mill business. He started his business in 1998 with his own capital of $200. He is married and has two children. Due to the high customer demand in the community, with a loan of $550, Theo would be able to purchase a 30-horsepower mill, which is more powerful than the one he is currently using.  The more powerful mill will enable him to meet his clients’ needs and make additional profits. His current business capital is $2,200.

loans.use: To buy a 30-horsepower mill.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Nganda

texts.en: Nganda sells vegetable oil and lamp oil and general goods. She has been in business since 1995. Her beginning business capital was $45. With a loan of $700, Nganda wants to purchase ten containers of oil, boxes of tomatoes and other goods in order to meet her clients’ needs and generate additional profit. One of Nganda’s strategies to keep her clients is that she tells them in advance about any change that can occur in business. She is married and has ten children.

loans.use: To buy 10 containers of oil and other goods for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mazita

texts.en: Mazita S. was born in 1968. She is married and a mother of three children. She started her business in 2000, with a beginning business capital of $80 selling smoked fish. After she joined Hope’s Group (a DRCongo Microfinance Institution), her business developed. Her current business capital is $980. As the smoked fish demand is high in her community, with a loan of $800 Mazita will be able to meet the customer demand and generate additional profits.

loans.use: To buy big baskets of smoked fish for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Yusinjon

texts.en:
N. Esinjohn has been baking trditional bread for 16 years. He began to bake when he was 18 years old, as soon as he graduated from high school. At that time he helped his uncle and he learned to bake. Over time, he separated from his uncle and started his own business. Besides his wife and 3 children, he has his parents to support. His father is an invalid, a veteran of World War II of 1941 - 1945. His mother is pensioner too.

Until recently, income from production and cake sale were hardly enough to support his family. Additional means were necessary to expand his business and thus to improve their living conditions. In March 2006 he applied to MicroInvest and received his first loan in the amount of $150. Step-by-step, receiving new loans, he improved his business conditions. Now he needs $1000 to purchase coal, flour, oil and other necessary materials when it is cheap in in the summer. For example, coal costs now 1/2 as much as it does in winter. Besides this, he wants to repair and expand his premises.

loans.use: Purchase raw material, repair workplace

loans.name: Mimi

texts.en: Mimi sells meat and chickens. She started her business in 2003 with $10. Mimi is a hard-working woman who has demonstrated some abilities in business such as organisation and good management. Mimi is requesting a loan of $800 in order to meet the high demand for meat and chicken in her community. She is confident about her business. She knows how to attract her customers by offering what they need and like. She is also diplomatic when she talks with her clients. Mimi’s long-term plan is to open a clothing shop.

loans.use: To buy meat and chickens in bulk for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Faeziddin

texts.en:
B. Faeziddin has been baking traditional bread since childhood. He inherited this skill from his father and grandfather. His working day starts at 3 a.m. when he and his assistants begin to knead dough, form the bread, and heat the stove. For the first time, he kneads dough from 2 sacks of flour of 50 kg. each. The summer is an important period for his business, as citizens have many weddings and other family events. He needs to have a stock of flours and coal. A year ago, having received his first loan in the amount of $150, he renewed his supplies that he uses for cake baking.

The premises where he bakes is in his home, which is located far from the Isfara central market. That's why he plans to rent a place near the central market for working and storing the flour and other raw materials. Besides this, he wants to buy bicycle and small cart in order to deliver prepared bread to the market. For the realization of these plans he wants to receive $1000.

loans.use: Rent a shop; purchase raw material, bicycle and small cart

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his charcoal selling business

loans.name: Khasan

texts.en: Khasan is a Displaced Person from the occupied Lachin district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He started his business in 2002, and borrowed three Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1900. Now he is willing to borrow $1200 to increase his variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Noor Mohammad

texts.en: Nor Muhammad S/O F. M., has a butcher shop in District 8 of Kabul City. He has 5 years experience in this business. He is taking a loan to make his shop bigger and buy sheep, cows, goats, a meat grinder and other materials in his shop to support his family financially and make a better lives for them.

loans.use: Buying sheep, cows, and a grinding machine

loans.name: Mehman

texts.en: Mehman is a Displaced Person from the occupied Kelbadjar district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married, and has two children. He started his business in 1999, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2300. Now he is willing to borrow $1200 to increase his variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more metal stocks for his blacksmith business

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en:
This young woman, after graduating from school, could not find a job and had to go to the market for trade. First she helped her mother, who also traded in the district market. But as she had her own family, she decided to go into business independently. She has one child.

At first she sold only children's boots. It did not bring much profit, but it covered part of the family expenses. Having received her first loan from “MicroInvest” last year, she saw the possibility of expanding her assortment of goods. During the loan period, she increased the number of goods twice, improved the quality of goods and started to sell more expensive children's clothes. Nowadays she rents a place in the market, but she wants to have a larger place and expand her trade by adding woman clothes. For that purpose she needs $1000.

loans.use: Adding new types of goods

loans.name: Maliyka

texts.en: Maleyka is a Displaced Person from the occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is married, and has four children. She started her business in 1999, and borrowed three Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2300. Now she is willing to borrow $1200 to increase her variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase the materials he needs to start a cafe

loans.name: Rafail

texts.en: Rafail is a Displaced Person from the occupied Agdam district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married, and has four children. He started his business in 1994, and borrowed seven Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $5250. Now he is willing to borrow $1200 to increase his variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Rafiga

texts.en: Rafiga is a Deplaced Person from the occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is married, and has two children. She started her family business in 1994, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1900. Now she is willing to borrow $1200 to increase her variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Fazil

texts.en: Fazil is a Displaced Person from the occupied Agdam district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married, and has two children. He started his business in 2001, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $3500. Now he is willing to borrow $1200 to increase his variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Biamil

texts.en: Biamil is a Displaced Person from the occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married, and has two children. He started his business in 2003, and borrowed a loan of $300 from Normicro Baku branch. Now he is willing to borrow $500 to purchase more equipment.

loans.use: To increase the number of equipment

loans.name: Nazile

texts.en: Nazile is a Deplaced Person from the occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. She is married, and has two children. She started her business in 1997. She plans to borrow a loan of $1200 from Normicro Baku branch to purchase more computers.

loans.use: To increase the number of computers

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.en:
Mrs. Isabel decided to become independent so she installed a salon in one of the rooms of hour home. Thanks to her good work and charisma she's been able to maintain her clients. "Thank God I'm lucky with people and they keep recommending me. What I need is more furniture and equipment for the salon, I'd like your help with a $1,200 loan."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Isabel decidió independizarse e instaló su estética en un cuarto de su casa, gracias a su buena mano y carisma pudo mantener su clientela. "Gracias a dios tengo mucha suerte con la gente y me siguen recomendando, lo que me está haciendo falta es mas mobiliario y equipo de trabajo quisiera que me ayudaran con $1,200.00 dlls".

loans.use: To buy furniture and equipment for her salon.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz C. lives with her four young children in a small house, which she owns, in the Pasankeri zone, on the western slope of the city of La Paz. Her husband passed away in 2003, which is why Beatriz supports her family by working in a cereal factory. Beatriz’ house consists of one bedroom (which serves as bedroom and dining room for the whole family), a kitchen, and a bathroom. The purpose of the loan is to build another room, which would provide a minimum level of comfort for her family. This is the second time she has requested a loan with our institution, and her payment and punctuality show a good conduct with credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Beatriz C. vive con sus cuatro hijos menores de edad, en una pequeña casa de su propiedad en la zona Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz. Su esposo falleció el año 2003 por lo que la señora mantiene a la familia trabajando en una fabrica de cereales. La casa de la señora Beatriz C. cuenta solo con una habitación (que funciona como dormitorio y comedor para toda la familia), una cocina y un baño. El destino del crédito es para construir una habitación que pueda dar las condiciones mínimas de comodidad a su familia. Es la segunda ocasión que solicita un préstamo en nuestra institución, y su rendimiento y puntualidad demuestran un buen comportamiento crediticio.

loans.use: Construction of a new room in her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more groceries stocks for her grocery shop

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Joyce B. is a client of this organization. She sells various items in her locality from house to house. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina is a seamstress and she makes fabric hats. She is 41 years old and has two daughters, who, along with her husband, help her make the hats. This is a small family business, which is why they do not have any employees. Ernestina has been working in this business for more than 15 years. Her home and shop are located in the Llojeta-Tiwiña zone, one the western slope of the city of La Paz. She also has a stall on Isaac Tamayo Street in La Paz, where she sells hats by the dozen every morning. This is one of the city’s streets that gets a lot of traffic and is dominated by the informal sector. Her hat production is by the dozen, since she sells in bulk to her buyers, who then sell the hats individually; through her business, she indirectly generates several jobs.

This is the fifth loan Ernestina has obtained through IMPRO. Her history with our institution qualifies her as a Level 1 client, that is to say, Very Good in payment of her obligation. The amount requested will be used to buy fabric, thread, and burlap (jute) bags. Her work, experience, and the location of her stall give her the opportunity to obtain credit, which is why she is sure she will have the income to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Ernestina, es costurera y elabora sombreros de tela. Tiene 41 años y dos hijas, quienes junto a su esposa le ayudan en la elaboración de los sombreros. Este es el caso de una microempresa familiar por lo cual no cuenta con empleados. Tiene experiencia en el rubro por más de 15 años. Su Vivienda y Taller están ubicados en la zona de Llojeta-Tiwiña (ladera Oeste) de la ciudad de La Paz y tiene un puesto de venta por las mañanas a precio de docena en la C/ final Isaac Tamayo de la ciudad de La Paz, calle de comercio informal muy popular en esta ciudad. Sus producción y elaboración es por docena ya que en el puesto de venta es al por mayor para que sus compradores lo puedan vender al detalle, con esta actividad genera varios empleos indirectos Es la quinta vez que obtiene un crédito en Impro, Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 1, es decir con cumplimiento Muy Bueno en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de tela, forro hilo y bolsas de yute. Su trabajo, experiencia y ubicación de su puesto de venta le dan la oportunidad de obtener un crédito por lo cual le asegura los ingresos para el retorno de el crédito

loans.use: Working capital to buy materials with which to make hats

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Grace A. is a client of this organization. She sells used clothing in her locality from house to house. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Deborah N. (lady with the machine) is a client of this organization. She is a seamstress. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Federico

texts.en:
Federico lives in a rented house on Villamil de Rada Street in the Villa Nuevo Potosí zone, on the western slope of the city of La Paz. He is 43 years old and has a business making wallets from leather and leather-like vinyl. He has been working in this for more than 15 years and his wife helps him with the business. She is the one who sells the products on market days, which are Thursday and Friday, in the city of El Alto, on July 16th Street. This business gives him the opportunity to create jobs; in the making the wallets, Federico cuts the leather and assembles the wallets, while an employee sews them. The employee receives wages of 3 Bolivanos per piece, which is equivalent to $0.38. In addition to this employee, he employs two street vendors, who receive a percentage of their sales.

This is Federico’s first loan with IMPRO. According to the characteristics of the business and the evaluation that has been done, and the fact that he generates other jobs, it is considered that he will be able to fulfill this obligation. p> Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Federico vive en anticretico en la calle Villamil de Rada de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí (ladera oeste) de la ciudad de La Paz. Tiene 43 años de edad y se dedica a la confección de billeteras de cuero y cuerina; realiza este trabajo por más de 15 años, tiene la colaboración de la esposa que es la que vende el producto en las ferias de la ciudad de El Alto en la Av. 16 de julio los días jueves y viernes. Este trabajo le dá la posibilidad de creara fuentes de trabajo, asi en la confección de las billeteras, Federico realiza el cortado y armado y tiene un empleado que es el que se encarga de coser cada una, con un salario de BS. 3.- (Tres 00/100 Bolivianos) por pieza lo que equivale a $us.0.38 (Treinta ocho centavos de Dólar Americano), además de este empleado cuenta con dos vendedores ambulantes a quienes les paga en porcentaje por ventas. Este es su primer crédito en Impro, y por las características del negocio y la evaluación efectuada, además de ser una persona que genera empleo se considera que está en posibilidades de cumplir con la obligación contraída.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Grace H. (3rd from left) is a client of this organization. She sells used clothing in her locality from house to house. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan lives in his uncle’s house, which is located on San Cristóbal Street, in the Bajo Tacagua zone, on the western slope of the city of La Paz. He is 28 years old, married, and has three children. He works in the afternoons for a private television company, but his salary isn’t sufficient to support his family. For this reason he spends his morning making clothing, with help from his wife. They make jackets for other small businesses that subcontract such work. The requested loan will be used to buy a sewing machine so that Juan can do his work under better conditions. Because of his previous good loans with IMPRO, he can take out a new loan without any problems.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan vive en la casa de su tío ubicada en la C. San Cristóbal de la zona de Bajo Tacagua en la ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene 28 años de edad es casado y tiene 3 hijos. Por las tardes trabaja en una empresa privada de televisión, con un pequeño sueldo que le resulta insuficiente para mantener a su familia, por lo cual en las mañanas se dedica a coser prendas de vestir con el apoyo de su esposa, en especial chamarras, que le proporcionan otros microempresarios que se dedican a la confección de las mismas y subcontratan este servicio. El crédito solicita está destinado a la compra de una maquina de coser para efectuar su trabajo en mejores condiciones. Por sus antecedentes en Impro puede acceder a un nuevo crédito, sin problema alguno.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation, a local NGO based in Ghana, has been assisting women, especially in business, for quite a number of years now. Agnes N. O. is a client of this organization. She operates a retail shop where she sells various items. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her improve upon her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stocks of her used shoes business

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo lives in a rented house on Jaimes Freyre Avenue in the Tembladerani zone of the city of La Paz. She occupies two rooms, for which the monthly rent is 200 Bolivanos (the equivalent of approximately US $25.00). She is 25 years old and is a single mother. She works making cakes with her mother and her sister. She has been an IMPRO client since 2004, and with the financing that has been provided to her she has bought an oven and to date has been increasing her work materials by buying cake molds and other tools she needs. Because of her past good credit, it is entirely feasible to grant her a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

.Consuelo vive en alquiler en la Av. Jaimes Freyre de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz, ocupa dos habitaciones cuyo alquiler mensual es de Bs.200.-(equivalente a $us.25.- aproximadamente) Tiene 25 años de edad es madre soltera y se dedica a la elaboración de tortas junto con su mamá y hermana. Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2004, y con el financiamiento que se le ha dado ella se compró en un principio el horno y hasta la fecha va aumentando su material de trabajo comprando moldes, y otras herramientas que requiere para su trabajo. Por el antecedente histórico se considera factible otorgarle un nuevo crédito

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Jorgelina

texts.en:
