Jorgelina Cuadros is 47 years old and lives with her mother in a two bedroom house in the Alto San Pedro neighborhood of La Paz. She has worked as a cleaning lady at one of the companies in town for the past 11 years. Aside from the two bedrooms in her house, there is a bathroom and an unstable shed made from corrugated iron which they use as a kitchen. With the help of this loan, they wish to remove the shed and build a proper brick kitchen. This is the sixth loan Jorgelina Cuadros takes from our institution, but the first inteneded for home improvement. Her history with us shows that she will be able to pay back the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Jorgelina Cuadros tiene 47 años de edad, vive en compañía de su madre, en dos habitaciones ubicadas en la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz y es empleada de limpieza en una institución desde hace once años. En su vivienda cuentan con dos habitaciones, un baño y un ambiente precario construido con calaminas que le sirven de cocina y que, con la ayuda del crédito solicitado, quieren remover y construir en el lugar, una cocina de ladrillo. Es la sexta ocasión que la señora Jorgelina Cuadros obtiene un crédito en nuestra institución, pero la primera para mejorar la vivienda, su rendimiento en el pago de sus obligaciones muestran que puede cumplir con el presente crédito.

loans.use: Building a kitchen in her home

loans.name: Alisson

texts.en:
Alison is 19 years old and lives with her grandmother in a single room in 3 de Mayo street in the Villa Nuevo Potosí district of La Paz. She is a single mother of a 2 year old son. She works selling candy, cookies, and chocolates at the entrance to a school. This is her only source of income, which is why she needs more working capital. Her history with Impro makes her a feasible candidate for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Alison tiene 19 años vive en casa de su abuela en una sola habitación en la calle 3 de mayo de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz y es madre soltera, tiene un niño de 2 años Su actividad es de pequeña comerciante dedicada a la venta de dulces, galletas, chocolates en la puerta de un colegio. Esta actividad es su único medio de subsistencia por lo cual ella necesita aumentar su capital. Por el antecedente histórico que mantiene con Impro se considera factible otorgarle un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Increase her capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stocks of used children clothes stocks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase resources needed to expand her poultry business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase resources needed to start a catering service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her auto parts business

loans.name: Tho

texts.en: Tho is 62. Tho’s husband died a very long time ago. Now, Tho lives with her daughter, who is 40 and is single. It is difficult to imagine how they have overcome many problems in their life. They have no land aside from their home. Only the daughter can earn money by catching fish on a small canal of the Hau Giang River in the Mekong delta. Daily, the daughter has to spend much time catching fish on an old boat that isn’t safe. Their income is only $7 per person/month. They hope to get a loan of $75 so that they can purchase a small new boat that is safer and nets to continue catching fish on the canal. They are going to repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To purchase a small boat and net in order to continue catching fish

loans.name: Tania

texts.en:
Tania has a small caber cafe in the outskirts of Guayaquil, Ecuador. Hhe was able to start the businesss with the help of her parents. Tania and her sister mostly provide word processing services along with copies. There are not many businesses like this in the poor sectors of the city, but slowly the people are coming around to use them.

She hopes that she can take out a loan because she wants to improve on the physical appearance of the business. Right now, there is not a clear division between the cyber café and her parent’s home. She wants to build a wall and put in a door to establish the presence of her business.

loans.use: Make the space in her home more adequate for her word processing business.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Mr. S. has a cart where he sells a typical Ecuadorian food called Morocho. Morocho is made of corn, condensed milk, and cinnamon. He has been making morocho and running his business for a few years now, selling from about 3 pm until 10 pm. He hopes he can receive a loan because he is anxious to invest in a new cart. The cart he currently owns is not suitable for going out to busy streets where there are more clients. Mr. S. is married and has 2 children who are in school. His short term goals are to finish fixing his home and continuing to educate his children.

loans.use: Buy a new cart to sell morocho.

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.en:
Jacinto is a hard working farmer who grew up in Baba. He produces rice and corn on land given to him by his father, who, he still helps and work with. He lives with his girlfriend, who he hopes to marry and start a family with in the near future. He will invest the loan so he can plant for the next cycle by preparing the land, and buying fertilizer and seeds. He does not have children but is still very family oriented, as he is close to his mother, father and brothers. He hopes he can fix the lands so they can be productive for years to come.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by big large companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans, as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plough the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are no drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of products including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many of the loans will also go towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice and Corn Farming

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan has been working on this farm his entire life. He lives with his wife and 9 year old daughter, and helps his other two children who are grown up and independent. He relies completely on rice farming to feed his family, as his lands are only productive for this activity. He was born and raised in Baba and learned to farm rice from his father. He wants to make his land more productive by plowing them with rented machinery. In the long run, he wants to save for his daughter’s education.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Anzuelo Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their organization, El Anzuelo Asociacion, works cooperatively to help their members cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. Most recently, El Anzuelo was able to start a program that improved their members access to watering services..

The members of La Asociacion El Anzuelo de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.en:
Lorenza lives on a farm with her husband and her only child who is now 17. Together they all work to produce rice. She has lived in Baba her entire life and she has survived from her agricultural production. She hopes to take out a loan in order to buy fertilizer and pesticides that will help her nurture her crops. With the profits, she hopes to make some improvements to her home.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Progresista Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria V. D. V. is a single mother with five children - the oldest is 15 and the youngest is 7. They live in a barrio called La 41 in the municipality of Consuelo, about two hours northeast of the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo. She payed off her first loan from Esperanza after opening up a small grocery store that sold food and various household necessities.

This loan she is requesting will allow her to expand her business and increase her capital investments to become more self sustainable. Rosisert Reyes, Maria's loan adviser, says Maria had very little before she started her business. With this loan, her business will be more prosperous.

NOTE: This $850 loan will go to fund Maria's business, as well as four other businesses within her solidarity group. They have gone through Esperanza's business training program and will receive shares of this $850 loan to invest in their respective businesses and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be made. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the success and struggles of the other members in their group.

loans.use: Purchase, flour, sugar, dried milk, bread, gasoline, soap, butter, bread and sauses among various household items

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: Rosa lives in a farm with her son where work together to produce rice. She is a native of Baba, Ecuador where she learned to grow rice and plantains. On her land she is currently fully dedicated to growing rice, although she does have a small plot where grows soy. She hopes to take out a loan in order to buy fertilizer and pesticides that will help her nurture her crops. Also, she wants to hire a worker because she is no longer able to do the fieldwork herself. With the profits she hopes to make some improvements to her home which she will leave to her son some day.

loans.use: Farm rice

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela has three children and one adopted child. On her farm she plants rice and relies on this production to feed her family. She lives at home with one of her grandchildren, her daughter and, the adopted son. With the loan she will buy fertilizer and seeds for rice production. Angela suffers from kidney disease and must go through dialysis once a week for treatment. She hopes that she will be able to contract someone to help work her land so she can pay her medical expenses without bothering her children.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. loans.use: Fertilizer and seeds for rice farming

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela C. J. is the mother of two children and the owner of a small food stand in her rural neighborhood. Carmela travels to the Dominican capital to purchase products at resale value and sells them to the residents of her community. Her respected reputation among her neighbors and the essential products that she supplies have established her business as a mainstay in the small community market. Carmela is asking for this loan to expand her inventory from mainly household products and nonpreishable food items, to include fresh produce and poultry from, which she can purchase from the same markets that she currently buys from for her other items.

NOTE: Carmela is a member of a Bank of Hope solidarity group - made up of five micro-entrepreneurs who have gone through Esperanza's business training program and have proven to be in need of a loan as well as able to pay it back. Each member will receive a share of this $750 loan to develop their respective businesses and are responsible for making each loan repayment together, which fosters accountability as well as social support.

loans.use: Purchase food and beverages to stock her small grocery store.

loans.name: Janett

texts.en:
For eight years Janett has been selling household products in her community. She started off by just offering plastic ware, but now has expanded to other home products. She also has a secondary source of income where she hand makes dolls she is holding. She buys materials to make these toys in the city and then sells them to her friends and acquaintances.

Janett hopes to receive a loan because she wants to include a wider variety of products in her business. She sees a great opportunity to sell school items now that the new school year has started.

Janett has been seperated from her husband for a year. She is 24 year old and she has two daughters. Although he does not live with them, he is still very supportive and helps them out with money for school. Janett hopes to save enough herself so she can buy her own home. Currently she lives with her ex-husbands parents, developing a good relationship with them despite the differences with her ex-husband.

loans.use: Invest in household products to expand business.

loans.name: Dora Alicia

texts.en:
Mrs. M. has a grocery store in one of the most populous parts of the city. On weekends, many people come to the local craft fair and the population increases threefold. "Every weekend it's the same," she says. "So many people come to buy that I sell out. I just don't have enough to sell and that's why I want this loan for $1000."

Translated from Spanish by Alexis Hult, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. M. tiene una tienda de abarrotes en una de las colonias mas pobladas de la ciudad los fines de semana es tradición acudir a los tianguis que hay en ese sector y la población se triplica. "Cada fin de semana siempre es lo mismo se me termina la mercancía, es mucha la gente que viene y no les doy abasto, por eso quiero que me ayuden con $1,000.00 dlls".

loans.use: To buy goceries for resale.

loans.name: Aiga

texts.en: Aiga is a married mother of four. Her husband is an experienced designer and painter. He designs T-shirts and wraparounds sold at local stores that attract tourists, and she runs the business.

loans.use: Purchase of brushes, paints, and materials wholesale

loans.name: Asega

texts.en:
Asega O’Brien is a fisherman’s wife with five children. She participates in the business by pricing the fish and selling them at market. The family does not have a vehicle and relies on public transportation. She catches the early morning bus to take her fish to market.

She plans to spend the money she is borrowing from SBPD on fishing shoes and fishing equipment, such as fishing nets and coolers for storage. If the weather is good and the tide is calm, the fishing business will continue to prosper, and they will be able to meet their loan payments.

Asega envisions investing in a fishing boat in the near future.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing equipment and coolers

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy runs the only grocery store in her village, and her store is very successful. She works every day of the week because the village relies on her store. She sells basic wares such as mosquito coils, refrigerated goods, and dry goods. Members of Daisy’s family help her run the store.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for the store

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana F. is on her second loan with SPBD ($1250 total). She operates a handicrafts business, selling earrings, necklaces, and bracelets for ladies. She also sells hair accessories, make-up, and Samoan handicrafts. As Ana explained during her interview, her husband is a talented carver. Ana’s job is designing and decorating the items that her husband carves.

The handicrafts industry is lucrative and growing more important in the community. Ana feels fortunate that the raw materials she needs for her business, such as coconut shells, are freely available in the environment. The only supplies that Ana needs to buy are hooks, paints, brushes, and so on.

loans.use: Purchase of hooks, paint, brushes, string

loans.name: Epe

texts.en: Epenesa M. is an experienced artist working in elei, a traditional form of fabric printing. She designs uniforms for committees and companies. Her talent has made her famous in the village, and she is loyal to her clients.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, thread, and oil

loans.name: Soraida

texts.en:
Soraida lives in a rural community outside Consuelo with her husband and their five children. She runs her own small grocery store, known in the Dominican Republic as a colmadito. She used her first loan from Esperanza to start the business, which is now ready to expand.

Now that she has successfully paid off her first loan, Soraida is elligible for a second, larger loan that will help her to take the next step out of poverty. With five growing children to feed, clothe and put through school, Soraida is in need of expanding her business to increase profits so she can provide adequately for her family and save for their future.

Her plan is to invest in fresh produce and dairy products to round out the products that she offers, which currently are prepackaged household items, canned food and beverages. Soraida is determined to work hard and has recruited her husband to expand their family business to its full potential. With this loan of $300, she will have the funds to move forward in her business plan.

loans.use: Expand inventory to include fresh produce and dairy products

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa is a 56-year-old working mother who grows nonu (Indian mulberry) for a living. She sells the fruit to local merchants, who dry it and make juice out of it. Nonu is used in health cures and the treatment of numerous illnesses. Her earnings help her put her two youngest children through school.

loans.use: Purchase of string and fertilizer and salaries for laborers

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta is one of SPBD’s new members from the village of Faleula. Her idea was to start a small business making and selling sandwiches. Her customers include people in the village and the village school. Elisapeta is trying her best to make her business successful so that she can support her two children, whose father passed away two years ago.

loans.use: Purchase of eggs, canned spaghetti, tuna, bread, butter, mayonnaise

loans.name: Agina

texts.en: Agina is a happy mother of five children.  She works hard with her husband to manage a small banana plantation.  She helps her husband with planting and tending the plantation.  Agina also hauls their banana crop to the local market twice a week, where she is able to sell between 10 and 15 bags of bananas.  This brings in approximately ST 250 – 300 (about USD 100 – 120) and is the main source of income for this large family.  Agina is applying for a small loan to purchase fertilizer in hopes of increasing the yield of her small farm.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en:
Elisapeta is one of the old ladies in the Faleula Fou 4 Center. Despite her age, she works actively in the vegetable garden with the help of her husband. When the vegetables are ripe, Elisapeta and her children sell them to the village shops or at the market.

Fishing is another source of income for the family. Elisapeta’s sons are good fishermen who go out four days a week, depending on the weather. The fish are sold at the village near the road, or at the fish market.

Elisapeta decided that having two businesses was insurance against setbacks, such as a slow or low yield, or an illness that would prevent her sons from fishing for a week.

There are eleven people in Elisapeta’s family, and the sons don’t have permanent jobs. Through her two businesses, they generate revenue that helps cover family expenses and other faalavelaves (communal family events or obligations such as births, funerals, repairing or building a home).

loans.use: Purchase of vegetable seeds, fertilizer, fishing equipment, and tools

loans.name: Faagata

texts.en: Faagata has an exceptional talent for sewing. This talent is in high demand these days in Samoa. Because of the high cost of living, not everybody can afford  to buy dresses or clothes from shops.  Faagata specializes in T-shirts, uniforms, and traditional two-piece outfits (puletasis and muumuus). The 59-year-old caters mostly  to people in her village and works six days a week. Faagata has been sewing for the past 25-30 years.

loans.use: Purchase of materials such as thread, oil for sewing machine, fabric, and paint

loans.name: Faalua

texts.en: Faalua is in her fifties and an expert in elei, traditional Samoan fabric printing. She designs and prints elei with her children. Faalua is on her fourth loan, and she is still expanding her business. Faalua’s son attended art school,   and he is good at designing and cutting different patterns. His job is cutting the dress and shirt patterns, and Faalua designs and paints the sarongs. These designs can also be applied on men’s wear like alo’a (shirts) and ladies' wear like puletasi (formal female clothing). She can also create logos for organizations, companies and communities.

loans.use: To purchase paint, brushes, rolls of cotton materials

loans.name: Aivale

texts.en:
Aivale is married and has four children. She lives in the Samoan countryside, where she works a small taro plantation. Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet.

She is dedicated to working hard on her farm in order to help her family. Aivale takes her taro crop to market twice a week, and she can generally sell her supply and bring home the ST 300 – 400 (USD 120 – 160) that her large family lives on. A loan would enable Aivale to purchase some natural fertilizers, which could help her increase her crop yield.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese lives in the Samoan village of Tafitoala.  She is 51 years old and has raised ten children.  A previous SPBD loan helped Akenese expand her cattle farm, and the business income is now able to provide for the basic needs of her large family.  Her husband and children all take part in the farm work and help Akenese pour water and cut grass for the animals.  Akenese has been delighted with the recent growth in her cattle farm and is enthusiastic about investing further.  She is seeking a loan to buy equipment for her farm, such as fencing materials, bush knives, gloves, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese P. is a married mother of five.  Three of her children are still in school, but two have moved overseas to try to find work.  Determined to remain in Samoa and keep her three school-age children in school, Akenese supports her family by leveraging her weaving talent.  She weaves fine mats, those used on special Samoan occasions such as weddings.  It takes Akenese one to two months to complete a single mat.  When completed a fine Samoan mat can command high prices, up to ST 400 (USD 160).  Akenese is seeking a loan so that she can purchase more of the high quality raw materials for these special Samoan mats.

loans.use: Purchase of weaving supplies

loans.name: Alatupe

texts.en: Alatupe lives in a small Samoan village.  She is married and has six children.  She runs a small banana plantation.   The money she receives from selling 10 – 15 bags of bananas at the local market is the family’s main source of income.  Alatupe would use loan funds to purchase some basic supplies for her plantation to help make the work easier on her hands.

loans.use: Purchase of knives, gloves, and basic supplies

loans.name: Faamigi

texts.en:
For the past six years, Faamigi has made a living in elei, traditional fabric printing. With many years of experience, Faamigi has increased the number of her loyal customers, whose stores cater mainly to tourists. Her business is a success.

She works two days a week and purchases material from wholesalers at an affordable price. One of the best parts of her business is that after six years her sons are now the designers and printers. She creates mainly T-shirts and lavalavas.

loans.use: Purchase of paints and brushes; labor

loans.name: Faapaia

texts.en:
Faapaia counts the land she lives on as a blessing. The soil is suitable for planting taro and bananas and raising cattle, and they own a lot of acres. Faapaia’s husband used to work for the Agriculture department but is now running his own business with the help they received from SBPD. Faapaia joined the program because she wants to extend water pipelines and fencing that separates the cattle from the plantation.

They weren’t qualified to apply for a loan at the local banks. The cows they raise are useful for faalavelaves (family events and obligations) and can also be sold when their money supply is short.

loans.use: Purchase of salt licks for cattle, nails, hammer, roll of copper wire for fence

loans.name: Binh

texts.en: Mrs. Binh’s husband died of cancer 8 years ago. She is supporting 2 children by herself. Hien, her first child, stopped going to school and he works as a daily laborer. Loan, her second child, is in grade 10. Binh only has a little land planted with rice (about 3000 square meters) and some cashew nut trees around the house. The family’s income is low at $7/person/month. Mrs. Binh wants to borrow a loan of $75 so that she can buy fertilizer for the rice and cashew nut trees.

loans.use: buy fertilizer for rice and cashew nut trees

loans.name: Ami

texts.en: Ami is married and lives with her husband and three small children in a small Samoan village.  Ami had previously lived in New Zealand, but she was eager to return to her native country to raise her family.  To support her family in Samoa, Ami opened a small village store in the front of her house.  She has used previous loans to launch her store and keep it stocked.  Ami has a strong history of repaying those loans in full and on time, and so she qualifies for another loan.  Ami would again use this loan to purchase shop inventory.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise to re-stock shop

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is a single young woman who recently finished school.  She joined the SPBD program to launch her own business and achieve financial independence.  She wishes to run a business cultivating plant seeds and bulbs to sell to local vegetable farmers.  A loan will help her purchase some basic gardening tools and seeds to get her business underway.

loans.use: Purchase of gardening tools and seeds

loans.name: Fiapaipai

texts.en:
Fiapaipai G. comes from a family of highly educated people. But Fiapaipai herself is a different case altogether. She took art when she attended school. It was a hobby for her, and her favorite pastime was to create something or paint anything that she could get her hands on. When she was about to retire from work, she decided to start a business that would put her artistic talents to good use and at the same time generate income so that she could fend for herself.

Fiapaipai designs her own patterns and cuts her own designs. These designs feature mainly plant leaves and flowers such as the pua and Samoan mamanu. She used the money she received from SBPD to purchase paints, brushes, and cloth.

Fiapaipai’s husband passed away a long time ago, but she found the courage and determination to continue living. Even though her children are well employed, Pa’i does not rely on them for money. She will use the money she earns to continue living independently and repay her loans.

loans.use: Purchase of paint, brushes, materials

loans.name: Aolele

texts.en: Aolele is one of the first members of the SPBD Center in the Samoan village of Malie.  She is a hard-working, 62-year-old woman with five children.  Aolele operates a small shop in the front of her house.  Although Aolele had moved to New Zealand to seek a better life, she returned to Samoa some years ago and is passionate about remaining in her home country and finding a way to support her family in her small village.  Aolele has used micro-loans to build up her small shop, and these funds are key to allowing her to finance the expansion of her inventory.  Aolele can bring in revenues of ST 500 (USD 200) on a good day and works hard to translate that into a profit.  Every Friday, Aolele contributes to her steadily growing savings account.

loans.use: Purchase of shop inventory

loans.name: Fono

texts.en: Fono’s husband is a carpenter, but because it is a family tradition, he fishes after work. Fishing brings in extra money to improve the family's living conditions and meet other financial needs. Fono sells the fish in the road in front of her house every day of the week.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing nets

loans.name: Tuileva

texts.en: Tuileva is a married mother who knows exactly how to make children loosen up after a day at school. Popular with people of every age, ice-cakes are made from cordial mixed with sugar and other sweeteners and popped into the freezer. Especially good on hot days, ice-cakes are a nice change from ice-cream.

loans.use: Purchase of refrigerator

loans.name: Tua

texts.en: Tua is the mother of four school-age children. She operates a food stall and sells to the general public at the local market. She sells cakes and drinks. Her stall is open six days a week, and she realizes an average profit of 250 tala per week.

loans.use: Purchase of flour and flavoring for cakes and drinks

loans.name: Foai

texts.en:
When Foai heard about the SBPD program, she thought that it was a good opportunity for her and her family to get into fishing as a business and see whether they could achieve success. Foai is now operating a successful fishing business. Her husband goes out to sea to fish, and she sells the fish directly to the people in the village or at the fish market.

Foai’s family now has a fishing boat, which was financed by loans from SPBD. Her husband goes out to fish six days a week, if the weather permits. The least Foai realizes from her sales is never less than $600ST a week. Foai’s savings passbook shows that she saves more than the usual person in business.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing equipment and tools

loans.name: Eva Maria

texts.en:
Mrs Eva Maria is married and has two children, aged 7 and 2. Her husband is a baker and has worked for 8 years for a department store. His income is not enough to cover the family expenses. Therefore Eva, for the past 7 years, has been making and selling Tacos. She first stared helping one of her sisters and now has her own business, working from home.

Eva wants to move ahead and contribute more with the family expenses and provide a better education to her children. Eva now needs a loan of $200 to buy supplies to make the tacos and plans to repay the loan in 3 to 6 months. Your support can improve the standard of living of this family and help this business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Eva Maria es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos, de 7 y 2 años. Su esposo es panadero y trabaja desde hace ocho años en una tienda departamental, sin embargo, el ingreso que recibe no cubre todas las necesidades de su familia, por esta razón desde hace siete años Eva se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tacos, inició ayudándole a una de sus hermanas, pero desde hace cuatro años tiene su propio negocio, en su domicilio. Eva desea progresar y tener un ingreso extra para poder contribuir en los gastos familiares y otorgarles una buena educación a sus hijos. En estos momentos Eva necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 200 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los insumos que necesita para la elaboración de los tacos, mismo que planea devolver en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Tú puedes mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia y contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio, decídete a apoyarla.

loans.use: purchase supplies

loans.name: Savili

texts.en: Savili is a married mother of six who operates a lawn mowing business targeting locals and businesses that request assistance in mowing the lawn. Today, this business is highly in demand as more and more people in Samoa have decided to live by themselves instead of with their extended families. She is successful because she says she allows credit and also her fees are reasonable so she has many loyal clients.

loans.use: To buy a new weed eater

loans.name: Maria De Jesús

texts.en:
Since she was a kid, Mrs Maria de Jesus was involved with sales – her parents had a grocery store. When she got married, her husband’s income was not enough to cover all household expenses and she decided to start selling clothes and stationary. Maria’s husband passed away 2 years ago. She has seven children, all of them married, and lives with one of her grandsons, who is 18 years old and helps her in her business.

Maria needs $775 to buy merchandise and prepare for children’s day, mother’s day and the end of school break, when sales increase. Maria needs your support to grow her business and is grateful for any help you can give.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria de Jesús desde niña estaba relacionada con las ventas, sus papás tenían una tienda de abarrotes, ya casada, el ingreso que recibía su esposo era insuficiente para solventar los gastos del hogar, por lo que decidió iniciar con la venta de mercería y papelería. Hace dos años Maria quedó viuda, tiene siete hijos, ya todos están casados, actualmente vive con uno de sus nietos, de 18 años, que le ayuda a atender su negocio.

En estos momentos Maria necesita de un préstamo por $ 775 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para surtir su negocio y prepararse para las fechas del día del niño, de las madres y el regreso a clases que es cuando se incrementan las ventas. Ella necesita de tu ayuda para sacar adelante su negocio, y te agradece cualquier apoyo que puedas brindarle.

loans.use: surtir el negocio

loans.name: Folototo

texts.en: Folototo’s business is selling chips at the village primary school. Her husband earns $150ST ($55 USD) a week as a carpenter. She knew that her family could not depend on her husband’s salary alone to support them; therefore she looked at other means to generate more revenue for her family. She thought that a chips business was good business to start. After this loan, Folototo is planning to sell ice cakes along with her chips.

loans.use: to purchase flavoured cordials, plastic cups and bags, salt, dripping

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa has three children, and when her husband abandoned the family, she was left without income and no means to provide for her children.  She heard about the SPBD program from other women in her village and decided to join and start her own business.  With her small plot of family land, she was determined to show that not only men can be successful farmers.  With an initial loan, she bought some vegetable seeds.  Three months later, she had a vegetable crop and began selling her produce at the local markets.  Now she has an income stream that is larger than the income her husband had previously been able bring home.  Having repaid the first loan, Epenesa is eligible for a second loan.  She will use additional loan funds to purchase seeds and gardening tools.

loans.use: Buy seeds and gardening tools

loans.name: Faamamalu

texts.en: Faamamalu is a young married mother of three children.  In her backyard she has a vegetable garden that she faithfully tends to ensure that she can afford her children’s school fees.  She grows many different kinds of vegetables and takes them to the local market three times a week.  She can bring in approximately ST 150 – 200 (about USD 75) from these trips to the market.  Having repaid her initial loan in full, Faamamalu is now applying for a second loan to purchase additional seeds and bulbs to expand the variety of vegetables she grows.

loans.use: Buy seeds and bulbs

loans.name: Savili

texts.en: Baking has always been Savili’s first interest. So, when she became responsible for a family of ten, she decided to put her talent into action. Her four children are still attending school. Savili’s husband works six days a week while she tends to the baking from home. Two of her children  are working but their incomes cannot accommodate their growing family.

loans.use: To purchase flour, wheat, bananas, labor, and rent fee for stall

loans.name: Gogo

texts.en: Gogo S.’s business is making and selling ice cakes. These ice cakes are made up of cordial with Chinese lollies in it. Children really like them and this is one of the best ways to generate income for Gogo. Gogo’s mother runs a shop and this is where the ice cakes are sold. The cost is fifty cents for each ice cake; Gogo can also give you an extra for free if you will buy more than five ice cakes.

loans.use: To purchase chinese lollies, plactic cups & bags, cordial

loans.name: Faatietie

texts.en: Faatietie lives with her husband and four children in the small Samoan village of Malie.  She operates a small banana plantation.  Her banana trees are located very far from her house, so she must walk many miles each day to tend the plantation.  She hauls her banana crop to market twice a week.  There she is usually able to sell between ten and twenty bags of bananas and bring in revenues of ST 300 – 400 each week (approximately USD 120 – 160).  This income is the main income source for her large family, and she is committed to continuing to invest time and money into her plantation.  Thus, she has applied for a small loan to buy some basic equipment that will help her keep her plantation in good condition.

loans.use: Buy equipment: fencing, knives, and gloves

loans.name: Sauleola

texts.en: Sauleola is a married mother of two. The 50 year-old woman operates a popcorn business from her home and sells the popcorn to local schools and villagers. She has been in this line of business for the past four years, so she has a solid group of clients to whom she sells. Because she is so successful, she is building a store which will sell her popcorn and also cater to other needs and wants of local school children.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, oil, roofing iron and timber

loans.name: Fei

texts.en: Fei is a smiling, happy woman.  She is a mother of six.  Two of her children have moved overseas to find work, but Fei is happy living in Samoa and committed to remaining in her homeland and working hard to support the four children that remain in Samoa with her.  Fei makes flavoured ices (locally referred to as “ice cakes”) that she sells in her village.  She enjoys the work, and is applying for a loan to help her purchase bulk supplies of purified water, sugar and cordials to make her product.

loans.use: Supplies for making ice cakes

loans.name: Gustava

texts.en: Gustava was one of the first beneficiaries of South Pacific Business Development. Gustava sews a variety of clothing: women's Puletasi, men’s aloa, children’s wear and any other kind of clothing you want. Her sewing machine was a second-hand machine she bought when she got her first loan of $300. She sews clothes by order. If you provide your own material then Gustava will charge you less, but if you want to buy the finished product then you are charged the full amount. She also has her Banana Plantation, which is worked by her husband, to provide income to her family. Gustava is requesting a loan for her sewing business, and also for the banana plantation that her husband runs.

loans.use: To purchase materials, thread, needles, new sewing machine, fertilisers, bushknives, weed killer

loans.name: Filiga

texts.en: Filiga is a long-running and successful member of the SPBD Program in her small village.  She is married and has six children.  She runs a business selling cooked food in front of her house every Saturday.  Filiga bakes yams, taro, and bananas on hot stones and sells five pieces wrapped in foil for ST 5 (about USD 2) to local villagers.  Each Saturday, she is able to bring in revenues of about ST 100 – 200 (about USD 40 – 80).  She is confident in the demand for her product, and she would use an additional loan to buy ingredients and food packaging.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and packaging

loans.name: Salevao

texts.en: Salevao is a married mother of five whose long time passion and talent is sewing. To help her family financially, Salevao decided to turn her talent into a business investment and she caters to people in her village. She works full-time sewing. She sews t-shirts, collared shirts and school uniforms.

loans.use: To purchase electric sewing machine

loans.name: Foini

texts.en: Foini recounts the story of her and her husband’s taro plantation:  Her family had always relied on remittances from sisters and brothers overseas for income.  But three years ago, she and her husband became determined to stop depending on the money their family sent.  They started planting taro in their backyard as a way to earn their own independent income and support their children.  Foini is applying for a loan to help support the growth of her plantation.  Already she and her husband are able to sell three to four bags of taro at the local Fugalei Market twice each week.  Their hard work brings them a weekly income of ST 250 – 300 (approximately USD 100 – 120), which allows them to provide independently for the basic necessities of their large family.

loans.use: Buy equipment: fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Iloga

texts.en: Iloga is 33 years old and is married with two children.  Her husband has a job in town, but his wages aren’t enough to provide for the family.  She applied for a loan from SPBD in order to purchase the materials she needs to start an “ice cake” business.  She sells these flavored ices to the locals in her village.  These treats are especially popular with the children at the primary school.  She is able to earn approximately ST 20 – 30 (about USD 8 – 12) each day.  This is a valuable supplement to the family’s income.  Iloga will use additional loan funds to buy more supplies for making ice cakes, such as purified water, sugar and cordials.

loans.use: Buy purified water, sugar, cordials

loans.name: Pulega

texts.en: Pulega is a mother of three who started her own pineapple plantation. When she was younger, she worked happily on her family's farm, which is what led her to start her own plantation. She now sells the pineapples she grows to earn a living for her family. Pulega also enjoys her work as she follows in her father's and mother's footsteps.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay for labor

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta is a mother of two and lives with her children and husband in the small Samoan village of Saleaumua. She said that her family had always relied on the intermittent generosity of overseas relatives sending remittances back to Samoa.  Without a reliable, independent income stream, Imelta joined the SPBD program in 2005 in order to gain access to capital to start a small taro plantation.  Imelata invests most of her time and money back into her farming venture, so that she can support her family independently and build a better life for her two small children in Samoa.

loans.use: Buy equipment: fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Isu

texts.en: Isu P.’s family is not well off. They struggle to find things or beg other neighbors for necessities to survive. When Isu heard about our program, she decided to use the opportunity given by the SPBD program to provide financial assistance for her and her family. She used her skills in baking and selling her Samoan pastries (faapapa) to the local people. She focuses on baking a traditional Samoan pastry made of sugar, flour and a mixture of ripe bananas. The mixed ingredients are baked in the traditional Samoan oven. Isu walks around the village to sell her cooked pastries until they are all sold out. Finding her idea to be a success, Isu is looking forward to buying a second hand oven to bake on instead of going through the long process of baking her pastries in a traditional Samoan oven.

loans.use: to purchase a second hand oven

loans.name: Laveaina

texts.en: Laveaina is a mother of three children.  She lives with her children and husband in a small village in Samoa.  Laveaina tends a small taro plantation two meters from her house. Laveaiana joined the SPBD Program to apply for a loan to help her buy some basic equipment for her plantation that will help her repair fences and make the work easier on her hands (bush knives and gloves).  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet and so her plantation both feeds her family and provides the family their main source of income.  She can sell three to four bags of taro twice a week at the local market.  With this income, it still remains a struggle to support her family, but Laveaina feels the best way to raise her family’s standard of living is to invest in their taro farm.

loans.use: Buy equipment:  fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Patosina

texts.en: Patosina is a farmer who has survived and developed her family’s status in life and financially by working six days a week on their family plantation. The plantation provides income to accommodate her growing family. She sells her crops to neighbors and caters to near by villages.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, stings and seeds

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en: Jenny uses the land around her house to plant and grow bananas and taros. She lives in Sinamoga, which is a larger town, so she has to make good use of the land around her home. Fertilizers are the main food for the land and help to increase the harvest yield; Jenny knows the right time to apply them. Jenny’s husband takes the crops they grow to the market to be sold when they are harvested. Jenny’s husband also works, and provides extra money for the family. Jenny also works on her plantation with the help of her father.

loans.use: to purchase fertilisers, taro roots, bushknives

loans.name: Leaga

texts.en: Leaga is a strong, happy mother of five children.  She lives with her family in a small Samoan village.  Leaga bakes foods on hot stones at her house, and she takes the cooked foods to sell at the market three days a week.  Leaga bakes Samoan favorites, including taro leaves in coconut cream.  Leaga’s food sales bring in about about USD 60 – 80 a week.  This income is crucial to support her large family, especially to keep current with her children’s school fees and supplies.

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients and supplies

loans.name: Pai

texts.en: Pai has a family of 14 people. However, only two of this big family work, so there is hardly enough income to cater to all of them. But, with her canteen business, Pai is able to accommodate all of those that are not working. She caters to the local school and has ten years experience in this line of work. She also sells to the people in the village. She sells drinks, twisties, cooked sausages and other tasty food normally sold in a canteen. She works five days a week from Monday to Friday.

loans.use: To purchase flour, rent for stall, boxes, sausages, cordial, sugar, bread, boxes of mayonnaise, butter

loans.name: Joanne

texts.en: Joanne’s business is selling plates of food in front of Yasaki Compound. She chose this location because of its strong sales potential. She is located at the front gate of the Compound. When the employees of the company have their lunch break, she is one of the sellers from which they buy their lunch. On one plate, Joanne sells one chicken leg with sausage, two bananas, curry and some salads of cucumbers and sauce. This is usually sold at lunchtime and she generally sells out. Joanne is one the newest members of the programme. This is her first time running her own business.

loans.use: chicken leg quartes, sausages, bananas, tomato sauce, plates

loans.name: Lemafoe

texts.en: In the tiny villages along the Samoan coastline, there remains a market for home-grown Samoan tobacco.  Lemafoe knows that she can make a decent income from raising and selling this native plant in the local markets.  With hard work, she can bring in revenues of up to ST 60 – 70 per day (approximately USD 25).  With this income, it remains a struggle to support her six children and keep them in school, but Lemafoe is confident that with hard work and access to micro-loan facilities, she can continue to grow her family’s income and raise their standard of living.

loans.use: Buy farming equipment: spades, gloves, hoes

loans.name: Moira

texts.en: Moira is from the village of Faleula, which is located along the coast of the island. This is one of the main reasons her business is fishing. She needs the loan to purchase more materials to upgrade her fishing business. She needs to purchase a new fishing boat to meet the high demand in this line of business. Moira sells her catch at the Fish Market in the heart of the capital of Upolu, and on less profitable days, she sells them to neighboring villagers.

loans.use: To purchase materials for fishing boat and nets

loans.name: Lesina

texts.en: Lesina is a married mother of three children.  She is from the small village of Sauano Fagaloa, very far from town. She was employed at the Ministry of Health, but her enterprising spirit led her to resign two years ago in order to launch a lawn-mowing business.  Lesina says, “We women should not rely only on what our husband does.  We have to do something better, for our families and for the future of our kids.”  She used an initial loan to launch her business with two secondhand lawn mowers, but she is now applying for another loan to buy additional, upgraded equipment.

loans.use: Upgraded lawn-mowing equipment

loans.name: Kimi

texts.en: Kimi M.’s business is selling ice pops, and her customers are the schoolchildren and the village people. Kimi’s income comes from selling these ice pops, and she also sells chips on the side when she is able. She charges fifty cents for an ice pop and one dollar for the chips. Kimi also brings her ice pops to the center meeting and sells them to the women at the time of the meeting. The freezer is too small for both the ice pops and other things, so she would like to purchase a bigger one. Kimi also wants to run a BBQ in front of her house beside the road together with her ice pops.

loans.use: freezer

loans.name: Lisa

texts.en: Lisa is a married mother of four children.  Her main source of income is selling cooked foods, snacks and drinks at a canteen at the local village primary school.  An initial loan helped finance the start-up of this business, and Lisa has found that her canteen is very lucrative.  Her family is very supportive of her efforts and appreciative of the extra income, so she continues to expand her small stand. In order to purchase additional products to sell, she has applied for another small loan to help her expand her product line.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and packaged foods for resale

loans.name: Lily

texts.en: Lily P.’s husband is good at fixing car engines and motor vehicles of any kind. She is helping to support her husband by providing financial support for him. This is Lily’s business. The loan she gets from SBPD is for their business together, and the money she gets to repay the loan is from her husband.

loans.use: But tools

loans.name: Malelega

texts.en: Malelega runs a flea market stall in Samoa’s main market.  Her husband and five children remain in a small village far from town, where her husband works on crafting many of the goods that she sells in her flea market stall.  Malelega sells the traditional Samoan handicrafts made by her husband and others both to locals and to tourists looking for souvenirs.  A loan would help Malelega purchase raw materials for her husband’s crafts as well as purchase goods from others to resell at her flea market stall.

loans.use: Buy basic supplies, e.g., knives, gloves, packaging

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is 39 years old.  She is a veteran of the SPBD program and is very active in her local center.  One main motivator for Maria to join the program was the goal of keeping current with her children’s school fees and buying them their school supplies.  She has used two previous SPBD loans to finance an expansion of her small shop’s inventory.  With an outstanding history of on-time and in-full loan repayments, Maria now qualifies for a third loan.  Again, she will use this loan to finance the purchase of more merchandise for her shop.  Maria is committed to ensuring that her local customers remain satisfied and are able to get all their basic shopping done within this small village.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale in her shop

loans.name: Dao

texts.en: Mrs. An has a child and must support her mother and her sister. Mrs. An’s mother is 78 years old and Dao, her sister, is mentally retarded. The family only has about 3000 square meters of land planted with rice, but the land is very poor and far from her home, so An has rented 2000 square meters to somebody and keeps 1000 square meters to plant rice. The family’s living depends on Mrs An’s business of buying waste materials from door to door and then selling it to the local recycling company. However, she does not have enough capital to buy much waste material so that she can earn more. Average income is low at $8/person/month. An wants to borrow a loan of $25, and she promises she will repay per month.

loans.use: buy & sell waste materials

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: “The more you plant the more you get” – that’s Maria’s motto.  Taro farming is hard work, and when her husband begs off of working on the plantation, Maria keeps her motto in mind and walks the many miles to her farm to tend her taro plants.  She hauls her taro to market twice a week and is usually able to sell the bulk of her supply.  Her hard work earns up to ST 300 – 400 (approximately USD 120 – 160) a week for her family.  As the committed farmer in the family, Maria joined the SPBD program to keep reinvesting in her farm and keep the land, equipment and plants in good condition.

loans.use: Buy fertilizers, knives, taro plants

loans.name: Toan

texts.en: Toan is 38. Her husband is Huy, 40. They have one daughter and 2 sons between 10 and 16. They don’t have any land for cultivation, so it is difficult for their family to earn a living. However, their children go to school. Huy, her husband is a daily laborer, but the work is not stable. Selling soya-milk for breakfast is therefore important for them, increasing their very small income about $8/person/month. She wants to borrow a loan of $50 so that she can buy an amount of soya with cash so that it is cheaper.

loans.use: selling soya-milk for breakfast

loans.name: Logitu

texts.en:
Logitu is one of the veteran members in the program. She started with a pancake business, but now has a general store at the front of her house. The shop was financed and planned when she started in the SPBD program. The idea came from her eldest son: He knows that she is not suited for doing any home duties such as grass weeding, so he decided to run a shop, and Logitu is responsible for looking after it.

The shop is open seven days a week, from six o'clock in the morning to ten at night. The maximum profit that she can earn a week is between 500 and 1000 ST (USD180-360). This money is then used to buy goods for the shop, and what is left goes for her savings and the loan payment.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to stock the shop

loans.name: Maseiga

texts.en: Masiega is 67 years old.  She still helps tend her family’s vegetable garden, and she is the one who takes the vegetables to market three days a week and is adept at negotiating good prices.  Far from relying on her children for support, Masiega is able to contribute meaningfully to the family income, and she is proud of her efforts.  A loan to Masiega will help her purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Loretta

texts.en: Loretta is a healthy lady because she likes to eat fruits and vegetables. She grows lots of fruit at the back of her house, but mostly pineapples, which are grown in rows. Tending her garden takes up most of Loretta's time each day. When the fruit is ripe, she will spend the whole day at the market selling it. Her loan will enable her to purchase gardening tools.

loans.use: To purchase gardening tools

loans.name: Mataomanu

texts.en:
Mataomanu is a married mother of six children. While her husband has a steady job, Mataomanu feels strongly about being financially independent and does not want to rely on her husband for money.

She says she only asks her husband for money if she needs it to finance her business.

Mataomanu is passionate about keeping her business strong. With her flea market stall, she can bring in revenue up to ST 250 (about USD 100) on a good day.

With this income stream, she is able to provide for most of the household needs and still work on growing her savings account balance. A loan to Mataomanu would help her finance new inventory to sell at her flea market stall.

loans.use: Buy merchandise and handicrafts to resell at flea market stall.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann S. is 31 years old and works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  She earns $2/day and her husband, Ros Vannak, earns $5/day working in construction.  They have two young children that are both able to go to school full-time.  Vann S. and her husband will use this loan to buy some construction tools for his business.  Ros Vannak is trying to move up from a wage worker, to a construction manager.  With the new tools, they will be able to start a small construction business that employs some workers.  If this business is successful, Vann S. would like to pay for her children to go to high school.

loans.use: To buy construction tools

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva P. is a single woman living in the small Samoan village of Vaipuna. She joined the SPBD program last year right after completing school.

Passionate about being financially independent, she manages her mother’s small village store and is applying for a small loan so she can restock the shop’s shelves and finance an expansion of their product line.

The shop brings in about ST 350 – 400 (approximately USD 150) in revenue a week for her and her mother. Minerva feels that this is a solid income stream worth investing in and that with diligence she can grow it further.

loans.use: Buy goods for her shop

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Thy L. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 2 children.  She works at a local organization teaching people how to become tailors.  She earns $5 at this trade, while her husband makes $7 driving a tuk-tuk (motortaxi-type vehicle) that he rents daily.  Thy L. will use this loan to buy a tuk tuk and motorcycle for their family to own so they don't have to face the day-to-day rental fees.  In the future, Thy L. hopes to buy one more tuk-tuk to rent out and to send her children to university.

loans.use: To purchase a tuk-tuk trailer and a new motorbike.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria K.’s business is her pineapple garden beside her house.

This is one of the sweetest fruits in Samoa, and most people from overseas like it. These pineapples, when they are ripe, are sold at the market, and people usually use them for salads.

As you can see in the picture, Maria plants these pineapples in rows so they are easy to collect when they are ripe.

Instead of planting taro and taamu beside the house, Maria prefers to grow pineapples, which can be sold or even used by the family when it’s needed.

Instead of using a stick to dig in the ground, Maria is looking for a machine to dig with to grow her pineapples.

loans.use: To purchase more tools, such as bushknives, spades and gloves

loans.name: Toeun

texts.en: Toeun S. is 40 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 4 children.  She feeds the family's animals, but does not make any profit from the animals until they are mature and can be sold to the market.  Her husband is a construction worker and a member of staff at a private company.  3 of their children work at a garment factory and 1 is a student.  Together, the household income is $20/day.  Toeun S. will use this loan to buy long pieces of bamboo for use as construction scaffolding.  With this new equipment, her husband can become a more self-sustaining construction manager.  They will also use it in the future to build their new house.

loans.use: To buy long pieces of bamboo to use for scaffolding

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Toeun Sin has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Miriama

texts.en:
Miriama is a married mother of one child. She was formerly employed at one of the government’s offices, but her entrepreneurial spirit and desire for independence led her to resign from her post and start her own business.

She now runs a small store in front of her house and reports being happier now that she is master of her own financial destiny.

She can earn up to ST 300 - 400 (USD 120 – 160) each week. She is applying for a loan to purchase more inventory to stock her shop.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Moana

texts.en:
Moana freely expresses how privileged she feels to be able to be not just a mother of four children but also a businesswoman.

She and her husband run a small vegetable farm on their land. The income that the vegetables bring in is their sole source of income.

Her husband does most of the farm work, while Moana is the one who hauls the produce to the market and sells it.

She feels the best way for them to raise their standard of living is to invest further in their vegetable farming. Thus, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer to improve their crop yield, which, hopefully, will lead directly to a boost in income.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria L. is one of the active and hard-working members of the Faleula fou Centre.

She buys corn seeds from the shop and cooks them. She then packs them in plastic bags, and they are sold for one dollar each. This is one of the children’s favorite foods, and she delivers it around the village and at school.

Maria is using her cooking pot to cook her popcorn, and she is looking for easier ways of doing it. This is why Maria is good at paying her loans, because she is still working on producing more supplies for her business.

loans.use: Popcorn popper

loans.name: Maselina

texts.en:
Maselina is a teenage mother of three children. She runs her business at the flea market at Apia.

She makes porkbuns and mixes drinks to be sold. This is a good location, and she doesn’t need to search for customers because they are always there.

Maselina’s husband does not work, and he is the one who really supports her in doing the business. So when it’s time for Maselina to go to the Center meeting or when she is sick, her husband runs the business.

This is the usual place for all Samoan schoolchildren to gather together to have their last meal of the day before they go home.

loans.use: To purchase cordials, plastic cups, mutton flaps, onions, soy sauce, flour and sugar

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Chin V. is a 60 year old widow with 4 children.  She also has 4 nieces and nephews that live with her, making the total household size 9 people.  Two of her children are mototaxi drivers, and she would like to use this loan to buy a new mototaxi for her nephew to drive.  Once the household gathers enough savings from the new mototaxi, Chin V. will build a small coffee shop (seriously lacking these in Phnom Penh!).  She is confident that the shop will earn her family enough money so that all the children may complete university.

loans.use: To buy a mototaxi and wood to build a new coffee shop

loans.name: Ripena

texts.en:
Ripena is married and lives with her husband and four children in a small Samoan village. Her family relies on their small taro plantation for income.

Ripena’s husband does most of the farming, but Ripena is the one to haul their taro crop to market and ensure they receive good prices. She can earn enough money to support the basic needs of her family and pay for her children’s schooling.

However, she is anxious to raise her family’s standard of living further and is applying for a loan to invest in some fertilizer and basic tools to help improve the crop yield from their small plot of land.

loans.use: Buy chemicals, fertilizer and knives

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en:
Matalena A. is in her active years, and her business is making and selling fast food.

Yasaki Samoa Company Limited is the number one industry that employs lots of Samoan people. This is the best place where most of the ladies with this kind of business prefer to sell their food because it’s good.

Matalena is one of those ladies, and she sells food for five dollars a plate.

Matalena is a mother of four children, and this is the source of money to finance their school and family activities.

loans.use: To buy chicken leg quarters, onions, peppers, sausages, bananas, plastic plates, tomato sauce, soy sauce and cucumbers.

loans.name: Roine

texts.en:
Roine L. is a young mother of two, and she lives with her husband in the small Samoan village of Siuniu Falealili.

She believes in her and her husband’s farming abilities, and they manage a 10-acre taro plantation together.

Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and so when Roine takes their crop to market twice a week, she is usually able to sell her full supply for about ST 300 (approximately USD 120).

She is anxious to invest further in their farming enterprise, and so she has applied for a loan to buy some fertilizer to improve their crop yield. Roine also wants to use part of the loan funds to repair the damaged floor of her house.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and make home improvements

loans.name: Chu

texts.en: Chu H. is a 57 year old English teacher in Phnom Penh.  He earns $7/day teaching English, and lives with his 51 year old wife and their 3 children.  Two of his children are students, and one works in a garment factory to supplement her father's income.  Chu H. will use this loan to help buy the wood he needs to build their new house.  His steady stream of income will make repaying the loan easy for him.  In the future, he'd like to see his children graduate from university.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a new house.

In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time.
