Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Mativa

texts.en:
Mativa S.’s business is lawn mowing.

When she started in the SPBD program, she started to buy secondhand lawn mowers and started to run her lawn mowing business. Mativa now has three lawnmowers, and she is still looking for more.

Her business depends on people’s requests for lawn mowing. So when a family needs its grass mown, then Mativa will work for them. She gets paid at the same time once the job is complete. She charges different rates depending on how large the job is.

There are only three employees: Mativa, the husband and the son. Mativa has usual customers arranged every week so she gets almost $500 a week.

loans.use: To buy new lawnmowers

loans.name: Senila

texts.en:
Senila is 34 years old and is married with three children.

Senila operates a stall at the local flea market. She purchases jewelry and traditional wares from local Samoan handicraft artists and sells them at her stall.

The income from the flea market stall is critical to keeping current with her children’s school fees and purchasing their uniforms and school supplies. She is passionate about keeping high quality items in supply for both local customers and tourists.

Senila will use loan funds to purchase additional inventory for her stall.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for flea market stall

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Chum S. is seeking a loan to buy wood and cement for the construction of his new home.  He lives in Phnom Penh and works as a mototaxi driver and earns $5/day.  His wife (pictured here), Hak Sopha is 43 and sells shoes at the local market, earning $4 profit/day.  They have 3 children and 1 nephew who also lives with them, and they are now seeking better housing for their family.  The new home will also be used as a small grocery shop, and should generate enough income to continue sending their children to school.

loans.use: To buy wood and cement to build a home.

loans.name: Sieraseta

texts.en:
Sieraseta has been a member of the SPBD Program for two years. She is married and has two children.

Although her husband is a policeman and earns a steady income, Sieraseta still works hard to bring in the extra income that can raise her family’s standard of living and provide her children a good education.

She knows how to weave in the traditional Samoan fashion, and she leverages this talent to weave mats and bags and other items. She spends the bulk of her days at the flea market selling her products. Locals and tourists alike buy her wares.

Loaning funds to Sieraseta would help her purchase raw materials for weaving.

loans.use: Buy materials for making traditional Samoan handicrafts

loans.name: Moegau

texts.en:
Moegau is living on the far end of the island of Upolu, and she is running a different kind of business from all the other ladies at the Center.

Moegau owns thirty cows, and they are kept in a fence so that they won’t go out. These cows are for family "faalavelaves" (family events, such as weddings and funerals) and for special occasions.

This is the most expensive and most worthy animal in the "faasamoa" (a word that refers to the Samoan way of life). The cheapest price for a cow based on size is $500 for the small cow.

Moegau’s family is going to be one of the good families in the future if this business continues.

loans.use: To purchase nails, a hammer, copper wire, salt for the cattle and animal feed

loans.name: Sofai

texts.en:
Sofai is married and has four children.

She is passionate about ensuring all of her children can receive a good education, and so she spends most of her days at the flea market selling products she is able to raise or make at home.

One of Sofai’s children is just 3 months old, and Sofai brings the baby with her to the market every day. She sells vegetables as well as Samoan coconut oil at her stand.

loans.use: Buy chemicals, fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Oka

texts.en: Oka T. sells tugane at the front of her house and beside one of the busiest main roads near the town area. This sea creature is found near the shore, and usually women are the ones to collect them. This is Oka’s first job of the day. When the sun starts to rise, Oka gathers her fishing baskets together and walks straight into the sea. She sells the tugane in plastic bags, and it’s about five tala per bag. She plans to use the loan for more plastic bags and fishing gear.

loans.use: plastic bags, fishing gear

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Um P. is a local doctor in Phnom Penh, and earns $20/day.  His wife, 4 children, and mother all live with him.  Um P. would like to use this loan to buy land which he will rent out.  He is seeking to transition from a doctor to a businessman that buys and sells land and other assets.  With this new income, he would like to send his children to study at a top Cambodian university.

loans.use: To buy land

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Um Phovhas repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Teina

texts.en: Teina M. is a mother of five children and lives in the Samoan countryside far from town.  She has a talent for weaving and weaves traditional Samoan mats.  She weaves the fine mats that are used in special Samoan celebrations, such as weddings.  Traditionally in Samoa, all women knew how to weave, but now Teina is a rarity.  There is a strong market for her mats, and although it is very time-consuming and difficult work, she is able to sell these fine mats for good prices.  Teina invests the time and diligence in her weaving in order to preserve the traditional Samoan craft and to provide for her large family. She plans to use the loan to buy weaving materials.

loans.use: Buy weaving materials

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive M. sells her pancakes at her house or even delivers them to the school. Olive works five days per week, and she can earn $100 a day. This is her source of income to support her family. The money she gets for the week is then used to buy other bags of flour and sugar for the next order. She is a good saver; this is how she finances her children’s school activities. She plans to use the loan to purchase more ingredients to make the pancakes.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, baking powder, dripping

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim S. is 35 years old and works in a garment factory making $2/day.  Her husband (pictured here) makes $7/day driving a mototaxi in Phnom Penh.  They have 4 young children that live with them and go to school.  Kim S. will use this loan to build a home that she can rent to factory workers.  She hopes that this new business will allow her to stop working at the garment factory and give her greater daily income.  Her husband would like to start earning more money by driving his motobike, but also by working as a mechanic.  After they pay off this loan, they plan on taking out another loan to build another house for rental.

loans.use: To build a house for rent

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich T. and his wife (pictured here) own a small rice and Khmer food restaurant in Phnom Penh.  He has 6 children that all work with him at the restaurant--1 as the chef and the other 5 as servers and busboys.  With this loan, he will buy more food supplies, as well as decorations to make his restaurant more pleasant.  In the future, Pich T. would like to buy a clothes store at the market for his children to work at after they graduate from university.

loans.use: To buy food for his business

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia T. is 52 years old and a mother of three.  Her husband died six years ago, leaving her without income.  As none of her children have steady employment, Telesia must strive for financial independence to survive.  She grows cocoa and sells roasted, ground cocoa at local markets.  Cocoa grows well in Samoa and is prized for its unique flavor.  Telesia will use loan funds to buy some basic supplies to make her difficult work more productive.  Telesia’s current cocoa sales bring her approximately ST 50 – 60 (about USD 20) a week, and she is anxious to invest in some time-saving equipment that will allow her to bring more cocoa to the market.

loans.use: Buy basic supplies, e.g. knives, gloves, packaging

loans.name: Nat

texts.en: Nat operates a taxi which runs everyday of the week and earns between 200 and 400 tala per day. (1 tala = $0.35 US dollars). The taxi is the main source of income for the family, and Nat needs finance to purchase spare tires for the taxi.

loans.use: To purchase tires

loans.name: Oloniu

texts.en: Oloniu is the secretary of Aleisa C and one of the active members in the Aleisa Center. Oloniu’s business is weaving fine mats, and she also runs a shop at the front of her house. These fine mats are used for faalavelave and for many of Samoan special occasions such as funerals and weddings. The mats (Ie Sina or Ie Toga) in the Samoan way of life (faasamoa) are one of the treasured goods of the Samoan people, and they are expensive in price. Oloniu's weaving business is the substitute for the shop in case cash flow is slow. Oloniu is looking at ways of marketing her fine mats overseas, and she is confident that the money from her business will be worthwhile.

loans.use: To buy feathers, paint, and weaving equipments

loans.name: Tetee

texts.en: Tetee is a married mother of four, and she lives with her husband and children in a small Samoan village.  Tetee joined SPBD to help enlarge the canteen she operates, where she sells baked taro, yams and bananas.  Tetee bakes the fruits and vegetables on hot stones at her home and sells the food to local villagers.  Having repaid her first loan, Tetee is eligible for a second loan and will use these funds to purchase ingredients and some basic cooking supplies.  Tetee is passionate about keeping her children in school and is anxious to invest in her business to ensure she can reach that goal.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and cooking supplies

loans.name: Moli

texts.en: Moli is a mother who uses her taro patch well by turning the taro into chips and selling it to earn a living for her family. She caters to local schools and to the village people. Her loan will be used to purchase more materials for her taro chips business.

loans.use: To purchase oil, knives, fertilizers, oven

loans.name: Id

texts.en: Mr. Id P. works as a private driver in Phnom Penh, earning an average of $5/day.  His wife (pictured here) and their 4 children live together with him in Phnom Penh.  All members of the family work, and their combined household income is about $12/day.  This loan will be used to help buy a car so Id P. doesn't have to spend money renting one daily.  In the future, he plans on being a driver, as the ownership of the car will give him significantly more income.  He also hopes to build a house for rent, which will eventually be given to his children.

loans.use: To buy a car for his business

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Id Phally has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Oun

texts.en: Oun S. is 51 years old and works at a small private company earning $2/day.  She lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 4 children.  Her husband and 2 of the kids work as mechanics and earn $12/day combined.  One of the other children works at a local hotel and also contributes to the household income.  Oun S. will use this loan to buy a motobike for her family to get to and from work.  This will save the family money in the long run, as well as time.  In the future, Oun S. wants to help her husband make his shop larger, and she'd also like to improve her home.

loans.use: To buy a motobike for transportation to work

loans.name: Tiana

texts.en: Tiana is a married mother of two from the Samoan village of Faatoia.  She runs a general store in this small village.  While her husband is employed, his earnings do not cover the expenses of their family.  Tiana opened a small store, and the income is a crucial supplement to the family finances.  Tiana has been able to use past loans to finance expanding the inventory for her store, and she will use these loan funds for a similar purpose.  Tiana is determined to provide for her family’s future, and thus makes a weekly deposit in her savings account.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Piliopo

texts.en:
Piliopo is about forty years of age, and she makes and sells German Buns and chips. Piliopo’s husband is a carpenter. When he is available, he carries his fishing net to the sea to catch some fish to sell.

Piliopo works four days of the week with the help of her daughters. Piliopo sells her buns at the Primary School. This treat is one of the children’s favorites; that’s why Piliopo decided to sell it at the school. It's one dollar for a German Bun and the same price for the chips. She will use the loan to purchase ingredients for the buns.

loans.use: To purchase flour, dripping, sugar

loans.name: Mile

texts.en: Mile is a 51-year-old businessperson who specializes in making German buns. The buns are a delicacy with students and grown-ups alike, and she delivers her pastries to local schools to earn a living. Mile works five days a week during the school days. She plans to use the loan to buy bags of flour and coconuts.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour and coconuts

loans.name: Toeafe

texts.en: Toeafe is a young, single mother.  In order to support herself and her child, she opened a shop directly after she finished school.  Her shop is a small general store in her tiny Samoan village, providing the basics to the villagers.  She can earn a steady income stream from her shop, and she takes half of the money from her sales and deposits it into her savings account.  She uses the savings as needed to reinvest in her business and to save for her child’s future.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for sale at her shop

loans.name: Saleuleu

texts.en: Saleuleu lives at Falelauniu, which is a place of coconuts. This is where Saleuleu’s payment comes from. She sells these coconuts at the market everyday and earns about $300 a day. Saleuleu’s children collect the coconuts and she will rent a village car to deliver her coconuts to the market.

loans.use: Purchase coconuts

loans.name: Vitolina

texts.en: Vitolina is 65 years old and has raised seven children.  Vitolina is quick to extol the virtues of hard work and, likewise, disparage laziness.  Vitolina owns a set of beach fales that she rents out to back-packers or picnickers passing through the village and works hard to keep the structures in good condition.  Fales are simple, small open huts with thatched roofs built in the style of the traditional Samoan house.  Vitolina’s fales are situated on a white sandy beach on the Samoan coast.  She readily welcomes guests and provides them with a simple roof, unbeatable views, and home-cooked meals. She will use the loan to renovate the beach fales.

loans.use: Renovate beach fales (small open huts)

loans.name: Salote

texts.en: Salote’s business is making and selling pork buns at her village. The market is too far for her, so she prefers to sell her products at home. Salote uses pork and flour for the pork buns. When the pork is short, she buys turkey tails as a substitute. This is one of the children’s and even old peoples' favorites. The pork bun costs one dollar, and customers choose between the fried and the steamed buns. Salote works six days of the week, including Sunday evenings. Salote plans to take her business to the flea market when she finds a rented spot.

loans.use: To purchase flour, turkey tail, soya-sauce, and pots

loans.name: Saumama

texts.en: Saumama P. is one of the active members in the program who contributes a lot of ideas during the center meetings. Saumama is running two businesses. If one fails, she has the other to fall back on. Saumama’s store is at the front of their house. She explained that in the past, her family operated the shop, and it went bankrupt. Saumama’s idea when she first entered the program was to re-open the shop. Learning from the past mistakes, Saumama thought to create a banana plantation at the other side of the house. The bananas are sold at the market only on Fridays and Saturdays. Saumama believes that the shop will never fail again.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to stock the shop and planting tools for the banana plantation

loans.name: Aneriuneta

texts.en: Aneriuneta believes fishing is not just a male duty. She is a strong and motivated 35-year-old woman.  She earns a daily income of more than ST $250 (approximately USD$100) from fishing to support her six children.  She sells fish to the people of her village. She is so thankful to SPBD for their financial support in upgrading her fishing tools for her small business. Aneriuneta has applied for another loan to upgrade her fishing gears and also to improve her home.

loans.use: Buy fishing tools

loans.name: Sieni

texts.en:
Sieni’s husband is an experienced fisherman. Vailoa is one of the urban villages, and the market is good there. There is no need for her to bring her fish to the market. Sieni is still young. She sells her fish at the front of her house. These are fresh fish that were just caught by her husband. It’s always $25 for one string of fish and she can get $100 a day for selling four strings of fishes.

They have no freezer, so they do not want to take their fish to the market. Instead, they sell it right away when the husband returns from fishing. Sieni would like to use the loan to purchase a freezer.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer

loans.name: Silalotalie

texts.en:
Silalotalie has a vision for the future. Silalotalie is one of the older members in the program, and she is an honest and hard worker. This is Silalotalie’s seventh loan, and she has no arrears on her repayment performance.

Silalotalie is a woman who can do a man’s work. She may look fragile when you see her, but she is very strong. She operates two businesses together: a shop and a plantation. The ideas and planning are hers. She thinks that the plantation is helpful and supportive for the shop and for family food so that no money will be spent on buying taro or bananas. She would like to use the loan to restock the shop and buy planting tools.

loans.use: To purchase goods to restock the shop and planting tools for the plantation

loans.name: Tigaina

texts.en: Tigaina has four children and they are all in school. She is one of the pancake sellers in the S. area. This is Tigaina’s daily job. Whether she makes pancakes in the evening or during the day, her inventory is all sold out.  Tigaina’s husband works and he also assists her when he can. As she explained, the loans from SPBD really helped with her children's school fees and school activities. She is looking for a new experience to start a new business with her next loan.

loans.use: To purchase flour, dripping, pots, baking powder, kitchen wares

loans.name: Totoa

texts.en: Totoa is a 39-year-old mother from Vaimoso who runs a small shop. She was able to upgrade her shop with the assistance of SPBD; her first loan really attracted more clients. She has three children, and two of them are still relying on their mother for full support. She has managed to keep her business going and do her duties as a mother at home. She has done a good job, and as a result of her great effort, she is now able to earn more than ST$1,000(approximately USD$667) a week from her shop. She would like to use the loan to buy more supplies, like mutton flaps, turkey tails, and cigarettes.

loans.use: Buy stock like mutton flaps, turkey tails, cigarettes, etc

loans.name: Lopepe

texts.en: Lopepe grows cocoa and sells it to the local market in town. Cocoa is in high demand because it can be used in many ways to make affordable Samoan delicacies. This is one of the major reasons why Lopepe’s business is so successful. She would like to use the loan to buy more cocoa plants, beans, manure, and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy more cocoa plants, beans, manure and fertilizers

loans.name: Tine

texts.en: Tine is good at gardening and planting. This is one of her hobbies in life. Tine’s backyard is filled up with different vegetables, but cabbages are the main crop. About one-quarter of her area is covered with cabbages. These cabbages only need two to three weeks to grow and re-grow. The place where she lives is mostly occupied with Europeans, and they really like vegetables. These are Tine’s main customers. When Tine has a surplus of vegetables, she prefers to take them to the market. Tine would like to use the loan to buy seeds, tools, and fertilizers from the agriculture store.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds, gardening tools, and fertilizers

loans.name: Liliolevao

texts.en: Liliolevao has always had passion for gardens, but it wasn’t until she put her experience to good use that she started earning a living by selling her vegetables to the local market and villagers. The mother of seven from Mulifanua-fou works six days a week on her garden. She would like to use the loan to buy seeds.

loans.use: To buy seeds for the vegetable garden

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina S. is 51 years old. She believes that, regardless of age, she still has the potential to build more decorated cement posts. She is a very independent lady.  Although two of her children work, she does not want to rely on them. She prefers to have a business of her own.  Tina earns good money from her small business, and she is looking forward to working closely with SPBD. She has applied for another loan to improve and extend her business based on a great demand from her usual customers. She will use the loan to purchase materials.

loans.use: To buy materials to build more cement posts.

loans.name: Toga

texts.en: Toga is known for her pancakes, and is requesting a loan so she can expand her baking business. She is now going to be baking Puligi (cakes) that many families enjoy with their morning tea. The cakes will be more profitable, because they sell for a higher price. She will use her loan money to buy a second-hand oven and to extend the back of her house to accommodate her baking business.

loans.use: To purchase flour, baking powder, eggs, butter, timber, nails, cement for kitchen extension

loans.name: Koreti

texts.en: Koreti has always loved flowers and her passion has made her very good at growing them. She earns her living by growing and selling a variety of flowers for funerals and special occasions. She also sells potted plants for the home. She is requesting a loan to purchase more seeds and gardening materials so she can produce more flowers to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds, cutter, pot plants, fertilizers and pots

loans.name: Tuleiga

texts.en: Tuleiga’s husband is a good Engineer and can fix lawn mowers and other light machinery. Tuleiga and her husband have two lawnmowers, and they earn their living by mowing lawns. Tuleiga enjoys this business because it is good exercise, even though the sun can get very hot when she works. Tuleiga is requesting a loan so she can purchase another lawnmower and a second-hand car for transportation. This will enable her and her husband to do more business.

loans.use: To purchase a new lawnmower

loans.name: Jahnitta

texts.en: Jahnitta is a small business operator who sells pancakes to earn a living. She is married with six children, and she believes that she is one of the best pancake makers in her country. However, pancakes in Samoa are not the S. as the flat ones seen on breakfast tables in other places. Samoan pancakes are round, ball-like delicacies that are enjoyed by those who cannot afford to buy breads for a large family. The pancakes are less expensive and a small amount of money can buy pancakes for eight people. Jahnitta makes her pancakes in her home and sells to families and school children. She is requesting a loan so she can produce more and increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase oil, flour, bananas, and yeast

loans.name: Tusipepa

texts.en: Tusipepa is a young, talented woman whose husband is a very talented man in the sea. Her husband and her older brother do the fishing, staying out for two days a week. If the weather is bad, they come in at night and only fish in the day. Tusipepa then sells the fish at the Fish Market. Tusipepa's first loan helped her family build their fish business. Now she is requesting a second loan to purchase a good fishing boat which will help them increase their catch.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Leumele

texts.en: Leumele is very creative and she specializes in making handicrafts and to sell.  The competition selling handicrafts is sometimes very high, so she has started selling cooked eggs as an alternative business for additional income.  Leumele earns ST$420 (approx. USD$160) fortnightly, which helps a lot in supporting her children, family and church activities. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase more materials for her businesses and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Buy eggs, and supplies for handicrafts

loans.name: Vaimoana

texts.en: Vaimoana is one of the business ladies in the program that has attained the second level of business ranking. Her husband works, but his wages are not enough for the family's needs. Vaimoana is talented at sewing and designing clothes which she sells at the flea market along with traditional Samoan handbags she makes herself, coconut shell earrings and other handicrafts. She works at the flea market six days a week, and her income helps support her family. Most of her customers are local people and tourists. She is requesting a loan so she can offer more items to sell and increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase materials for sewing: thread, neddles, scissors, paint

loans.name: Visitasia

texts.en: Visitasia uses seashells from the shore for her jewelry business. With the help of SPBD, she was able to buy tools to carve and design different sizes of earrings. Other ladies in the program taught her how to make this jewelry. This was her first loan and her first time to do this kind of business. She is a good learner and she was able to earn more money from this craft. Everyday is a learning experience for her as she gathers more ideas from the other ladies of the program in how to be successful in her business. She chose this type of business is because she likes the creativity and it is profitable. She is requesting a second loan so she can increase her stock and income.

loans.use: To purchase more hooks, varnish, brushes, paint

loans.name: Lemalie

texts.en: Lemalie V. is a 33-year-old woman from the village of Seesee, and is married with six children.  She likes cooking Samoan food -- like taro, banana, yam and fish mixed with coconut cream -- in a Samoan oven. Her stall is open on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Saturdays. This income greatly assists in paying for her children's education and making her weekly repayments at the center's meeting. She is now ready for a second loan so she can increase her output of food and improve her income and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and materials for making food

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea T. is a 57 year old widow who lives in Phnom Penh with her 1 child and two grandchildren.  She sells furniture and makes about $7/day.  Her child works for a small private company and contributes to the household income.  Chea T. will use this loan to buy furniture products to sell in her store. In the future she plans on continuing with her business until she has enough money to build a larger home where she can also have her shop.

loans.use: To buy furniture products for reselling

loans.name: Ku

texts.en: Ku T. is 39 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 3 small children.  She works as a grocer, making $2.50/day, and her husband works as a blacksmith.  She will use this loan to buy a machine for her husband's business as well as groceries for her business.  In the future, she wants to build a house to rent out and also to send her children to university.

loans.use: To buy a machine for a blacksmith business and to buy some grocery products

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Ku Theit has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Fuamatala

texts.en: Fuamatala P. has a food vending business and sells cooked Samoan dishes, like taro, banana, fish and yam all mixed with coconut cream. She sells her product to the public in front of one of the shops near home.  Her husband works fultime on their small plantation and gives her a hand in running the business when needed. Her stall is open Mondays, Tuesdays and Saturdays. Her weekly net profit helps a lot in supporting her childrens' education. She is requesting a loan so she can upgrade her business and earn more money for her children's studies and for improving the home that they live in.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients and upgrade her food stall

loans.name: Koun

texts.en: Koun C. is a 47 year old mototaxi driver who can earn $2.50/day.  He lives in Phnom Penh with his wife (pictured here at her sewing machine), who works as a tailor, and their two children.  He will use this loan to buy one motobike for his mototaxi business.  He can rent this bike out to a driver and also take a percentage of his daily earnings.  In the future, he hopes to save up enough money to start a different business.  He also would like to see his children reach university.

loans.use: To buy a motobike for his taxi business

loans.name: Lusia Alosio

texts.en: Lusia of Seesee has made a beautiful stall in front of the dairy shop for selling Samoan favorite foods such as Palusami (cooked taro leaves mixed with coconut cream), taro, banana and yam. Lusia only opens her business on Mondays, Tuesdays and Saturdays and other days, she works collecting coconuts, taro, banana and yam from the plantation for the preparation of her food stall.  Her husband works full time on their plantation and he provides great support to her business. She normally earns a net profit of $180 from selling her food products to the public. This lady manages her business very well. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase supplies for processing her the food she sells.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for the processing of food

loans.name: Fetu

texts.en: Fetu is a 49-year-old lady who is a Center secretary for the Puipaa Center. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a full-time fisherman, and this is their main source of income. This business pays for the education of their children, clothing for the kids, family dues and village and church financial activities.  Fetu works in her business six days a week and she earns $80+ per day.  She earns a total net profit of $100 a week, and some of this money goes into her savings account with SPBD to assist with her weekly loan repayments if the weather is bad, and her husband can't supply the fish she sells. She is requesting a loan so they can upgrade their fishing equipment and increase their catch.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Vaimoa

texts.en:
Vaimoa is a pancake maker whose number one customers are the school children. Because pancakes are the cheapest substitute for bread and sweet cakes, it is a favorite among the school children. One of the reasons why pancakes are a high demand with schoolchildren is because not only it is affordable food, but they come in a big number also. School children with only one tala in their pockets can purchase 10 pancakes with just that amount of money.

For five days a week, Vaimoa goes around to the schools selling and earning 20 tala per day and 100 a week; her profit is 50 tala. The 40-year-old mother’s business helps her husband who works to earn the school fees for three of their children who are still attending school.

loans.use: To purchase oven, flour & oil

loans.name: Jossie

texts.en:
Jossie from Vaimoso runs a shop in her own village. She used to sell BBQ before she joined SPBD in the beginning of 2006. She managed to get a first loan from SPBD to continue selling BBQ, and was successful enough at the same time to open a new grocery shop as her other small business.

Jossie is married with 1 kid and her husband is working, which greatly assists her in a time when both businesses are too slow. She earns ST$120 on a daily basis and her overall net profit for a week is ST$500 (USD$180).

Jossie continues to work hard on her small businesses and she is willing to extend her shop in the future. She has applied for another loan to upgrade her existing shop business.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for the village shop

loans.name: Matele

texts.en:
Matele is a 41 year old married mother who operates a handicrafts business, a talent that she has had since a very young age. She has chosen to make good use of her ability to set up a business to further improve her family’s standard of living.

Matele chooses good quality but cheap traders of wood to create her masterpieces, which she sells to the local markets and individuals. Her number one customers are tourists and Samoans traveling overseas who purchase her wares as souvenirs.

loans.use: Purchase timber, cement to set up handicrafts stall

loans.name: Mia

texts.en: Mia is 38. Her husband is a mason. They have two daughters who stopped going to school to work as laborers. This family must take care of their old mother, who has cardiovascular problems. All of them live in a leaf hut. They have a fishpond, which is about 300 square meters. Their income is about $10 per person/month. They want to get a loan of $75  to raise fish. They promise to repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To raise fish

loans.name: Siline

texts.en: Siline is a mother of eight and baking is the main source of income for her family. She sells her product at a local school. Mostly she produces donuts, which she knows that the small children at the school can afford to buy for lunch.

loans.use: To buy flour, yeast,sugar,yeast

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta is a mother of three who operates a plantation at Samatau. Her husband works six days a week on the plantation. When it is time for harvesting, Imeleta sells the taro and bananas to members of her village and also to the local market.

loans.use: To vegetable seeds, organic fertilizers and pesticides, and additional farming implements like shovel, rake and bush knife

loans.name: Gafa

texts.en:
With 12 people in her family, Gafa decided to join SPBD to earn a living to accommodate the growing number. She runs an ice-cake and ice-pop business, which caters to young children and adults.

The ice-cake and ice-pops are mixed with cordial, sweetener and flavoring to give a good taste. She earns 50 tala a day, seven days a week. She earns a profit of 75-100 tala ($25-35) a week.

loans.use: To purchase plastic cups, sugar, cordial and pay electric bills

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en:
Fofoga has a family of five. She operates her business from her home, selling popcorn. Her business is popular with village members, especially the younger people. She makes 50 packets of popcorn a day, and sells them for one tala a packet.

Fofoga does this six days a week, while her husband helps earn more money as a taxi driver.

She needs 1,250 to purchase more corn seeds and oven to expand her business and buy gas.

loans.use: To purchase corn seeds, oven, and gas

loans.name: Levon

texts.en:
Levon of Papaigalagala has great cooking experience. She runs her own barbarque business in front of her house. Her place is close to the University gate, and she has many customers from the students of the University.

Levon is making good money from selling her BBQ, and she is willing to make and sell her BBQ 5 days a week. She is able to save some money from her business to support her children and her family. She has asked for another loan to upgrade and improve her small business.

loans.use: Purchase more supplies for making the BBQ

loans.name: Fiapaipai

texts.en: Fiapaipai runs a plantation at Vailoa-uta. She sells her crops to people in her village to earn a living to accommodate her growing family. Fiapaipai has many years experience in operating a vegetable plantation, so as a result her experience is used to expand and nurture her crops, and to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, string, seeds & crops

loans.name: Suluvale

texts.en:
Suluvale is motivated to start a small shop business as she has six children to support. She is from the village of Papaigalagala and she is 55 years old. She is wearing many hats, which include her mother’s responsibilities at home, her role in the village and church, but also her role as businesswoman.

She makes $300 profit per week which greatly assists her family financially, especially in supporting her six children. She has applied for another loan to keep her business going well.

loans.use: Buy more stock for the shop

loans.name: Faaumia

texts.en: Faaumia grows and sells flax patches to the villagers who weave fine mats, traditional hats and Samoan fans. Her business is currently operating because most important traditional materials for Samoans are woven goods such as fine mats, widely used in funerals, church events, family gatherings, and other occasions. These are also important sources of income for many families that cater to tourists by weaving handicrafts, fine mats, fans, and other materials that could be bought by tourists as souvenirs of their visit to Samoa. Faaumia’s business is very important because flax is for everyday consumption.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and for labor

loans.name: Loan

texts.en: Loan is 26, and her husband is 30. They have no land, but they rent from a neighbor to grow vegetables. Their activities include selling groceries and growing vegetables. Their income is $11 per person/month. They would like a loan of $75 from the Kiva program to purchase a variety of goods for their grocery. They are going to repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods for their grocery shop

loans.name: Aigatupu

texts.en:
“... It was very hard to raise up a family if none of them can get a job to rely on...” That is what Mrs. S. believed. She is married with five children. She joined the SPBD program at the end of 2006, and received a loan of 750ST. The money was used to start a business of selling pancakes and snacks to the people, especially to the school children. She bought a brand new kerosene oven, flour for making pancakes and snacks for her business.

She mentioned that she can now get some more money to help out in her family needs and especially supporting her five kids. She wants another loan for repairing her house to upgrade and improve their living condition, and believes that she would like to be an SPBD member for a long time because she believes they help her the most.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for home improvement

loans.name: Faavava

texts.en: Faavava started her grocery store in her village at Mulifanua because she realised there was a big market but hardly any stores to cater for the needs of people in the area. She now cater for one of the most sparsely inhabited areas in the country.

loans.use: To buy sack of twisties and boxes of chicken and turkey tails

loans.name: Asomaliu

texts.en:
Mrs S. is married with 3 children. She and her husband are unemployed. They decided to grow a vegetable garden which she is making into a business to help out with family needs, especially their children's.

She was facing a lot of problems such as too many weeds and lack of chemicals to kill insects that damaged the vegetables due to financial constraints. She needed financial assistance to improve her vegetable garden's condition in order to maintain her customer orders and therefore joined the SPBD program which she found out about through other village members.

She would like to apply for another loan through SPBD so that she can pay her children's school fees and if there is enough, she would like to make repairs to the back of their house.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for her home improvement and pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Lagomau

texts.en: Logomau grows more than just the usual bananas and taro on her plantation. She also plants pineapples and as a result of experimenting with different types of crops, helps her plantation by attracting different customers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and shovels.

loans.name: Vaiola

texts.en:
It may sound really weird to us that a woman operates a pool table game but this is Vaiola S.’s small business. She understands that some people of her village like playing pool, so she has decided to run this business and see how it goes. Her pool tables open from Monday to Saturday as more and more people are interested in playing pool, especially in the morning and in the afternoon.

She is planning to expand her business as it attracts a lot of people but due to limited resources she can only afford to buy one new pool table from her loan with SPBD. Her new business helps her a lot in supporting her family and children.

loans.use: To buy another pool table to accommodate customer demand

loans.name: Chuk

texts.en: Chuk R. is 39 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 2 children.  Her husband is 47 years old and works as a security guard, earning $2.50/day.  Chuk R. sells clothes at the local market and earns $9 in revenue per day.  She will use this loan to buy more clothes in order to have more variety at her store.  In the future, she wants to open a beverage shop and send her children to university.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for selling

loans.name: Leata

texts.en: Leata runs a fishing business from Faleula and earns 300 a week. She is expanding her business and needs to buy more nets to cater to the demand of the fishing industry in the country.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak M. is a moto-taxi driver in Phnom Penh.  He lives with his wife and their child who works as a tailor earning $2.50/day.  Prak M. can make $2/day driving people around.  He will use this loan to buy two sewing machines and some clothes for his child's business.  In the future, he hopes to continue investing in his child and helping them to build a business of their tailoring skills.

loans.use: To buy two sewing machines and some clothes

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Prak Muong has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Suy Bun

texts.en:
Suy Bun T. is 29 years old and works as a tailor earning $2.50 per day. Her husband is an electrician and earns $5/day. Together, they have 2 children who are students, and they also have one niece who also lives with their family. This loan will be used to buy a motorbike for their transportation.

In the future, Soy Bun T. hopes to hire a couple of workers to start a small garment manufacturing company. She hopes to see her children graduate from university someday.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation

loans.name: Matata

texts.en: Matata loves gardening and as a result, she operates a vegetable garden which assists in earning money for the family. She is a mother of six children and her main crops are cabbages which she sells at the local market and village.

loans.use: To purchase weedkiller, string, fertilizers & seeds.

loans.name: Qudsia

texts.en: Qudsia is 24 years old and living in District 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married. She has five children. She took her third loan to expand her business. She spent that money on the land where she grows food to buy some items that help her family. She wants to make her life better than it is now. She wants their children to be in school to study and to be a success in the future. Now she is very happy with her business.

loans.use: Buying Materials

loans.name: Srk Srey

texts.en:
Srk Srey S. is 26 years old and works in a garment factory earning $2.50/day. Her husband drives a mototaxi and earns $2/day. They have 1 child and are using this loan to build a more proper home.

In the future, the husband wants to become a tuk-tuk driver because the pay is better. They also hope to have enough money to build a gate around their home.

loans.use: To buy wood for building a home

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is a mother of two children and runs a lawn mowing business which helps cater for her family’s needs. With eight people in her family, she earns 200 a week but needs to purchase materials to further develop and expand her business services to meet the high demand of clients.

loans.use: To purchase oil, weed eater & lawn mower

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem P. is 54 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 3 children. Her husband earns $3/day as a construction worker, while 2 of her children work with their father and each make $2/day.

The recycling system in Phnom Penh is not very organized, and consists of people buying and reselling plastic/paper/metal and other recyclables until they finally reach a place (and bulk quantity) where they will actually be recycled.

Sem P. will use this loan to buy recyclable products and resell them in bulk for a small profit. In the future, she feels she can use CREDIT to have the ability to buy larger quantities and make more money. She hopes to earn enough to send all of her children to high school.

loans.use: To buy recyclable items

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Sem Phan has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Pea

texts.en: Pea has many years' experience in sewing, which is a talent that she has had for many years. Pea has decided to set up a seamstress business catering to people in her village. She specialises in the Samoan traditional wear puletasi, school uniforms, committee uniforms and wrap-arounds.

loans.use: To purchase thread, needles, buttons, oil for machine and fabric

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Sin S. is 58 years old and is a construction worker in Phnom Penh. His wife is 53 and they have 2 children together that go to school daily. Sin S. has grown his business so that he has several employees. He needs to pay these employees regularly, but he does not get the money from his project until it is completed.

He will use this loan to cover his employees' wages until the project is complete. In the future, he hopes to continue growing his business so that he is more of a manager rather than a worker. He also wants to help his wife open a grocery store at the local market.

loans.use: To pay the advanced wages of his employees

payments.comment:
Congratulations to Sin Sang for repaying his loan early! Because of your loan, he was able to cover the upfront costs of paying his workers until the building project was completed and he could receive his fee.

Sin Sang and his family appreciate you offering him a loan, without which he would not be able to continue with his business. 

We thank you for supporting poor Cambodian entrepreneurs and hope you will invest in CREDIT MFI clients in the future.

Many thanks,
Jordyan Edmiston, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia
and the entire CREDIT MFI staff

loans.name: Masina

texts.en: Masina S. and her family use to rely mostly on her small business of selling ice cakes in the beginning to earn a few dollars to support the whole family. When she joined SBPD in 2006 she then realized that her dream would come true by running a village shop not only to get more profits but also to help out in supporting her children’s education. She believes that she has been struggling hard enough to get what she wants, and she is very thankful to have had SPBD grant her loans to start and upgrade her business.  She has now become a very active businesswoman.

loans.use: Buy more stock for the shop

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
Nuon N. is a tailor in Phnom Penh. She is 56 years old and lives with her husband and their two children. Nuon N. earns $2.50/day and her husband earns the same as a mototaxi driver.

She will use this loan to buy a sewing machine for her business. She also hopes to be able to fix up their house for the rainy season.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Hashim

texts.en: Hashim was born in 1970 and lives with his household of 4 children in District 16 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a butcher shop that sales cow, sheep, and goat meat. To enlarge his shop and buy animals and equipment, he is taking a loan from AFSG. This will make his life better than it is now. In the past he faced lots of difficulties and now he is very happy with his family and feels he can improve his life in a good way.

loans.use: Buy animals and equipment

loans.name: Taofi

texts.en:
Taofi has ten years' experience in operating a grocery store but she now wants to expand the commodities available on her shelves to attract more customers.

From the village of Aele, a settlement for Solomons and Papua New Guinea people in the olden days, her village is cut off from town. Taofi’s store is one of two operating stores in the small village.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the store, such as boxes of chicken, turkey tails and herring

loans.name: Pork

texts.en:
Pork C. is 57 years old and makes hammocks for a living. (There is high demand for hammocks in Cambodia). She can usually earn about $5/day doing this, while her husband rents out a home and earns $2.50/day. They have 4 children, 2 of whom work in a garment factory, and 2 who are students.

She will use this loan to buy land for building a house on. She will then rent this house out to give her a little additional income. She hopes to continue this process in the future, as it is a safe way to make $70-100 extra income per month.

loans.use: To buy land for building a rental house

loans.name: Soonalofa

texts.en:
Most of the school children at Maagiagi village cannot afford to buy breakfast or lunch from their school canteen as it is more expensive for poor kids. Soonalofa is just the solution for them.

She sells popcorn and Samoan cookies five days a week. This is a good alternative and the cheapest one for the poorer students at school. Soonaalofa has also been able to continue to collect good income from selling cookies and popcorn at school. She uses the profit from her business to support her three children's education and to support her family financially.

"At least I can earn something to help out with my children, but I have a personal goal to turn out this small business into a successful big one," said Soonaalofa.

loans.use: Buy more supplies for her foodstall at school

loans.name: Masooda

texts.en: Masooda is taking a loan for his brother's cosmetics shop. His brother is 23 years old and lives in District 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and lives with  8 members of his family. He has a cosmetics shop that sells cosmetics and stationery materials. With this loan from AFSG he will expand his business and buy cosmetics. Since is the worker in his family and he supports them financially, he wants more success.

loans.use: Buying materials

loans.name: Vaioleti

texts.en:
Residing just opposite the National University of Samoa is a blessing for Vaioleti’s small shop. Her shop is always full of students buying snacks,ice pops or even ice cream, when they take a break from classes. The school canteen is not sufficient for all the students, so this village shop helps to sell food, snacks and drinks during lunch break.

Vaioleti is planning to expand her shop, but she needs to apply for another loan with SPBD to assist in the expansion of her shop. She earns good profit and this has been invested for the expansion of her small business. In return, she is able to take care of her children and family.

loans.use: Buy more stocks for the village store

loans.name: Alfredo Abílio

texts.en:
Alfredo Abilio S. is 68 years old; he was born and raised in Machanga, a Sofala province. Alfredo had limited opportunities to attend school, because during colonial rule the indigenous population was not allowed to attend school above 4th grade level. Since 1987, Alfredo has been working in agriculture. He owns a 12 hectare plot in the district of Boane. In 2007, he heard about HLUVUKU-ADSEMA through friends. Alfredo learned more about the conditions for access to loans, and decided to request a loan in order to expand his farming area. With the 25.000,00 MT loan, he intends to expand his maize farming area from 3 hectares to 6 hectares, to purchase seeds and fertilizers, and to clear and prepare plots, consequently increasing his production. Alfredo currently employs 3 full-time workers. With the increase of his farming area he plans on hiring 3 more permanent workers, in addition to hiring temporary workers which will be needed when the work load so requires. Alfredo’s activities have a great impact in his community because he generates work for 6 community members, and income for their families. His work also makes corn available for the local market and provides grains, in great quantities, for the Malanga market, located in the city of Maputo.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva volunteer.

Localizacao: Pequenos Libombos - Boane Cliente: Alfredo Abilio S. Sector de actividade: Agricultura Valor do empréstimo: 25.000.00MT (1,000.00US$) Aplicação de montante: Compra de ínsumos agrícolas Inicio: 10/04/2007 Fim: 30/09/2008 Alfredo Abilio S. de 68 anos de idade, natural de Machanga, provincial de Sofala, cresceu sob responsabilidade, teve poucas oportunidades de estudar, pois na altura da dominação colonial a população indígena não podia estudar para além da 4@classe. Desde o ano de 1987 que vem trabalhando na área de agricultura e possui uma parcela de 12 hectares no distrito de Boane. No ano 2007 teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA através de amigos tendo aproximado, depois de informado das condições de acesso, decidiu solicitar um empréstimo para ampliação sua área de produção. Com o empréstimo de 25.000,00MT, pretende aumentar o volume a área de produção de 3 para 6 ha de milho e compra de insumos agrícolas (adubos e sementes), assim como preparação do terreno (lavouras), e consequentemente vai aumentar a sua receita. Actualmente conta com conta com três (3) trabalhadores efectivos e, com aumento da área de produção ira contratar mais outros três (3), para além de mão de obra eventual que sempre é necessária quando o trabalho assim o exige. A sua actividade tem um grande impacto na comunidade, porque para alem de providenciar emprego a meia dúzia de chefes de famílias, coloca milho a disposição no mercado local e abastece em grandes quantidades o mercado da Malanga que localiza-se na cidade do Maputo.

loans.use: To buy seeds and land Preparation

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Hussnia

texts.en:
Hussnia A. lives with four members of her family in District 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan.
She is an uneducated women. Due to family problems, she took a loan for her brother who sells shoes at a  shop near the market. She says that this loan will be very profitable for her brother because he wants to expand his business.  She thanks AFS for helping  poor people.

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Khnom Gul

texts.en: Khnom Gul was born in 1965.  She lives in Kabul with three members of her family. She practices animal husbandry and raises cows, sheep, and goats in her house. She took loan from AFS to expand her business and purchased three cows. Her sales of milk,cheese, and butter at the bazaar covers her familys financial needs. Three months ago she lost two of her cows. Therefore she took a loan to replace those  cows.

loans.use: to buy cows and sheep

loans.name: Zohra

texts.en: Zohra is 40 years old and lives in District 9 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has five children. She took a loan from AFS to help her buy sheep and other materials for her business of animal husbandry. She is an uneducated woman. She wants to continue practicing animal husbandry. Her husband sells the sheep at the bazaar. The business allows her to make her familys livelihood better because it adds income.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Mau

texts.en: Mau is 45, and her husband is 55. They have three children, whose ages are 25, 23, and 21. All of the children stopped going to school when they didn't pass primary school, to help their parents earn money in other provinces. Their income is about $10 per person/month. They hope to get a loan of $75 so that they can expand and supply their soft drinks shop. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: To expand the sales of her soft drinks shop

loans.name: Sayed Hussin

texts.en: S. Hussin is 32 years old and has a household of three.  He lives in District 6 in Kabul, Afghanistan. His main business is operating a garden but he has established an agricultural component as well. He has a lot of land for his garden. He needs a loan from AFS to buy different trees and materials for his garden. After growing the trees, he will sell them at the bazaar.  A successful business will ensure a good future for his family and himself and  will help to create a happy family life.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah was born in 1970.  He lives in a household of five in District 16 in Kabul, Afghanistan.During the war he was unemployed. After the peace, he bought a taxi to support his family.

He is taxi driver working in the main city. Due to the disrepair of the tires, tube and machine, he took a loan to replace these items. He is working seven days a week to develop his business and cover his familys expenses.

loans.use: to buying tires and a machine

loans.name: Najm O Den

texts.en: Najm o D. is 24 years old.  He lives with two family members in District 16 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a car that allows him to transport stones. He buys stones from big dealers and sells them in the bazaar to construction company. He needs money to repair his truck to secure a contract with a stone dealer. Due to problems with his truck, he can't receive the contract.  Therefore he needs a loan to repair his truck. He is glad that AFS is able to support poor and weak people.

loans.use: to buy stones

loans.name: Nguyet

texts.en: Nguyet is 56 years old, and her husband is 50 years old. They have two children, whose ages are 33 and 23. They have 2000 square meters of growing rice land, raising fish, pigs, and ducks for eggs. Their main income from this farm is only $10/person. Because of their low income, their children were forced to stop school in order to earn money by working as laborers in another province. Now, they hope to get a loan of $75 from the Kiva program to supply their farm. They believe that they are going to repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: Supplies for the farm

loans.name: Justa

texts.en:
Justa lives in her own home on 3 de Mayo street in the Villa Nuevo Potosí district of La Paz. She is 47 years old and has been separated from her husband for almost 10 years. She supports her three children by making ice cream (cones, cream cups, cinammon lollipops, etc.) She also sells her products in stores and on the street close to several schools. She has two employees who earn by commission.

Justa has been a client of Impro since 1999. She started with one refrigerator but currently has two for ice cream, and two ice cream makers, one to make ice cream from cream and the other to make ice cream from cinammon. Because of her past loans with the institution we recommend her for this loan to buy more specialized machinery.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Justa vive en casa propia en la calle 3 de mayo de la zona de Villa nuevo Potosí de la Ciudad de la Paz . Ella tiene 47 años de edad, esta separada del esposo casi 10 años y mantiene a sus tres hijos; se dedica a la elaboración de helados (conos, vasitos de crema y chupetes de canela, etc). Además de que ella misma realiza la comercialización del producto ofreciéndolo en las tiendas, como también en la venta ambulante en diferentes colegios. Ella cuenta con dos empleados a los cuales les da a precios económicos y ellos generan sus ingresos de acuerdo a lo que vendan en el día.

La señora es cliente de Impro desde el año 1999; empezó con una heladera y actualmente ella tiene 2 conservadores de helados y 2 maquinas, una para hacer helados de crema y otra para los helados de canela. Por su antecedente con la Institución se sugiere otorgarle el crédito porque ella necesita comprar una maquina selladora de helados.

loans.use: Increase her capital

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is 54 years old and lives in the home of a family member on Sanchez Lima y Aspiazu Street in the Sopocachi district of La Paz. She is separated and provides for her two children with her catering work. Teresa caters for events such as weddings, baptisms, and birthday dinners. She is currently taking classes to learn how to prepare different kinds of food. Teresa doesn't work alone but has one assistant, so we could call her an employer. The loan will be used to purchase ingredients. Teresa has been a customer before. She paid her previous loan very diligently so we recommend her for a second loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Teresa tiene 54 años de edad, vive en la casa de un pariente ubicada en la calle Sánchez Lima y Aspiazu de la zona de sopocachi de la Ciudad de La Paz; es mujer separada y tiene dos hijos a los cuales ella mantiene con su trabajo. Teresa se dedica a la atención de eventos sociales, como ser matrimonios, bautizos, Cumpleaños con cenas o almuerzos bufete, actualmente ella esta estudiando para mejorar la variedad de platos que ella cocina, además este trabajo no lo realiza sola ella cuenta con una persona que le ayuda, por lo cual diríamos que ella genera empleo. El monto solicitado sera utilizado en la compra de insumos. Es cliente antigua, el crédito anterior lo pago bastante bien por lo cual se sugiere otorgarle un nuevo crédito

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her catering service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: She will use the credit to buy ingredients (flour,sugar, yeast, butter, etc.) which will let her expand production and raise her income.

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.en:
Gabriela lives in a single rented room on Adrián Patiño street in the Tembladerani neighborhood. She is 34 years old, and a single mother who supports a 12 year old daughter. She is studying General Accounting at an institute.

She words in a shop, where they pay her very little, but with her savings she was able to buy some sound equipment which she rents out on Saturdays and Sundays for various social gatherings. In addition to providing her with additional income, this also provides work for the two boys who work for her. This loan she is requesting will serve to invest in her working equipment.

Gabriela is a new client, so we don't yet have any past history with her, but because she wants to succeed, we recommend that she be granted this credit.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Tuan

texts.en: Mr. Tuan and Dieu got married 21 years ago. They have three children. The children's ages are 20, 19, and 14. The two old children stopped going to school to earn money as daily labourers; only the youngest daughter continues at high school. They have a field that is 4000 square meters. They grow rice and raise  fish and pigs, and Tuan buys and sells lottery tickets to make money. However, their income is only $11 per person/month. They need a loan of $75 from the Kiva program so that they can improve their field and trade lottery tickets. They hope that their life will be better. They will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To improve the field and trade lottery tickets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I intend to expand and diversify business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the loan to widen my businesses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business

loans.name: Cuong

texts.en: Cuong is 59 years old, and there are 5 people in his family. Their chidren's ages are 25, 22, and 1. Their activity is to combine growing rice with raising fish. Their income is only $7 per person/month. Now, they see the good results of combining growing rice with raising fish to help them earn money, so they've decided to continue and expand this activity. A loan of $75 from the Kiva programme will supply capital to do this. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: To combine growing rice with raising fish

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia started her business of selling shoes 4 years ago to help her husband Jose Ismael, a factory worker whose income was insufficient to maintain the household and provide education to their 3 daughters. The children are 11, 18 and 22 years old and help in Lucia’s business, which has been growing lately.

Lucia needs a loan of $200 to buy wholesale merchandise at a lower cost and be able to offer more variety to her customers. You can help Lucia grow her business- support her today.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lucia desde hace cuatro años inició con la venta de calzado, para ayudar a su esposo, José Ismael, que trabaja como obrero en una fábrica, ya que el salario de él era insuficiente para los gastos del hogar y de la educación de sus hijas, ellos tiene tres hijas de 11, 18 y 22 años de edad, quienes colaboran con Lucia en el negocio, y últimamente han tenido un aumento en sus ventas y pedidos.

En estos momentos, Lucia necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $200 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía de mayoreo para conseguir un mejor precio, y poder ofrecer una mayor variedad a sus clientes. Tú puedes formar parte del crecimiento de este negocio, no lo dudes más y decídete a apoyar a Lucia.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Beatriz Jesusa

texts.en:
Beatriz is a hard-working woman who wants the best for her family. Her husband is a factory worker whose income was insufficient to maintain the household, so 2 years ago Beatriz decided to sell cosmetics, at first among her own friends and little by little expanding her clientele. She sells on credit and this has worked well for her. Beatriz had 2 sons, 17 and 5, and a daughter ,12 . who helps her in her business. Now Beatriz needs a $200 loan to fulfill her clients orders and expects to repay the loan in 3 to 6 months. Beatriz wants to improve her family’s standard of living and is willing to work hard for it, but she needs your help. Beatriz sincerely thanks you for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

Beatriz es una mujer muy trabajadora que desea lo mejor para su familia, su esposo es obrero en una fábrica y su salario no cubría las necesidades de su hogar, ante esto, Beatriz inició con la venta de cosméticos hace dos años, primero entre sus amistades y poco a poco ha ido ganando clientes, a quienes les otorga crédito y este método le ha funcionado muy bien. Beatriz tiene dos hijos, de 17 y 5, y una hija de 12, que colabora con ella en el negocio.

Ahora, Beatriz necesita de un préstamo por $200 dólares que utilizará para poder surtir los pedidos que sus clientes le han hecho, ella ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Beatriz quiere mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y esta dispuesta a esforzarse, pero necesita de tu ayuda, y agradece sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: buy merchandise

loans.name: Oli

texts.en: Oli P. operates her own flea market where she sells her own handicrafts as well as traditional clothing such as puletasi (ladies' dresses) and t-shirts for men. The Christmas season is a very exciting period for Oli, because this is a big time of the year when more tourists visit Samoa.  They always buy handicrafts made in Samoa to take it back with them as a souvenir. Some Samoan people who live outside of Samoa also buy a lot of handicrafts when they return to their country of residence. Oli makes a weekly profit of ST$400 (approximately USD160), which helps in supporting her big family and also in paying for her children's education.  She is now applying for another loan to buy more handicrafts for her business.

loans.use: Purchase more handicrafts to sell at the flea market

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli is married and mother of three children, 20, 23 and 24 years old. The older boys are married, only the younger daughter lives with her. Aracelli’s husband is a driver, but she realized that she needed to help with the expenses. Four years ago she started her retail business of clothes, shoes, décor and jewellery.

Demand has been growing and to meet it, Araceli needs a loan of $750. She will buy merchandise to offer more variety to her customers. You can support this business and improve this family’s standard of living. They thank you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Araceli es casada, madre de tres hijos, de 20, 23 y 24 años de edad, los dos hijos mayores ya están casados y sólo la hija menor vive con ella, su esposo labora como chofer, pero Araceli veía la necesidad de tener un ingreso extra para ayudar en los gastos del hogar, esto es lo que la motivó a iniciar su negocio hace cuatro años, vendiendo productos al menudeo, como ropa, tenis, artículos de decoración y joyería.

La demanda por sus productos se ha incrementado y para cubrir las necesidades de sus clientes, Araceli requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 750 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía, para poder ofrecer más variedad a sus clientes y brindar un buen servicio. Tú puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Opeta

texts.en: Opeta and her husband using fishing nets to  catch fish and other sea shells. The couple is fully committed to their business, as this is the only source of income for the family. She earns $120 per day from selling fish and other sea products to the public and people of her village. Both Opeta and her husband work together not only to making sure that the business is successful, but also to do all other family chores. Opeta is planning to buy another new fishing net, and to renovate their home once she gets her loan from SPBD.  She is a very talented and dedicated woman.

loans.use: To buy a new fishing net and fishing gear, and to renovate her house

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
Felipa O. lives in the town of Escobedo, Nuevo Leon. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a taxi driver, but his income was not enough to pay for the education of their children and so Felipa decided to start her own business 2 years ago. She sells shoes to ensure that her children can finish college. Felipa has worked hard and needs a loan of $475 to buy merchandise and provide better service to her customers. She is committed to repaying her loan in 5 to 10 months. You can support this business and improve this family’s standard of living. They thank you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

En la localidad de Escobedo, Nuevo León, es donde vive Felipa O., ella es casada y tiene tres hijos, su esposo es taxista, pero con el ingreso que obtiene no podían cubrir los gastos de la escuela de sus hijos, por lo que Felipa decidió iniciar su propio negocio hace dos años, vendiendo zapatos, para de esta manera obtener los recursos que necesitaba para sus hijos y que ellos puedan concluir su carrera universitaria con éxito.
