Felipa se ha esforzado mucho por sus hijos, ahora requiere de un préstamo de $ 475 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía, para poder brindarles un buen servicio a sus clientes, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un plazo de 5 a 10 meses. Tú puedes ser parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio, así como en la vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen tu generosidad y apoyo.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Héctor Noe

texts.en:
Hector lives in the town of Escobedo, Nuevo Leon. He is single and has great desire to progress in life. Although he has a full-time job, he decided to start his own business 5 years ago, selling tacos, hamburgers, flautas, enchiladas at street markets during the weekends. His customers have multiplied. Hector wants to grow as an entrepreneur and is willing to make the effort.

Hector needs a loan of $925 to buy supplies and be able to offer his customers a wider variety of products. You can play an important role in Hector’s life and in the growth of his business – Hector thanks you for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

Héctor vive en el municipio de Escobedo, Nuevo León, él es soltero y tiene enormes deseos de superación, aunque trabaja como empleado en una empresa, él decidió iniciar su propio negocio hace cinco años, donde vende comida, como tacos, hamburguesas, flautas y enchiladas, los fines de semana se instala en los mercados ambulantes y sus clientes se han multiplicado. Héctor quiere crecer como microempresario y esta dispuesto a esforzarse lo necesario.

En estos momentos Héctor requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 925 dólares que planea utilizar en la compra de los insumos que necesita para la elaboración de sus productos y así poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad de alimentos. Sé parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio y en la vida de Héctor, él agradece sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: purchase supplies

loans.name: Julia Nancy

texts.en:
Mrs. Nancy has 30 years' experience with her grocery store business. She first started selling clothing going to different towns each week. After saving a little bit of money and with the help of her husband they were able to open the grocery store. She works every day of the week from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. Her husband has a small car that she uses to buy new supplies.

Nancy wants to use the loan to invest in her business and buy new products that she hasn’t sold before. She already has some orders from the people in the area where she lives.

Nancy is 49 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Two of them are old enough to help her when needed. Her husband works in a company as a machinery operator. In the afternoons, he goes out in his small car to make some deliveries. Nancy’s wish is to be able to recondition the store and find a better location for it. She hopes to make it bigger and have a bigger inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nancy tiene una experiencia de 30 años con su negocio de venta de víveres para el hogar. Ella se inicio con la venta de ropa por la que viajaba a los pueblos cada semana. Luego poco a poco fue ahorrando dinero y con la ayuda de su esposo logran poner su tiendita. La trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 11 p.m. Su esposo posee un carrito con el cual van a comprar cuando necesitan surtir la tienda.

Nancy desea el crédito para invertir en el negocio y surtirlo con otros productos que no posee. Va ha invertir en artículos varios ya que tiene pedidos del sector donde vive.

Nancy tiene 49 años. Es casada y tres hijos . Dos de ellos ya tiene compromiso y le ayudan en lo que ella necesita. Su esposo también trabaja en una empresa de operador de maquina. Por las tardes luego de su trabaja sale a realizar fletes con su carrito que tiene. El deseo de Nancy es poder acondicionar su tienda y darle una mejor ubicación. Espera a futuro hacerla mas grande y surtirla.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise to have a bigger inventory.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa has 2 years' experience with her restaurant business. She used to have a store that she had to close due to health problems. On her own initiative, she decided to start selling snacks. Her business started growing and now she also sells lunches, and during the weekends she sells “Encebollados”, a traditional dish. She works every day from 6 a.m. to 3 p.m. and the weekends from 6 a.m. to 12 p.m. Her daughter helps serving the clients and her husband helps during his free time.

Rosa wants to use the loan to buy more plastic tables and chairs for her business, the ones that she has at the moment are not enough due to the demand that her food is having.

Rosa is married. She is 47 years old and she has 4 children. Only one of her children is still with her because she is still in school; and one of the married daughters helps her with the business. Her husband works as a painter and as a driver; he helps with restaurant during his free time especially over the weekends. Rosa’s wish is to be able to own a small house, since they are renting where they live now.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa tiene una experiencia de 2 años con su negocio de venta de comida. Ella tenía una tienda la que tuvo que cerrar por problemas de salud. Por iniciativa propia decide comenzar a vender almuerzos. Su negocio fue creciendo que al momento también vende meriendas y los fines de semana encebollados. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 3 p.m. y los fines de semana hasta las 12 p.m. Su hija le ayuda con la atención de los clientes y también su esposo cuando esta libre.

Rosa desea el crédito para poder comprar mas sillas y mesas plásticas para su negocio por que con las, que cuenta por momentos no le abastecen por la demanda que tiene de comida

.

Rosa es casada. Tiene 47 años y 4 hijos de los cuales solo una esta con ella ya que todavía estudia. Una de las casadas es la que le ayuda en la atención de su negocio. Su esposo también trabaja de pintor y de chofer. En sus ratos libres sobre todo los fines de semana le ayuda con el negocio. Su deseo es poder tener su casita propia ya que actualmente vive arrendando.

loans.use: Buy tables and chairs for her restaurant

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana T. is a very energetic mother who runs her own taro plantation. Ana has seven children and is 45 years old. Her husband is a strong man and works for a local construction company. With Ana’s taro plantation thriving, he happily tells how lucky he is to have married Ana. 

Because her husband’s job is physically taxing, Ana works the plantation on her own and also works hard to ensure that she does all the household chores, so her husband doesn’t have extra work at home. On Saturdays, however, Ana’s husband helps her haul her taro to the local market and sell her crop. Ana is glad to be able to have built a business that can keep her family happy and keep improving their living standard.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pest control agents for her plantation

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria has 5 years' experience with her restaurant business. On her own initiative, she started selling candies at home. Then her grandmother encouraged her to start selling snacks. Thanks to that motivation she doesn’t only sell snacks but she also sells lunches. She works everyday from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. and the weekends from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. Her mother helps her serving the clients at her eatery. With this business, she has been able to recondition the premises and provide a better service for her clients. She also has a small store that generates and additional income. Her younger sisters help her with the sales.

Maria wants to use the credit money to invest in kitchen utensils for her eatery like pots, pans and plates. She would like also to invest part of the money in her small store.

Maria is single. She is 34 years old and she lives with her parents, who have helped her undertake her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria tiene una experiencia ya de 5 años con su negocio de venta de comida. Se inicio vendiendo golosinas en su casa por iniciativa propia. Su abuela la motiva a que comience a vender meriendas y lo hace. Gracias a esa motivación hoy no solamente vende meriendas sino también a incluido venta de almuerzos. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 3 p.m. y los fines de semana hasta las 12 p.m. Su madre es una de las personas que le ayudan con la atención del comedor. Por medio del negocio a logrado adecuar su local para brindar una mejor atención a sus clientes. Además tiene una tienda la cual le genera otros ingresos. Sus hermanas menores le ayudan con las ventas.

Maria desea el crédito para invertir en utensilios para su negocio como lo son ollas, platos, y una parte desea invertir en su tiendita.

Maria es soltera. Tiene 34 años y vive en la casa de sus padres. Los mismos que le han ayudado en emprender su negocio.

loans.use: Invest in kitchen utensils for her eatery

loans.name: Maryuri

texts.en:
Maryuri has 2 years’ experience with her business of selling cosmetics. She used to work in a clothing store, but she was laid-off. A friend encouraged her to sell these cosmetic products. She works everyday of the week from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Maryuri wants to use the loan to invest in her business. By having a bigger investment her earnings will be bigger as well. She also wants to sell other articles like clothing.

Maryuri is a widower. She is 30 years old and she has a 14 year old daughter. Her husband died of tonsil cancer 8 years ago. She is now renting a house where she lives with her daughter who is in school. Maryuri’s mother in law who is abroad helps her with the needs of her granddaughter. Her mother and sister are always looking after her and help her when needed. She has been able to pull through with her own work. With this business, she hopes to able to save enough to buy a small house.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Maryuri tiene una experiencia de 2 años con su negocio de venta de cosméticos. Ella trabajaba en un local de venta de ropa, del cual la liquidaron. Por iniciativa de una amiga la impulsa a vender estos productos. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m.

Maryuri desea el crédito para poder invertir en su negocio. Al hacer una mayor inversión sus ganancias van a hacer mejores. Además desea poder vender otros artículos como son las prendas de vestir.

Maryuri es viuda. Tiene 30 años y una hija de 14 años. Su esposo falleció hace ocho años de un cáncer a las amígdalas. Ella actualmente alquila y vive solo con su hija la que estudia. Su suegra que esta en el exterior le ayuda con lo que necesita su nieta. Además tiene la ayuda de su madre y hermana las cuales están pendientes de lo que necesita. Ella con su trabajo ha logrado salir adelante con su familia. Espera con su negocio poder ir ahorrando y tener su casita propia.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics and clothing

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny has 6 years’ experience with her business of selling cosmetics and jewelry. She has been working since she was in school helping her mother. She would take products to sell them at school. In a way, it was her mother who started the business. Once she was of legal age, she decided to start buying her own products. The reason she is asking for a loan is that she was pregnant and had to stop working for one year. Now she works everyday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

Jenny wants to use the loan to invest in her business. She wants buy other products that for the lack of working capital she hasn’t been able to.

Jenny is a single mother. She is 24 years old and she has 2 children. Currently, she is separated from her husband. She lives in a house that belongs to her in-laws. They have practically given it to her to live. In spite of their separation, the father of her children helps them every month.

Jenny’s wish is to be able to buy a used car that would help her with her business and have a bigger income.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Jenny tiene una experiencia ya de 6 años con su negocio de venta de cosméticos y bisutería. Desde la época de colegio ella ya trabajaba por medio de su mama. Llevaba productos a vender a su unidad educativa. Su mama fue la que prácticamente la inicio con el negocio. Una vez cumplida la mayoría de edad decide comprar sus propios productos. El embarazo que ella tuvo la dejo sin trabajar un año motivo por el cual esta solicitando crédito. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m.

Jenny desea el crédito para invertir en su negocio. Además desea poder incluir otros productos los que por falta de capital no lo ha hecho.

Jenny es madre soltera. Tiene 24 años y 2 hijos. Actualmente esta separada de su esposo. Vive en una casa que es de sus suegros la que prácticamente se la han obsequiado para que viva con sus hijos. A pesar de la separación con el padre de sus hijos este le ayuda mensualmente. Su deseo es poder comprarse un carrito de segunda. Con el que le ayudaría bastante en la movilización de su negocio y por ende obtendría mayores ingresos.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana N. is a 26-year-old mother of two. Her husband is a waiter at a local resort. This steady income can cover the basic necessities of her family, but Diana is committed to also taking responsibility for the financial management of her household. She joined SPBD to find a way that she could start up her own business. She began a small taro plantation with her first loan. She is now seeking additional funds to purchase fertilizers and tools that will improve her crop yield. Diana wants her children’s lives to be different than hers. She knows that she didn’t get a good education, and she desperately wants to be able to fund a good education for her children. She believes that her taro farm is the key to being able to reach this goal.

loans.use: Buy fertilizers and tools

loans.name: Datura

texts.en: Datura is a florist. She loves to work on her own beautiful garden by growing more different flowers to make beautiful bouquets, and also to make more potted plants for sale to the public. She earns ST$200 (approximately USD80) per day from the sale of flowers and potted plants. There is always a high demand from her clients, especially when there are special occasions which require flower decorations. Datura is applying for another loan to buy more pots and flower seeds for her business.

loans.use: Buy more pots and new oasis, and more flower seeds to grow in the garden

loans.name: Asosaasaa

texts.en: Asosaasaa is married with five children. She is very talented in sewing different types of styles, and she has been doing this business for a long time. Although she earned some money at the beginning, it was still not enough because there weren’t enough clients, plus she depended on these clients providing their own materials. When she received her first loan of ST$750, she bought her own materials and either sold the finished clothing at the flea markets or she provided for all her customers by her own money and they repaid her later. Asosaasaa is hoping to get another loan to help with the extension of the business by building a stable place to sell her sewing materials with very good service. She can also pay her kids' school fees with the money she gets from the business.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for her business pace

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is a 60-year-old woman who had seven children, although one of her children died from a sickness that neither the hospital nor the traditional Samoan medicine woman could cure.  In addition to her husband and children, six of her extended family lives with Elena. Her husband does agricultural work to support their family, fishing and raising taro. Elena’s sewing business brings in a steady income. She sews women’s and men’s clothing in popular Samoan styles for local villagers. But Elena reserves her sewing income to fund her daughter’s university education. With a loan, Elena would purchase a new sewing machine that would help keep up her business and ensure her daughter had the means to continue at the university.

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en: Avelina V. is married with six children. She started with a ST$750 loan to operate an ice-pop business. She used that loan to buy a new freezer which is essential to her business. Her customers are the school children and the villagers. She operates her business happily because she believes that she earns more money from it and it also helps out her family's needs. Avelina is applying for another loan to purchase a bigger freezer for the business and a wheelbarrow for delivering her ice-pops to the school. She is also planning to invest in a food stall to operate together with her ice-pop business in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase a new freezer

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa is 50 years old, married and has four children, one of whom is blind. Elisa’s husband is a fisherman and works for one of the tourist resorts near their small village. His wages are not enough to support the family, and the income that Elisa brings in from her sewing business is critical to the family finances. Given how important her business is to supporting her family, Elisa want to invest in a new sewing machine. A new machine will increase her productivity and allow her to increase her business income. Her chief goal is always to ensure that her children are provided for and happy.

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Eneleka

texts.en: Eneleka operates a small grocery store where she sells drinks, snacks, twisties, lollies, tins of herring, and all other stock needed by customers. She is a 34-year-old mother of eight children; six live in Samoa and two reside overseas, but they all support their mother's business. Her goal was to improve their standard of living, and for her children to get a better education and better access to proper health care. Eneleka joined SPBD in 2004; she paid off her first loan and relaxed for some time, but now she is applying for her next loan to buy more stock for her village store. Her shop is open from Monday to Sunday and she earns ST$140 (approximately USD60) profit a day. She puts the profits from her business into her savings account with SPBD to assist in refilling the stock of the business if any week is too slow.

loans.use: Buy more stock for the shop

payments.comment: Kiva Lenders, SPBD is pleased to report that Eneleka successfully repaid her loan ahead of the loan term.  She is now applying for a third loan.  She has now made two expansions to her shop and plans on another.  She used her profits to help pay for her children's educational fees.  Thank you very much for your support.

loans.name: Faafouina

texts.en: Faafouina runs a taro plantation and a fruit farm. She is 39 years old and has six children.  Her husband earns wages of less than USD 3 a day and supplements this with some fishing, but this was never enough to support their large family. So Faafouina joined SPBD in order to find a way of lifting their family out of poverty. When she joined the program, the SPBD staff and the women in her center spent a lot of time with her, teaching her how to run a business and how to handle cash and count money. Now she is able to handle her business alone and is a whiz at counting money. She is still aiming to grow her business and keep improving her family, and so she is applying for an additional loan to purchase fertilizers that can improve her crop yield. Two of Faafouina’s children have graduated from school and have jobs in government offices. She is very proud of their accomplishments and hopes that with hard work she can provide a bright future for her younger children, too.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers for her taro and fruit farm

loans.name: Faamaopo

texts.en: Faamaopo is a young lady of 35 years, with six children. She is very talented in making elei materials, which is one of the most sought-after Samoan types of painted materials for making clothes and lavalavas. By operating this business, she spent her first loan of ST$750 to purchase paints, elei wood and different types of materials. Money earned from the business helps support her family needs.

loans.use: To purchase materials, paint, and brushes, and to pay her children's school fees

loans.name: José

texts.en:
José has 13 years’ experience with his business of selling groceries. He used to be a bricklayer. With his small savings and on his own initiative, he decided to set up the store. He thought about it because there wasn’t this type of business in his neighborhood. Thanks to the store, he was able to buy a small used car which he uses to do deliveries in the mornings from time to time. He was able to buy two lots that he gave to his children to live there. He works everyday of the week from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m.

José wants to use the loan to invest in his store. He was left without working capital because his brother suffered a stroke and he is has been helping him through out his recovery.

José is married. He has 5 children and only 3 live with him. They are still in school and help him with the store. His wife doesn’t work and when José needs to go out she is in charge of selling the groceries. Jose’s wish is to be able to buy two small sugar cane houses for his lots to get an additional income.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

José tiene una experiencia ya de 13 años con su negocio de venta de víveres. El señor se dedicaba a la albañilería. Poco a poco con sus ahorros y por iniciativa propia decide ponerse el negocio de la tienda. Pensó en ese negocio ya que por el sector donde vive no había este tipo de servicio. Gracias al negocio a logrado comprarse un carrito de segundo el cual lo trabaja por las mañanas realizando fletes de vez en cuando. Fruto de sus ahorros también a comprado 2 solares los cuales les ha dado a sus hijos para que vivan en ellos. Trabaja en la tienda todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 10 p.m.

José desea el crédito para poder invertir en su tienda. La que a quedado un poco sin capital por motivos de que su hermano sufrió un derrame cerebral y el fue el apoyo para que su hermano se recupere. /p>

José es casado. Tiene 5 hijos de los cuales solo 3 viven con el. Los que estudian y le ayudan en la atención de la tienda. Su esposa se dedica al hogar y cuando José tiene que salir ella se encarga de vender sus productos. Su deseo es poder comprarse unas dos casitas de caña para ponerlas en sus terrenos y que estas le puedan producir otros ingresos.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise to have a bigger inventory

loans.name: Faaga

texts.en: Faaga manages two sources of income to support her family of twelve. Her husband and some local village boys work on the taro plantation, and Faaga sells the taro crop at the local market. Taro is in ample supply at her local market, however, and sometimes the over-supply means that Faaga can’t sell the entire crop. So Faaga also began making and selling ice-pops (locally referred to as “ice cakes”), which are a favorite of the local children. This additional income helps keep up with the children’s expenses, but Faaga is anxious to find ways to invest further in her businesses and grow her income. She will use loan funds to buy weed-killers to improve her taro crop as well as to buy ingredients for ice-pops in bulk (to get better prices and increase her profit-margin).

loans.use: Buy weed-killers for her plantation and ingredients for ice-pops

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en: Mariana is a 35-year-old mother of five children from the village of Toamua, Samoa. She joined the SPBD program in 2004 and she is still an active member. She started off her business with selling ice cakes and sausage sizzle, and now she operates a small grocery store from her home. Mariana is a hard-working and very dedicated mother, as demonstrated by showing more improvement in her business as well as her home. She opens her shop from Monday to Sunday and earns $300 (approximately USD120) in profits, or more, per week after paying off all business related expenses. She is looking forward for her next loan to rebuild her house and also to upgrade her business.

loans.use: Fill in stock and buy materials to rebuild her house

loans.name: Faapala

texts.en: Faapala S. is an old lady of 75 years, married with nine children. Despite her old age, she still tries to come up with ways to earn money to support her and help out with the family commitments. Faapala works very hard in making and operating her popcorn business, so that it can be profitable even though she gets very sick at times. The popcorn is sold at schools or delivered to the village, but when she is sick, her daughter helps out. Faapala can never forget or leave her business because it’s what she relied on in the past to pay her kids' school fees and cater for her family needs, even though the children are now employed and more money is coming in to support the family.

loans.use: To purchase a popcorn popper, corn seeds, to pay kids' school fees

loans.name: Aipopo

texts.en: Aipopo has raised seven children. She still provides financial support to much of her family via her business selling coconuts. Most of what Aipopo sells at the local market is pre-husked coconuts, which command a slightly higher price than the other coconut products. She is confident that her business has a future, and she says that she prays for another twenty years of being strong enough to carry on the operation.

loans.use: Buy tools

loans.name: Alieta

texts.en: It is the income from Alieta’s store that pays the household bills and the school expenses of the children.  She used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase her shop several years ago.  Alieta heard about the program from listening to other women in her village talk about their experiences with the loans.  She launched her business smoothly, and she repaid her initial loan.  Now Alieta is interested in applying for another loan in order to purchase new goods that are in high demand by her customers.  She believes that by reinvesting in the business and expanding her product line, she can increase her profits further.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for store

loans.name: Faasulu

texts.en: “Works which are done by men can also be done by women, if the heart is in it,” Faasulu commented. She is married with six children, five of whom are in school. Painting is a job you seldom see women perform, but Faasulu believes otherwise. She is very handy with a paint brush and therefore made it her business. She goes to the houses which need painting, especially new ones, and does the job herself or sometimes gets the help of her husband. That is how she spent her first loan of ST$750 up to her third loan of ST$1250, buying paints, brushes, varnish, and more. Faasulu likes doing this business because she’s not only good at it, it also gives her more money.

loans.use: To purchase more paint, brushes, varnish

loans.name: Faaoloviti

texts.en: Faaoloviti is a 38-year-old married woman with three children.  Neither she nor her husband has work outside of their small taro plantation.  Faaoloviti recognizes the importance of continually reinvesting in their land and plants to ensure they remain a viable and steady source of income.  Some of their crop has recently been the object of theft and a playground for wild animals.  Thus, Faaoloviti and her husband would like to invest in a barrier fence to protect their crop.

loans.use: Buy fencing material

loans.name: Aomalu

texts.en: Aomalu operates a flea market stall in the local town market.  The market is located two hours from where she lives, and the journey back and forth is both taxing and expensive.  Aomalu has fallen on hard times because in addition to the expense of hiring transport for her and her crop, her yield has been low due to a series of disasters that have befallen her orange grove.  She is confident that one thing that will help protect her crop from stray animals and theft is building a barrier fence.  She has requested a loan to help her achieve this goal, thereby protecting a valuable income stream for Aomalu’s family.

loans.use: Fencing material

loans.name: Faaui

texts.en: Faaui is married with one daughter. Because she didn’t complete her schooling, there was no hope for her in getting a job. She decided that the best option for her was to work on her family’s land to grow vegetables, and thus made it her business, generating income for her family. She plants cabbages, tomatoes, cucumbers, peas and pumpkins in her garden. That is how she utilized her first loan, by purchasing vegetable seeds and fertilizers for her vegetable garden. She delivers her different vegetables to restaurants in town and some are sold at the market. Faaui is earning more money which helps very much in supporting her family’s daily needs and also the raising of her kids. She also sells coconuts for extra revenue in case the vegetables are slow in prospering or ripening.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, farming/gardening tools, and plastic bags

loans.name: Faititili

texts.en: Faititili is 44 years old.  She lives in a small Samoan village and makes meat pies that she sells at a stand to both locals and tourists.  She has five children.  Two of her children are grown.  One is employed and helps contribute to the family finances; the other wasn’t able to finish school due to her troubled family finances, and helps Faititili with her business.  Faititili toils tirelessly with the goal of keeping her small children, and raising her family’s standard of living.  She will use a loan to purchase supplies in bulk (and thus at better rates) for her food sales.  The small pies she makes -- puff pastries filled with meat, cheese and/or vegetables -- are a Samoan favorite.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and supplies for her baking

loans.name: Aseria

texts.en: Aseria is an energetic mother of six children.  She sells coconuts and vegetables at the local village flea market. Her six children help her out by harvesting coconuts, while she concentrates on tending her vegetable garden.  Her husband also works on their small farm. She is aiming to expand their small operation into a full-scale farm. She is proud of her business; one of Aseria’s dreams is to be able to teach one of her children how to manage the family enterprise and have one of them carry on the business far into the future.

loans.use: Fertilizer and tools for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Feagaiga

texts.en: Feagaiga is a mother of four children.  Her husband works as a bus driver in their district, but his income is not enough to fully provide for their large family.  She has already planned a bright future for their children, and she feels it is her responsibility to ensure they can achieve it.  Since she started her taro plantation with an initial loan from SPBD, she has seen her family’s standard of living improve.  Feagaiga is anxious to keep investing in her plantation because she believes that there is more income growth possible, and with additional loan funds she will extend her plantation.

loans.use: Expand her plantation

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 40-year-old woman with three young children.  She tends a banana plantation just behind her house.  The income from this plantation puts food on the table and pays for her children’s education.  Thus, Cecilia feels strongly that her children’s futures depend on her ability to keep her plantation productive and in good condition.  Cecilia would like to invest in pest control products that can help save her crop from damaging insects as well as invest in some natural fertilizers that should improve her crop yield.

loans.use: Buy pest control products and fertilizer

loans.name: Faavae

texts.en: Faavae invested her first loan with SPBD in operating a business selling pork buns and ice-pops. She is now paying off her third loan, which was also used in purchasing necessities for her business. Some of these loans were used in paying her three kids' school fees. One of her children is attending university and the fees are very expensive. Faavae believes that she wouldn’t be able to meet their family needs without the assistance of the program.

loans.use: To purchase pork buns ingredients, cordial sugar, and assist in paying kids' school fees

loans.name: Lien

texts.en: Mrs. Lien and her husband, Phuong, are the same age, 48. They have 3 children and must support all of them, who are going to school. Mrs. Lien's first child, Nam, is going to the university, and her second and third are in grades 12 and 11. They have a little land for cultivation, about 5000 sqaure meters to plant cashew nut trees and cassavas. Their income is low at $200/year, but the expense of tuition is high, so Lien’s selling soya cakes at the local market is important for increasing their income, which averages $7/person/month. She wants to  borrow $50 so that she can buy a supply of soya with cash, which is cheaper than using credit with high interest.

loans.use: Selling soya cakes

loans.name: Feauai

texts.en:
Feauai recently joined the SPBD program.  She took out a small loan to purchase some taro plants to start a plantation, and she paid it back quickly.  She is now applying for a second loan to purchase additional taro plants.  Feauai is really excited about the micro-loan program and is anxious to continue reinvesting and growing her business.  For the first time in her life, she has money in her pockets.  Feauai also says that one of her main goals is to increase her savings.  While times are good now, she is saving because she says that she knows a lot about hard times, and when those come, she wants to be sure she is prepared.
.

loans.use: Buy taro plants

loans.name: Epefania

texts.en: Epifania is 34 years old and has three children.  Not too long ago, her life changed abruptly when her husband was killed in a car accident.  In addition to her emotional loss, Epifania also faced a severe economic crisis.  She had never had a job before, and now needed to find a means to support herself and her three children.  Epifania joined the SPBD program in order to gain access to the capital to start her own business.  She began running a fishing boat with the help of some extended family, and she began to have some financial security.  However, her boat is now in sore need of repair, as is some of the fishing equipment.  Having repaid her first loan, she is now seeking an additional loan to make the repairs and upgrades necessary to protect her only income source.

loans.use: Repairs to fishing boat and equipment

loans.name: Gese

texts.en: Gese runs a taro plantation.  She is a 39-year-old mother of six children.  Her husband does not have steady employment, but helps Gese with her taro plantation work.  She is a very active member of the SPBD center in her village.  She has used four previous loans to launch and grow her taro plantation.  Her plantation is thriving, and she is able to clear a profit of about ST$250 a week (approximately USD100).  Gese is quick to relate that her family has improved in many ways since she started with the program, especially her children’s education – they are all in school!  She hopes that any future success will allow her to send her children to college.  With all her previous loans paid in full with an outstanding record of timeliness, Gese is now requesting her fifth loan.  This loan would be used to purchase tires for the truck she uses to haul her taro to market and would also be used to do some maintenance on their outdoor shower.

loans.use: Buy new tires for their truck, and home improvements

loans.name: Fetulima

texts.en: Fetulima is married with five children. Three of her kids are in high school and two are in primary levels. In the beginning, she sold small goods in her house, like snacks for kids, sugar, salt, flour, bathing soaps and lollies. She bought them from wholesalers in bulk and then re-sold them in pieces. These transactions took place at her home because she did not have a shop to be used. Therefore she used her first loan from the program to build a shop to sell her items. Now Fetulima is a very happy woman because now she is able to earn money from her new shop; she plans to use this loan to extend the shop and make it more productive.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for the expansion of her shop

loans.name: Fuamata

texts.en: Fuamata used to own a small shop in her village, but she unfortunately had to close it.  Now she needs additional income to support her family and believes that reorganizing and reinvesting in her shop is the means to raise her family’s standard of living.  She joined SPBD to gain access to loan funds so that she pay renewal fees for the business license and re-open her doors with a full product line.  Her husband and her children are all committed to making Fuamata’s venture work. She says that she can count on their help to keep the business in good condition.

loans.use: to renew her business license and re-stock the shop

loans.name: Ioe

texts.en: Ioe S. owns a small grocery shop in a Samoan village.  Her husband works at one of the supermarkets in the capital. Their combined income at present allows them to send their seven children to school.  Ioe strategically opened her shop near the river because that is where villagers gather.  She has used previous microloans to finance the expanding of her inventory. She is currently seeking additional loan funds to use in a similar fashion.  Her dream is to be able to provide her children with the means for future success. She hopes that the growth in her revenue will be enough to finance a university education for all of her seven children.

loans.use: to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Karoline

texts.en:
Karoline has just joined the SPBD program.  She joined in order to invest in her small plot of land and develop it into a taro plantation.  She was born and raised in the small Samoan village in which she still lives in with her husband.  Neither she nor her husband are employed so this venture in cultivating taro is their only source of income.  

Unfortunately, Karoline’s husband has some significant health problems. This means that it falls on her to start up this plantation.  They hope that after the initial harvests, they can hire some local boys to do much of the work under the supervision of Karoline’s husband.  Historically, they have had to rely on the generosity of their relatives to survive.  Although Karoline gave birth to three children, these children are living with relatives because Karoline and her husband cannot afford to raise them.  Karoline’s dream is financial independence and the ability to provide for her husband and children.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Gogosina

texts.en: All farmers would agree that is hard to keep a plantation going when you lack tools and the right supplies.  Gogosina is experiencing this problem.  She is dedicated to developing her small plot of land into a vegetable farm but she is suffering from a lack of tools.  She is seeking loan funds to buy some fertilizer and a basic toolset to help her plant and harvest.  Her husband has steady work as a security guard at the local school, but his small wages are not enough to cover the family expenses.  Gogosina believes that financial well-being will come from the vegetable crop. She is dedicated to cultivating her land into a dependable source of income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and gardening tools

loans.name: Fiaava'e

texts.en: Fiaava'e is an old lady with six children. All of them are unemployed and do not have any financial means. Luckily, her husband is a very good fisherman and that is their only means of earning money to support the family. She started with a $750ST loan and now is on her fourth loan. She used the money to buy new fishing gear for her husband. The other rest of the money was used to build their new bathroom and pay her childrens’ school fees. She is very happy to be in the program and believes that the loans were a savior for her and her family.  They were able to provide for not only the business, but also their living condition but her kids’ fees.

loans.use: to purchase more fishing equipment and building materials for home improvement

loans.name: Imoa

texts.en: 62-year old Imao relies on the profits from her small shop to support her family of ten.  Imao’s children and grandchildren live with her. All profits from the store are either reinvested in the store or pay for the family’s expenses.  Acting as breadwinner for this large family, she is unable to save for her own future.  Imoa is trying to find a cheaper means of buying her inventory, thereby improving her profit margin.  She will use a loan to buy supplies in bulk from a wholesaler in the capital.  This small growth in the profit margin will benefit Imoa, her children and her grandchildren.

loans.use: to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Laumua

texts.en: Laumua is a married mother of five children. She is from the village of Sataoa and runs a taro plantation.  She started her plantation with an initial SPBD loan that she used to buy seeds.  She harvested 300 taro plants during her first harvest.  After two harvests, she made ST 500 (about USD 200).  Laumua has invested some of this revenue into more taro plants and now has a total of 4,500 plants.  Her dreams of growth aren’t over and she aims to expand further.  Her husband and children are very excited about the extra income and they notice the satisfaction it brings their mother in being able to support the family.  She is seeking additional loan funds to make some improvements to her plantation and her home.  She needs to purchase fencing material, a lawnmower and make some necessary repairs to the floor and roof of her house.

loans.use: to buy a chain-link fence, lawnmower and make home improvements

loans.name: Fofoa

texts.en: Making use of natural resources is an alternative our people turn to when they cannot get jobs to support their families financially. Fofoa chose fishing as her business because it was the means of her survival before she received help from the SPBD program. She is now on her fifth loan of $1400ST. She used the money to buy more fishing gear, build a new bathroom for the family and pay the school fees for her three children, who are all attending high school. She also sold pancakes to earn more money to finance the weekly repayments. Fofoa believes that the program helped her and her family in not only putting her husband’s fishing talent into earning money but also improving their standard and way of living.

loans.use: to pay the childrens’ school fees and purchase more fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Iulia

texts.en: Iulia is a 37 year old widow.  When her husband died, she was left to raise and support four children by herself.  In order to provide for her children, Iulia opened a small stand in front of her house where she sells fruits, vegetables and basic household items.  However, the income from this makeshift store wasn’t enough to meet the financial needs of her family.  Iulia thus joined SPBD and applied for a loan to open a proper store in her village.  So far this has been a successful venture.  She is confident that investing in her store is the only way to ensure a bright future for her children.  Having repaid her first loan, she is now seeking additional funds in order to expand her product line.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Leitu

texts.en: Leitu lives in a small Samoan village with her husband and newborn baby.  Her husband works as a carpenter and earns just enough to provide for the basic necessities for their family of three.  Leitu’s parents recently passed away and left her their small taro plantation.  Leitu capitalized on this opportunity to earn additional income.  She joined SPBD to gain access to the capital necessary for her to develop her land into a productive taro farm.  She is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and some basic tools to help her through her first large harvest season.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and basic tools

loans.name: Lanuola

texts.en: Lanuola is a 38 year old woman.  She is married and has six children.  While her husband is employed as a taxi driver, his income isn’t steady and doesn’t meet the needs of her large family.  To ensure that her six children can remain in school and have a bright future, Lanuola opened a shop in her small Samoan village.  She has used microloan facilities to expand and upgrade her business.  While her store is profitable, the sales are still not enough to cover the family’s expenses. Lanuola feels that being a successful shop-keeper is the most promising means of becoming financially secure. Therefore, she is seeking an additional loan to finance further expansion of her product line.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en: Fofoga is married with three children. Fofoga struggled financially in the beginning because there was very little money to support her family and at the same time meet her children’s school fees. She joined the SPBD program for help by getting her 1st loan of $300ST, which she used to start a business of selling ice-cakes. The money was used to purchase a small freezer for the business. The ice pops were sold to the village people and school children. Fofoga is now slowly earning extra money to cater for the neglected needs of her family. She is at the same time gaining confidence to build new ideas to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase a new freezer

loans.name: Laumoe

texts.en: Laumoe lives in the seaside village of Lalomanu.  This village boasts one of Samoa’s most beautiful white sandy beaches.  Laumoe owns several beach fales right at the shoreline.  A fale is a small open hut with a thatched roof built in the style of a traditional Samoan house.  Laumoe rents these fales to overnight guests.  She is aiming to attract more tourists by upgrading the services she provides.  Thus, she is seeking funds to buy bed linens, mosquito nets and insect repellents so that she can keep her guests comfortable.

loans.use: to buy bed linens, mosquito nets and insect repellents for overnight guests

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en: Mrs. T. is married with three children, who are all attending primary school. When she was young she learned from her mother the weaving process and how to produce Samoan-style handicrafts such as bags, hats and earrings. She decided to make the sale of handicrafts her business because she believes she is very good at it. She is now on her fifth loan which is $2750ST.  The money was used to build two rooms for their house and buy more equipment for the business such as vanish, paints and glues etc. She is planning to get another loan to build a new house for the business to create a small marketplace for her handicrafts.  The loan will also finance accessories needed for her plantation, which helps her with the business and repayments.

loans.use: To purchase bulding materials for the expansion of the business

loans.name: Lise

texts.en: For 29 year old Lise A., planting and harvesting taro is part of her daily life and only source of income. When she first joined SPBD, she used her first loan to buy an extension on the land as well as some pest control agents.  Her taro crop is growing but to keep her plants in good condition she is seeking further fencing material.  This will allow her to finish the fence that will help keep stray animals out of her crops and pest control agents.  Having repaid her first loan, Lise is eligible for this second round of funding to help keep her plantation productive.

loans.use: to buy pest control agents and chain-link fencing material

loans.name: Penina

texts.en: Penina is twenty five years old.  She lives in a small seaside village with her husband and two children.  Penina’s husband does not have a job and thus the whole family relies on Penina’s beach fales for income.  Her beach fales are small, open huts with thatched roofs built in the style of traditional Samoan homes.  Penina’s fales sit on one of Samoa’s beautiful, white sandy beaches.  As there is competition from other beach fale owners in the area, Penina is applying for a loan to do some renovations and upgrade the services she provides to her guests.

loans.use: to renovate beach fales

loans.name: Lemalie

texts.en: Lemalie S. is thirty eight years old and has five children.  Lemalie inherited a small plantation from her parents and is working hard to ensure it remains in good condition.  The taro crop from her plantation provides for her family, so she is committed to investing in it to ensure that it remains a viable and steady source of income.  But the main obstacle to Lemalie securing a healthy crop is the limited water supply to her plantation.  She is applying for a loan to build fresh water lines to her farm.  She knows her parents would be proud of the improvements she is able to make to their legacy. She is certain that her children will appreciate the bright future she is working so hard to secure for them.

loans.use: to build water lines to supply taro plantation

loans.name: Herotia

texts.en:
Herotia is married with five children. She is very talented in making elei and prints. This is why she decided to operate this particular business. She spent her first loan starting her operation and utilised the profits to pay for the school fees of her five children, whom are all attending high school. She believes that the loan and her hard work allowed her to continue operating her business.  The business has made it possible for her and her family to meet their needs.

She is looking forward to have another loan to improve the business.  The money will be used to buy different materials and paints.

loans.use: to purchase more materials and paint

loans.name: Leone

texts.en: Leone S. is a thirty-six year old mother of five children.  She runs two ventures – a taro plantation and a business making and selling banana chips.  On her land she grows both taro and bananas.  The taro she takes to the local market to sell and the bananas she uses to make the chips to sell in the village.  Leone is divorced and raises and supports her children on her own.  She inherited her father’s land when he passed away, and she has developed this land into a solid plantation and she continues to expand it year by year.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her taro farm and packaging for banana chips

loans.name: Laga

texts.en: Mrs. T. is married with two children. She operated a small food stall when she received her first loan from SPBD. She cooks assorted dishes like taro, palusami (a food make from taro leaves) and fish. She buys the taro, taro leaves and fish for her dishes from the market.  She is now repaying her second loan of $1250ST, which was used to improve her business and make house repairs. She is thinking of finding a spot at the flea market in Apia to extend her business. She believes she will attract more customers there. Therefore, when she receives another loan, she will have to increase the number of dishes she sells. Laga is very glad for the program’s assistance because now she is able to financially support her family and provide for their personal needs.

loans.use: to purchase more chicken leg quarters, onions, soya, sausages, mutton flaps, pepper and stock

loans.name: Lisa Tila

texts.en: Lisa Tila is a married mother of four.  She resides in a small Samoan village.  She is twenty-seven years old and is following in her elder sister’s footsteps in baking and selling muffins to support her family.  Lisa’s husband is unemployed although he sometimes helps her with the muffin-making business.  With a loan, she hopes to finance the purchase of bulk supplies to reduce her costs.  Lisa works closely with her elder sister, Orepa, on this business. Orepa and Lisa’s ambition is to be able to expand their business to the point of opening up a muffin shop in Samoa’s capital city, Apia.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her muffins

loans.name: Sailua

texts.en: Sailau is a married woman with five children. Her husband is a teacher in their district  primary school. Her husband’s salary was the only income for their family but wasn’t enough to cover their expenses.  Therefore, Sailau joined SPBD to find a means of supplementing the family finances.  She used two small loans to launch her small village store.  Her business is now successful with about USD 200 in sales each week.  This income is crucial to them being able to pay for all of her children’s school fees. She is anxious to expand her shop and is seeking additional loan funds to do so.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her shop

loans.name: Lita

texts.en: Lita is a 29 year old woman with two children.  She provides the main source of income for her family, which includes her elderly, blind father who lives with her.  Lita makes a special Vi juice drink.  It is made from a local fruit, Vi, and is blended with milk, vanilla and peanuts.  She sells the drink at the local village primary school from Monday through Friday.  On Saturday, she sells the drink at the local rugby field.  She earns about USD 12–16 a day through her Vi juice drink sales.  She will use the loan to buy a freezer so she can prepare the Vi juice drinks in advance and freeze it.  She and her husband both believe that they can produce Vi juice drinks on a larger scale and thus enjoy a larger income. Their dream is to grow this business.

loans.use: to buy a freezer

loans.name: Laue

texts.en:
Laue is a mother of two. She is a very strong and determined woman seeking different ways to earn more money. She has been operating her vegetable garden for a long time but the money earned from the business is not enough to meet her familys immediate needs and maintain the garden. 

She started with a $750ST loan and purchased equipment with the money. She is now repaying her fourth loan of $1000ST, which she used to finance the purchase of a second hand pick-up truck she uses to deliver her vegetables to the market. Laue is delighted to own a car because this really helps take some of the burden off her shoulders.  It allows her to save money on public transport fares and is also helps her deliver vegetables to various restaurants in town. She also has a stable spot at the market to sell her vegetables.  Therefore, she is earning more profit and at the same time meets her familys daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase more gardening tools and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Lofi

texts.en: Lofi is a single mother with three young children.  Three years ago, her husband went overseas for a job opportunity and was never heard from again.  Lofi struggles everyday to raise her children and financially support them.  After her husband’s departure, Lofi joined the SPBD program to find a sustainable way to provide for her family.  With her initial loan, she began to grow taro on a small plot of land.  With a small but steady income stream, Lofi was able to feed and clothe her children and send them to school.  Having fully repaid this first loan, she is now seeking additional loans to finance an expansion of her small taro plantation.  She has dreams of being able to substantially improve the living conditions of her children. She believes that investment in her taro field is the best way to reach that goal.

loans.use: to expand her plantation

loans.name: Salaevalu

texts.en: Salaevalu is thirty-five years old and has five children.  Keeping up with the school fees for all of her children is a struggle that she doesn’t always win.  She used two previous loans from SPBD to launch her flea market stall where she sells traditional Samoan handicrafts to locals and tourists.  While her business is going well, she still needs to increase her sales to be able to give all her children the education she feels that they deserve.  Thus, having repaid the first two loans, she is seeking a third to expand her product line and increase her inventories.

loans.use: to purchase traditional Samoan crafts from local artisans to re-sell at her flea market stall

loans.name: Luma

texts.en: Luma lives in a small Samoan village with her husband and children.  Her husband brings in a very meager income and Luma and her family lives under very poor conditions.  However, Luma joined SPBD because she is confident that combining hard work with loan funds will enable her to bring enough income to dramatically raise her family’s standard of living.  When Luma joined SPBD, the program and the other members spent a lot of time with her and taught her how to create a business budget and account for her business income.  Luma is growing confident in her business skills and will use loan funds to expand her currently small banana crop into a steady income source and reach her dream of financial security.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pest control agents

loans.name: Saolele

texts.en: Saolele is a 52 year old woman with four children.  Her children are all grown and have their own families.  Saolele works hard to remain financially independent and not rely on her children for income.  She has a coconut tree farm.  Saolele harvests coconuts from her farm and brings them to town to sell.  However, she feels that she sorely needs to invest in her farm in order to ensure that this income stream remains viable.  Saolele is seeking loan funds in order to purchase machetes to aid in harvesting the coconuts, fertilizer to increase her yield and secure reliable transportation to the market.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, machetes, and rent transportation

loans.name: Satia

texts.en: Satia C. is 37 years old, married and has four children.  Satia’s husband has been unable to provide a steady income that can support their family.  Therefore, when she heard about the loan facilities available to women entrepreneurs, she joined SPBD’s program.  Satia was confident that she could run her own business and support the family.  She has since used two small loans to open a beach fale business.  Her fales are small open huts with thatched roofs built in the style of traditonal Samoan houses.  Satia caters to backpackers and picnickers.  She is sure of the demand for her fales given their unbeatable location on the white sandy beaches along Samoa’s coast.  She is anxious to build additional fales.  She will use another loan to put up three more fales.

loans.use: to build additional fales
